name: Presidente. –
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 16 March 2017.

name: El presidente. –
text: I would like to convey on behalf of the European Parliament our condolences and solidarity with the Colombian people after the Mocoa tragedy.The avalanche of water and mud has caused many victims and there are also two European missing.I therefore want to express the proximity and support of this Parliament to Colombia, its citizens and, especially, the families of the deceased.

name: Presidente. –
text: In accordance with article 166 of the regulation and after having listened to the person concerned, I decided to impose a sanction on the Hon.Pedicini for using insults and offensive language towards other Members of the European Parliament during his speech in the Chamber on 14 March 2017. The sanction consists in the loss of the right to the residence allowance for a period of two days.The decision was notified to the Member concerned, who apologized for the words used in his speech.

name: Presidente. –
text: Let us now move on to the order of business.The final draft agenda, set by the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149, at its meeting on Wednesday 29 March 2017, was distributed.Following consultations with the political groups, I would like to submit to the House the following proposal to amend the final draft agenda: the statement by the President of the Eurogroup on the progress of the second review of the economic adjustment program for Greece isreplaced, due to the decision of the President of the Eurogroup, by statements from the Council and the Commission with the same title and in the same time slot.Are there any objections?

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. -  Mister President! My group, the EPP Group, supports the change in the title. However, I would like to say that it is quite a scandal that the President of the Eurogroup, although the plenary and the Conference of Presidents have unanimously asked for it, and although you, as President of the European Parliament, have conveyed that wish to him does not consider it necessary to appear here in the European Parliament when we are debating important issues such as Greece. This behavior, Mr President, is unacceptable and disrespectful to the European Parliament. We ask you to express this to the head of the Eurogroup. I would also like to ask the socialists, because Mr Dijsselbloem is at least a social democrat, to hold talks with their party friends as to whether it is not possible for Dijsselbloem to appear here. And I would like to make one more thing clear, ladies and gentlemen. The colleague Dijsselbloem has given interviews in the last few weeks. We in the EPP Group want us to hold the euro together. We also want rules to be followed. But he was very, very derogatory about the countries that have had problems in recent years and that have received aid in the euro area. From our point of view, because of this disrespectful treatment, especially with the program states, Dijsselbloem's remaining in office is not acceptable. From our point of view, he should resign.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the position of the Socialist Group on this issue is very clear: we expressed it in the Conference of Presidents several times when we said that Dijsselbloem's choice not to come to Parliament was unacceptable.We reiterate it now.We said well before our colleague Weber that the interview granted by Dijsselbloem about the Mediterranean regions of Europe that spend their money on women and alcohol was shameful and scandalous, but also disrespectful and shameful towards women.And Dijsselbloem with that interview showed - but even earlier he had shown - that he did not have the aptitude to be president of the Eurogroup.This is the position of the Socialist group.This is the position of many of the socialist leaders.I hope that this is also the position of the Christian Democratic leaders, who have so far been the true supporters of Dijsselbloem.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Mr President, I will not take very long.I will simply underline that the attitude of the President of the Eurogroup is one of those contemptuous behaviors - we have seen it towards citizens, we now see it towards our institution - which are the source ofthe insurrection of a growing number of citizens against democratic institutions.Indeed, I think it is important - as you have done - that this Parliament express its deep disagreement with an arrogance that is truly out of season.However, Mr Weber, I heard of course that you referred to Mr Dijsselbloem as a socialist.For my part, it has been a long time since I stopped believing that it is because you wear the socialist bib that you behave as such.I can still tell the difference.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group.- Also in a nutshell: we discussed this last week in the Conference of Presidents.You have already explained to us that you have little desire to invite Mr Dijsselbloem again and receive a basket from him.And I think what we have to make clear to both the Council and the Eurogroup is that this behavior cannot be tolerated.Mr Dijsselbloem has an important function, especially in the implementation of measures against some countries in the European Union, and has absolutely no right to refuse to talk to the Members here.And as far as his interview stories are concerned - we also asked beforehand: Mr Dijsselbloem is the wrong man for the Euro Group, and he has to step down and shouldn't wait for someone to replace him.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, on behalf of the ECR, we want to denounce Mr Dijsselbloem's stance, because the Eurogroup is a body that takes measures to reduce pensions and salaries, pursues an anti-popular policy, and Mr Dijsselbloem does not dare to come. support the decisions of the Eurogroup. Moreover, with his shameful statements, he provoked all the peoples of Europe, he provoked the MEPs, and that is why we believe that he does not dare to come here to assume his responsibilities. This is the reality. We believe that it should be dismissed by the Eurogroup. And that is the responsibility of the leaders of the European Union. We therefore call on them to make their own decisions. This gentleman cannot be the president of the Eurogroup and insult the people. (applause)

name: Marcel de Graaff
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- I agree with the criticism of Mr Dijsselbloem voiced by my fellow chairmen.It is a shame and not only disrespectful for all the efforts that are being made in Southern European countries and the misery that people are experiencing because of all the budget cuts.It is of course also - and I agree with Mr Pittella - that it is a shame that women are spoken of in this way.That is absolutely not possible.I hope that you will express this criticism in a letter that you will send to Mr Dijsselbloem.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am going to be very short. Beyond the fact that we are all scandalised by the attitude of Mr Dijsselbloem, we have to ask ourselves whether there is also a question of principle here. And the question of principle is the following: he is the President of the Eurogroup, and so he is saying ‘my masters are the Eurogroup – the ministers of finance’. That problem can be solved by us, and that is by doing what is already in a number of our reports: to make a permanent president of the Eurogroup who is under the scrutiny of the Parliament. One of the ideas is to say: why not make the president of the Eurogroup, for example,  a vice-president of the Commission, and this vice-president of the Commission will automatically be accountable before the Parliament. So it is very good – I agree with what Mr Weber all other the colleagues have said – but let us also take account of the consequences. We can solve this in the coming years by making a permanent president, who would be a member of the Commission, accountable to this House.

name: Marco Valli
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my group, the EFDD, is also disappointed with the words put forward by the President of the Eurogroup.What he said is scandalous.For us too he should resign as soon as possible.It will now be up to the Heads of State to make a decision, but we consider it scandalous that he did not accept an invitation from this Parliament to talk about a difficult situation like that of Greece, a southern country that he insulted with his words, and we would have liked, as well as discussing this with him, maybe make a few notes on what his words were.We now await a reaction from the President and also from all groups.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our position on the Dijsselbloem phenomenon has been expressed by the President of our Group, who has spoken before: disapproval, anger at the insult to both colleagues and to the European Parliament. However, on this occasion, and as the debate has become more general, Mr President, and some issues of principle have been raised, I ask the question: who gave such possibilities and such powers to the President of the Eurogroup and to the Eurogroup in general? Was Dijsselbloem good when he came here cursing the Cypriots, proceeding to curtail deposits and memoranda? Was it good that Dijsselbloem came, as you remember, to Plenary a while ago and presented the report on the future of Europe on behalf of the five presidents? Instead of denouncing this institutional distortion, this sovereignty of the Eurogroup together with Mr Dijsselbloem, it is good to think about what we have accepted as the European Union, what we have accepted as a eurozone vis-.-Vis Dijsselbloem and the powers of the Eurogroup.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: - Mr President, while awaiting a reform of the type that President Verhofstadt very opportunely proposed, Parliament cannot let Mr Dijsselbloem's renewed contempt for it go unanswered.I propose that we apply a principle to it that we have applied to all the people and companies that have refused to cooperate with the European Parliament, with some of its committees and some of its groups.This principle consists in declaring the person concerned persona non grata in Parliament's premises and in considering that, since he does not want to come to plenary, he will never be admitted to any meeting of the European Parliament again.I think that's the least we can answer.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, on behalf of everybody who has not spoken, I would like to express our denunciation of Mr Dijsselbloem too.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Mr President, thank you for initiating this way of proceeding which means that, quite unexpectedly, on a Monday at 5 pm, a perfectly privileged time in this chamber, a debate opens on the presidency of the Eurogroup.I am pleased to note the support Mr Weber has given to the countries which are suffering from the actions of the troika.I believe it is a day to celebrate.

name: Le Président. –
text: So this is a proposal for the agenda?Are you proposing something?

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I do have something to propose.You should have ended this debate much earlier.The main thing is the debate we are going to have tomorrow to find out what the Council and the Commission are doing about Greece: everyone will be able to express themselves in this context on the Eurogroup's action on the spot, includingthose who give it a mandate, that is to say, within the Eurogroup, a certain number of finance ministers who do not want to conclude the review of the program.

name: Presidente. –
text: I am proud to preside over a Parliament which unanimously rejects the attempt by the Eurogroup president not to comply with a request, even if he is not obliged, of the representatives of the European peoples.He will send a formal letter of protest to the president of the Eurogroup telling him that the European Parliament, unanimously, does not accept such an attitude on the part of those who play such an important role.On Monday Caspary and a number of MEPs equal to the low threshold asked that the oral question on the Commission's replies to questions with a request for written answer, addressed to the Commission, be added as a second point after the oral question on trafficking in human beings.I give the floor to the Hon.Caspary to submit the request.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: – Mr President, every one of us knows an example where we have put a simple written question to the Commission and did not get a proper answer. Because of this, I have organised a kind of grassroots initiative which has an oral question with debate to the European Commission about that. In the year 2015, 157 Members of this House signed, but after three months this oral question lapsed. I started this initiative again in January this year and 246 Members signed, but this oral question will again lapse if we do not put it on this week’s agenda. Dear colleagues, I think it is not acceptable that 246 Members ask for an oral question and nothing happens, but we have good luck because according to the services this week there is some time, and so we can add this point to the agenda without removing another one. I therefore ask you to support this request that we have the debate tonight and please, even if it is very short notice, take the opportunity to take part.

name: Marco Zanni
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to ask on behalf of the ENF Group to add tomorrow afternoon, as the fifth item on the agenda, after the discussion on the revision of the multiannual financial framework, a discussion on the Ashworth report "Estimated revenue andof expenditure for the financial year 2018 - Section I - European Parliament ".The duration of the works, therefore, as you said, should be extended until midnight.I believe it is essential to discuss in this House and in front of European citizens how this institution manages its budget.Transparency must always be guaranteed, and therefore I see no reason why this unusual procedure is chosen this year, which deprives Parliament itself of one of its greatest prerogatives.I therefore ask that this amendment be put to the vote by roll call vote.

name: Presidente. –
text: Is there anyone who wants to intervene against? We put the request of the Europe of Nations and Freedom Group to hold a discussion on the report by the Hon. Ashworth on the estimate of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2018 - Section I - European Parliament. Voting is open. The vote is closed. The proposal is rejected, so the agenda is not changed. Wednesday The ALDE, S & amp; D and PPE groups called for a Commission statement on the situation in Venezuela to be added in the afternoon. The ALDE Group asked for this statement to be added as a sixth point after the report by the Hon. Vajgl on the 2016 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The S & amp; D Group requested that this statement be added as a fifth bullet, following the Commission's statement on the adequacy of the protection afforded by the EU-US Privacy Shield (without resolution). The EPP Group asked for this statement to be added as a fourth point, after the report by the Hon. Gabriel on third countries whose nationals must be in possession of a visa or are exempt from this requirement: Ukraine. Furthermore, the discussion will be concluded by a resolution, which will be voted on in the April II part-session. I now give the floor to some ALDE representatives to explain the proposal. Or do we go directly to the voting? Is it enough as I have illustrated it? Mr Pimenta Lopes wants to intervene against?

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, there will certainly be a lot to discuss about Venezuela, certainly not in terms that this house knows or ever does, namely the example that Venezuela is of sovereign development at the service of a people. The discussion that is proposed is not one of solidarity with the Venezuelan people. On the contrary, it ignores the real causes of the economic crisis, it feeds the most reactionary right that destabilizes the country, that promotes contempt and public disorder, that does not respect the separation of powers that you are so fond of evoking, that boycott political dialogue . This debate and the attached resolution will not contribute to the necessary serenity or to the ongoing dialogue, but interfere with the sovereign decisions of a country, for which we reject them. Allow me, Mr. President, to remind you of two questions about the recent statements you have made. The President said he spoke on behalf of the European Parliament. Mr. President has no counterparts in Venezuela, as he does not represent any sovereign body.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have always adhered to the votes of the Chamber, to the documents approved by the Chamber.All votes were voted by a large majority: support for the Venezuelan people against the imprisonment of political prisoners, in favor of democracy and freedom.And in this the European Parliament has always expressed itself in this direction.So I have done nothing but express the position of the European Parliament.It seems to me that even today there is a large majority going in this direction.Mrs Becerra Basterrechea, had you asked to speak?

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I only want to intervene on behalf of the ALDE Group to confirm that the opportunity to debate here, on Wednesday, in this plenary session, is incomparable: it is essential that we ratify our position, which is already a follow-up to the dismantling that has been taking place during all this time. What we are going to debate here and what we want to resolve in that common Resolution is that the constitutional order in Venezuela has obviously been dismembered. The very movement of the Maduro government to make the Supreme Court remove all powers from the National Assembly, which is the representative of Venezuelans, is as unconstitutional as the subsequent order to put it back into operation. You always talk about interference, you talk about sovereignty, you talk about democracy ... The truth is that in Venezuela democracy is de facto abolished because there is no separation of powers. And our obligation as Parliament is to reinforce the position of the European Union, which Mrs. Mogherini herself, this very week, has made very clear: release of political prisoners, restoration of constitutional order and democratic elections in Venezuela now. And this week, moreover, is the time when the Organization of American States will adopt a position. We must be with them.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mr President, our group supports, as you mentioned, the request to have a debate on Venezuela.We would like that point to be discussed as early as possible, on Wednesday, and not thrown out at midnight.We also want a resolution to be voted on in the second session in April.Thank you for your attention.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, let me clarify that the S&D Group supports the idea of a debate, but does not consider that we should have a resolution. We just want the debate to take place.

name: Presidente. –
text: We are now voting, and then we will see what the decisions of the House are. The first vote concerns the possibility of adding a Commission statement on the situation in Venezuela on Wednesday afternoon. The majority is in favor of adding a new item to the agenda. It is now time to vote when the declaration is to be introduced as part of the debate. As requested by the ALDE group: as a sixth point, after the report by Hon. Vajgl; as requested by the Social Democratic Group: as fifth point; or as requested by the EPP Group as a fourth point? So let's vote on the ALDE proposal first, as the sixth point. The proposal is rejected. The S & amp; D group proposes it as the fifth point. The proposal is rejected. Do you want to check? Let's check the socialist proposal, so as a fifth point. The vote is closed. The proposal is rejected. As requested by the PPE Group, as a fourth point. The proposal is approved. Then it will be inserted as a fourth point. I am now putting the EPP Group's request to the vote for a resolution to follow the debate, which will be voted on in the April II part-session. It seems to me that the House is in favor, but let's check it out. The EPP proposal is approved. So let's summarize: Commission statement Wednesday afternoon, as a fourth point, after the report by Hon. Gabriel, followed by a resolution to be voted on in the April II part-session.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: - Mr President, concerning this debate on Venezuela, we have asked several times in the Conference of Presidents for a debate on the European Union and the United States.Since the election of Mr. Trump last November, no debate has taken place.I think we are putting the cart before the horse, which is to say that we are interested in Venezuela without the point of view of the American administration.Today, I think it is necessary that we have a real debate on the future of the United States, especially in South America.

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr Ferrand, in the course of the debate you will be able to say whatever you want, and your political group will be able to express any ideas on this.The agenda was thus set.I communicate that I have not received any request to change the final agenda, so let's go ahead.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on: - the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on the European Solidarity Corps by Petra Kammerevert, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education (O-000020/2017 - B8-0210/2017), and - the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on the European Solidarity Corps by Thomas Händel, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000022/2017 - B8-0211 / 2017).

name: Petra Kammerevert
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner Navracsics, ladies and gentlemen! It is gratifying that so many young Europeans are showing interest in volunteering in solidarity with our social coexistence: 25,000 young people have already applied for the European Solidarity Corps on the relevant online platform. However, by publishing its online platform and sending the first volunteers, the Commission created facts without having a legal basis for it and, above all, without having clarified the funding. The Committee on Culture and Education welcomes the Commission's initiative to put young people more at the center of European politics. At the same time, however, we are asking ourselves a number of questions relating to the format, functionality, funding and long-term sustainability of the ESC. In our resolution we therefore point out the many weaknesses and errors of the initiative and point out the conditions that must be met in order for the ESC to be a success. The organizations responsible for youth work and voluntary services must in future be closely involved in the development and implementation of the ESC. Through their involvement in voluntary service, they have extensive experience and specialist knowledge. It would be downright negligent not to use this for the ESC. It must therefore be ensured that the achievements made so far with regard to the European Voluntary Service are not weakened. The creation of double structures would not only be ineffective but even harmful. New initiatives need fresh money. Despite the increase in funding, Erasmus + is chronically underfunded, good projects - especially in the field of youth work - have to be rejected en masse because there is not enough money. To overload Erasmus + with a new idea, Parliament cannot accept it without saying where the necessary funds are to come from. The ESC must not be at the expense of existing program lines in Erasmus +, and the youth guarantee must also remain sacrosanct. It could be a positive side effect of the ESC to increase the employability of young people, but it is not a labor market policy instrument. It is therefore important to ensure that regular jobs are not replaced by cheap volunteering. We expect a convincing and sustainable concept for the ESC from the Commission. Otherwise, the enthusiasm of young people can quickly turn into frustration, especially when it is clear that not even half of all interested parties will have a chance this year. Against this background we ask the following questions: First: How could the ESC further strengthen the European Voluntary Service? How will these two initiatives coexist in parallel and complement each other in the short and medium term? How do you avoid unnecessary overlaps between the two initiatives and how are the organizations currently involved in the European Voluntary Service involved in the process? Second: With which EU funding programs will the ESC be implemented in its initial phase, and what are the budgetary effects on these programs? What are the Commission's intentions with regard to the short, medium and long term financial sustainability of the ESC? Third, how will the Commission ensure that volunteering is not systematically exploited to replace regular jobs, whether full-time or part-time? I look forward to the Commission's replies.

name: Marita Ulvskog
text: author. – Mr President, on 7 December 2016 the Commission adopted a communication on a European Solidarity Corps. By voluntarily joining the European Solidarity Corps, these young people will be able to develop their skills and get not only work but also invaluable human experience. That is how it was spelled out by Mr Juncker. In this communication the Commission states that the European Solidarity Corps will bring together two complementary strands: volunteering and occupational. The occupational strand touches upon subjects that fall directly within the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs’ areas of competence, and this committee wishes to put a couple of questions to the Commission. How does it intend to differentiate between volunteering – which can provide very valuable experience but is unpaid – and traineeships or apprenticeships, which should be paid? How does it intend to ensure that volunteering is not misused to replace regular paid forms of employment? How will it guarantee that the initiative reaches out to all young people, in particular those in more vulnerable situations? How will it guarantee that the traineeships and apprenticeships offered under this scheme are of a good quality? How will formal and informal skills be recognised? How will it rely on, reinforce and complement existing initiatives such as Erasmus+ and the Youth Guarantees that have already been mentioned? Which share of the Employment and Social Innovation Programme and the Youth Employment Initiative and what additional funding does it envisage to allocate for the ESSC? Existing funds are already much needed given the social and employment situation in Europe. Does it consider resorting to other funds and programmes such as, for example, the ESF? How does it intend to avoid the duplication or replacement of existing programmes and tools such as Erasmus+, the European Voluntary Service and the European Youth Guarantee? We also have concerns that this is replicating already existing grassroots initiatives. The Commission has to consider already existing initiatives and respect their autonomous organisation. It is not the role of civil society to act as cheerleaders for the European Union or any governmental body. Strong, independent grassroots organisations are at the heart of European values. Finally, we would like an explanation of how it is possible that the initiative is already running, recruiting young people without the legal instrument. These questions I would like to have answered.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Solidarity Corps is at the heart of the Commission’s focus on youth. I am therefore pleased to discuss this important initiative with you today. As we debate the future of the European Union, I think it is appropriate to talk about an action which addresses young people. They have a key role in building the Europe of tomorrow and in strengthening central European values, such as engagement and solidarity. The European Solidarity Corps is a unique opportunity to put European youth, their commitment to solidarity, and their potential at the very centre of our EU agenda.  Within a few months, as Ms Kammerevert mentioned, more than 26 000 young people have signed up and the first placements have started. But as with all decisions, we need to make sure we have considered all options and heard all voices. The Commission therefore welcomes your questions and your draft motion for a resolution which raised relevant concerns. These are shared by many of the stakeholders we are consulting. Let me reassure you that we take these concerns very seriously. They are part of our ongoing reflections as we prepare the legislative proposal, setting up a dedicated framework for the Corps. We have to make sure that our proposal is spot-on and meets the expectations of young people and participating organisations.  Regarding your question about how the different programmes interact within the Corps, the European Solidarity Corps currently builds on a broad range of programmes: Erasmus+; Employment and Social Innovation; LIFE; the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund; Europe for Citizens; the European Regional Development Fund; Health; and the Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. There is in a sense no need to reinvent the wheel. We want to use this experience and the existing structures of these programmes as a basis. Our aim is not to duplicate actions or discontinue what works well. On the contrary, we want to build on the strengths of existing programmes, to increase their visibility, create synergies and offer more opportunities, because the whole is more than the sum of its parts.  Most of the volunteering activities will build on the European Voluntary Service, which looks back on 20 years of experience in developing high-quality volunteering placements for young people. All stakeholders involved consider the European Voluntary Service a major success. Solidarity jobs and traineeship placements will build on the success of ‘Your first EURES job’ and are currently mainly supported by the Employment and Social Innovation Programme. A special call for proposals has been launched to get proposals from consortia that will provide solidarity-related placements. The future legal base for the European Solidarity Corps will further improve, innovate and simplify the current approach. The Corps will bring together the activities available under the current programmes, add new activities addressing unmet needs, and use synergies wherever possible. The European Solidarity Corps portal as a single entry point for interested participants and organisations will ease access to volunteering opportunities, and it will provide digital tools to connect youth eager to express their solidarity with organisations looking for committed young people.  The key point is that with the Corps we create more opportunities for young people and make it easier for them to access these opportunities. The Corps will thus help to meet the real societal needs for solidarity across Europe, both within individual Member States and across borders. It will also harmonise and modernise the support services on offer. This includes, for example, preparation courses, language training, insurance packages and quality labels for organisations. It also includes participation certificates, as well as tools to recognise the skills acquired by young people during their placements.  We share your concerns about reaching out to young people in vulnerable situations. We believe that the European Solidarity Corps should be accessible to all youth. To reach out to those from less privileged backgrounds the Corps will ensure equal access and cater for the needs of under-represented groups by providing targeted and tailored additional support.  The forthcoming legislative proposal will be accompanied by appropriate communication and outreach measures. As for the risk of using placements as unpaid work, let me reassure you that organisations wanting to participate in the European Solidarity Corps need to be accredited. The arrangements to apply under the second phase will be proposed in the draft legal base. What I can tell you at this stage is that for the second phase we are currently considering three different types of placements: volunteering placements, job offers and paid traineeship placements. This way, the Corps will also complement the efforts made by Member States to implement the Youth Guarantee. It will provide additional opportunities for young people to make a start on the labour market by engaging in solidarity jobs or paid traineeships.  As to skills recognition, participants in the European Solidarity Corps will be entitled to receive a certificate when they have completed their placements. This could be complemented by a youth pass certificate. The Commission will work towards the recognition of the European Solidarity Corps certificate and related certificates at all levels.  You also raised the issue of the quality of placements. This is as important an issue to me as it is to you. Participating organisations have to comply with criteria that ensure that they provide only quality offers. In particular, organisations must commit to respecting the European Solidarity Corps Charter in which they pledge to foster the personal, socio-educational and professional development of participants; that they guarantee safe and decent working conditions; and that they provide adequate training for participants.  Employment offers under the occupational dimension are real jobs that will comply with national laws, regulations and collective agreements. Moreover, the principles outlined in the quality framework for traineeships will guide trainee placements offered under the Corps. Finally, the appropriate funding for the second phase of the European Solidarity Corps covering the period 2018-2020 is currently assessed by the Commission as we prepare the legal basis. Honourable Members, in conclusion let me thank you again for your interest in this initiative. We can only make it a success together for the benefit of the many enthusiastic young people all over Europe eager to make a difference.

name: Sabine Verheyen
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! In principle, I welcome the proposal by the top of the Commission to introduce a European Solidarity Corps, which by 2020 should motivate more than a hundred thousand young people to volunteer for projects and help out. These solidarity projects will benefit communities and people across Europe and are intended to help social communities to better act and respond to crisis situations or emergencies. As the EPP, we naturally share and support the aim of the European Solidarity Corps to promote a feeling of solidarity among young people in Europe and to create a more inclusive society. At the same time, however, I would like to make three main points: Firstly, there must be no competition between the ESC and the existing European Voluntary Service, which has already made efficient use of young people in voluntary work. The European Commission must quickly clarify the aim and framework of the European Solidarity Corps and ensure that it does not interfere with the well-running European Voluntary Service program. Second: As a program dedicated to youth, I believe it is urgently necessary to involve the youth organizations more closely in the development of the regulatory framework and to define the administrative framework together with them. Thirdly, we believe that the financing of the European Solidarity Corps is still completely unclear. In my opinion, new money must also be made available for this new program, and it must not be taken from funds that are already under great pressure from the medium-term financial framework. Our concern is that the funding will be taken from the Erasmus + budget. This is "left pocket, right pocket" and in the long run leads to frustration, because if the programs are in If the Erasmus + area is cut, the new Solidarity Corps will not help us any further.

name: Silvia Costa
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Navracsics, we welcomed Juncker's proposal for a European Solidarity Corps in his State of the Union address, as a response to the need to strengthen the common sense of belonging and responsibility of young people Europeans in situations of help, social commitment, responses to specific needs of local communities or emergencies, on the basis of a public appeal addressed directly to young people and in collaboration with national and European NGOs who, however, have gained specific experience in the field civil service or civil protection, or voluntary work, and that allow them to live a period of commitment in countries, I hope, different from theirs or, to a certain extent, also in their country. But I remember that the conclusions of the Council under the Italian Presidency had called for the birth of an additional European civil service to EVS, but distinct, for which in 2016 a pilot project had already been launched, with the acronym IVO, which includes three countries participants and four observer countries. Perhaps it would be helpful to see this experience as the basis of the new body. It is important to listen to European NGOs, as our resolution wrote, before defining the nature and tasks. We ask, with our resolution, that this initiative be launched with a defined legal basis, as already mentioned, with dedicated resources, hopefully in collaboration, I believe, also with national youth agencies, without removing funds from existing programs that also have an economic underestimation, as is happening in the ongoing experimentation that actually saw - and this is an important response - over 25,000 young people respond to the call. However, I believe that the body, if it is a body of solidarity, cannot be confused with the voluntary service of the European voluntary service, which in its 20 years of history has represented a reference framework for European and extra-European volunteering, in collaboration with national and accredited NGOs, and not even with EU Aid Volunteers.I think it is also important to specify the different nature of this body, which of course must maintain a civic service profile, albeit with reimbursements and insurance guarantees, but taking into account - and I end up - specific vocations and also possibly employabilitybrings into play.In Italy, for example, it is also used in part as one of the many options of the Youth Guarantee, as you mentioned.But it must be very clear that this must be aimed above all at promoting European citizenship and solidarity.

name: Jana Žitňanská
text: on behalf of the ECR Group - Commissioner, let me begin by thanking you for this initiative, which I believe will help thousands of young people to take part in voluntary projects or find an internship or job. As was the case at the launch of this initiative, and you have now confirmed this, Commissioner, the project also aims to reach young people from disadvantaged groups, including young people with disabilities. However, as I have already pointed out, the website itself, where those interested can register, is not available in sign language for the deaf or translated into an easy-to-read style for people with mental disabilities, and it is clear that accessibility must be ensured at all levels, and thus not only within the projects, but also during the registration of participants. The Commission must also ensure an effective campaign so that the communities to which the initiative is addressed find out about all the possibilities. More than 26,000 young people have already signed up for the program, as has been said, waiting for an internship, apprenticeship, job or volunteering. This number will increase and it is essential that the funding of the whole program be resolved as soon as possible, without jeopardizing already well-functioning programs such as Erasmus Plus or European Voluntary Service. I believe that the Commission is already working with the third sector in drawing up its legislative proposal, in particular with representatives of volunteer centers, who have experience on the ground. In this way, too, we can make sure that volunteering retains its character and is not abused by employers instead of paid work.

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, the new European Solidarity Corps expands and renews the current European Voluntary Service by creating opportunities for young people to volunteer and collaborate on projects that benefit communities and citizens across Europe. From a content point of view, I do not find significant news. So, as Mrs Kammerevert has said before, from the Committee on Culture we ask ourselves some questions about how this is going to work and how it is going to be financed - Mr Navracsics' statements have not given us many clues about this either. He is concerned about the fact, which some colleagues have underlined, that they may exit other programs, for example Europe for Citizens, already under-financed and for which we have just asked for a considerable budget increase. In any case, I would like to express my admiration for the philosophy of the European Solidarity Corps. Perhaps your motivations will seem naive, but I consider it noble and necessary to reaffirm the value of "solidarity" in the difficult times we live. The European Union represents the broadening of the moral circle at the supranational level and, therefore, this is an extraordinary achievement. The European principle of solidarity is at the root of the values ​​that found our Union, and we must not fail to affirm it despite the wounds that Brexit may have left us, the selfishness of some nations or our general clumsiness with the management of the refugee crisis. This body aimed at young volunteers is a step in the right direction if we want to consolidate our most basic commitments and our fundamental principles.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, it seems a joke, and in bad taste, that the same Commission that prevents the entry of refugees into Europe and that has condemned an entire generation to a precarious future now says that it wants, in 2020, one hundred thousand young people be European volunteers when, in any case, the objective should be for these young people to have a job and have a future. After decimating the cooperation sector, he wants to create a new body of volunteerism, in addition to the one that already exists, which will be financed with items destined nothing less than to combat youth unemployment. We certainly want a more supportive and inclusive Europe; the problem is that all this seems more like a farce that substitutes paid and professional work for free volunteering. This should be an occasion to promote part of that youth employment that we so need, while responding to other of our responsibilities, such as guaranteeing the right to asylum, offering a professional service. Let's start building bridges and stop building walls.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I am grateful to the colleagues who initiated this discussion because, in our opinion, the European Solidarity Corps is indeed a proposal with which we can get many young people enthusiastic about Europe. And the fact that so many got in touch in the first few weeks and signaled that they wanted to take part underscores that President Juncker's proposal is a step in the right direction. However, we should be careful that we don't just produce a new shop window decoration that is based on the old offer. And we should be very careful that the proposal does not run into bureaucratic overkill, as the Commission unfortunately succeeded in doing with the wonderful idea of ​​the Interrail Pass for young people. There are still many questions that need to be clarified. And we should not only discuss these questions among ourselves, but - that would be my appeal - also discuss with our colleagues in the national parliaments what their ideas are and support it together. I see two red lines. One is: You can't do it without fresh money. And the second means: There must be no confusion between labor market policy instruments and voluntary work. Beyond what has already been discussed at the moment, however, it would be important to me that the Commission once again pay particular attention to the possibility of how we can not only engage young people through this European Solidarity Corps, but also empower them, and also empower youth organizations they can actively engage for Europe in their own initiatives.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in his State of the Union address on September 14, 2016, President Juncker said about the European Solidarity Corps: “Young people across the Union will be able to offer their help there. where it will be most useful to respond to crisis situations ”. I believe that this statement is an admission of failure on the part of this European Union which, since its creation, has constantly spoken of solidarity only to better abolish it. How can you seriously, in the course of your text, praise the Union's solidarity when the savage competition it has imposed has devastated thousands of SMEs, put millions of Europeans out of work and enslaved several Member States? to the economic and budgetary diktats of Brussels? This observation of failure is also indicative of the European Union's total inability to resolve the crises that it itself has engendered, since the European Solidarity Corps poses the challenge of integrating refugees, for example. , on the shoulders of the younger generations. But I assure you, the young people did not wait for you to try every day to pick up the pieces of social cohesion that you have broken. In the European Union, one in four young people took part in an organized volunteering activity in the last 12 months. In France, more than 136,000 young people have taken part in Civic Service since its creation in 2010, particularly after the terrible attacks that struck our country. Dear colleagues, you invoke the word solidarity as one invokes a spirit of another — grave. So go back to the countryside and provinces of your respective countries! You will see that solidarity between neighbors or between fellow citizens did not wait for the great humanisms of the European Union to work and fill in the shortcomings that Brussels has shown for too long.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the initiative of the European Solidarity Corps raises many questions, as we are hearing now. Although we all agree that the idea of the Corps is good, many misunderstandings could have been avoided if the Commission had consulted on its intention in time with youth volunteer organisations. I hope that in the preparation of the legislative decision the Commission is directly cooperating with the youth organisations. Our committees rightly ask how the Corps will be organised and financed. We fundamentally disagree with the notion that the European Solidarity Corps could swallow other European programmes, for example the European Voluntary Service, which has more than 20 years of successful existence. The Commission’s communication is very unclear on this matter. To make the project acceptable for us, it needs fresh money from the budget. It is also not clear how the occupational strand would work: what are the financial links between the ECS and the Youth Guarantee, and will the provided job for young people be a truly rewarding experience? My last question is about whether the Commission has already prepared concrete activities for the more than 25 000 young people who have already signed up to the Corps, in order to prevent their frustration if the Corps does not fulfil their expectations.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, volunteering experiences and mobility offer citizens, especially young people, opportunities to broaden their horizons and grow as a result of new encounters. This not only leads to the development of skills, competences and knowhow but most importantly opens the door to other cultures and different visions of the world. Volunteering can equip people with the necessary skills and attitudes to become active, responsible citizens open to intercultural dialogue, which is much needed in the turbulent times we live in. Volunteering is particularly interesting in a broader context of occupational literacy. I agree, though, that in order to be successful the initiative proposed by the Commission must provide clear objectives and build on existing local grassroots organisations, so a close cooperation with NGOs, civil society and youth workers is needed. Citizenship and solidarity cannot only be piloted centrally, it must happen on the ground. Sport and arts must also be part of this and we must maintain a gender perspective. And we must reach out to the excluded young people as well as refugees and migrants. This, then, would be true solidarity.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I have been a strong, consistent supporter of volunteers and volunteering both before I came to this Parliament and since. So, was I overjoyed when I heard this proposal on the European Solidarity Corps? Initially yes, but there are many serious questions that need to be answered. How can we make a clear distinction between the volunteering and the occupational strands? What criteria do you intend to use, Commissioner? How can we ensure that there are no abuses in the system and that young, energetic, idealistic young Europeans do not find themselves on the fringes of precarious work? Funding is a critical issue but we have no details. The target seems to be 100 000 volunteers. That needs real resources. I agree with you Commissioner, young people will play a key role in promoting and strengthening solidarity. It is crucial that the programme delivers a quality experience for volunteers and the communities they serve. You spoke of many different programmes –LIFE, Erasmus, European Citizens, rural development to name a few – but I need to know where is the coherence? We need that detail. You have used a lot of fine words and your intent is good but I am concerned that this is a rush job. It is not fully thought out and the clear parameters have not been set and sufficient funds are not in place. I want it to succeed but I am concerned that we have not yet put the proper structures in place.

name: Curzio Maltese (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, among the many gimmicks and announcements with which the Juncker Commission seeks to mask its substantial political vacuum, this proposal by the European solidarity corps has at least the merit of having met the enthusiastic response of thousands of young citizensEuropeans.In order not to disappoint these hopes, the Commission must remove many ambiguities and many dangers from this proposal.Colleagues have already talked about it, and I will not repeat: the risk of duplicating, the risk of offering tools for yet another exploitation of youth workers.Finally, it is in no way acceptable for this new body to be financed with Erasmus funds.It is not possible to spread rivers of rhetoric about the wonders of Erasmus and then use the already scarce resources of this program as an ATM to finance more.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - The new initiative to establish a European Solidarity Corps will bring young people additional opportunities and challenges in their integration into society. As it is a pan-European project, it therefore has a special added value. Bringing together young people from different parts of the Union in humanitarian activities that reinforce the values ​​on which the Union is founded is good for it and for each young person individually. Although the initiative holds great promise, I would like to highlight the following: The Commission envisages that a European Solidarity Force will be set up in the first phase with the help of financial and human resources from existing programs, including Erasmus + and the related European Voluntary Service project. has been operating under it for at least twenty years and we have already talked about that today. I therefore share the concern with my colleagues that the integration of the European Solidarity Unit into the Erasmus + program makes it difficult to implement both effectively. Namely, in the recently adopted report on the implementation of the Erasmus + program, which I prepared, I pointed out that the program does not have sufficient funds to finance all its core activities, let alone to fund this project, this initiative as the European Solidarity Unit .

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! I fully appreciate the intentions of the authors of this program, but I have four comments. First thing: finances (my previous speakers have said a lot about it). It cannot be funding that undermines other well-functioning, lacking programs. The second issue: the existence of a local dimension of this program is a great opportunity for less active communities, for people with disabilities, for those who are reluctant to cross-border mobility. But in order to activate these environments, they must be duly rewarded. This cannot be free labor. I was concerned about the sentence the Commissioner said that there would be internships and apprenticeships, some of which would be paid. Does this mean that there will also be free internships and apprenticeships? Another issue is to coordinate this program with other existing programs, for example presenting it on the EURES platform. And the last point: paying attention to the follow-up activities after volunteering so as not to lose its effects.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! The European Solidarity Corps - as everyone has talked about here - is an opportunity for young people through volunteering, internships and work. But I believe it is important that voluntary activities are clearly separated from those involving employment. Organizations involved in the operation of the Corps cannot use young people as free volunteers - as Prof. Łybacka - when good-quality jobs are available. It is also important that the qualifications acquired through volunteering are later recognized in the labor market. An undoubted advantage of the program is the possibility of increasing the mobility of young people and gaining experience necessary for their future work, as well as the development of active citizenship. The program aims to encourage more young people to engage in various solidarity activities. However, it is essential to clearly define the framework - which many colleagues have mentioned here - and the financing of the program, especially as the Commission has already started the initial phase of the implementation of the European Solidarity Corps. The reallocation of funds from well-functioning programs such as Erasmus + or Europe for Citizens is not - as my colleague Zver pointed out - a good solution. The European Solidarity Corps should build on, strengthen and develop existing initiatives, not replace them. It should also be emphasized that the European Voluntary Service is a program with twenty years of experience, which turned out to be a great success. When creating the European Solidarity Corps, we should draw on knowledge and experience from the operation of the European Voluntary Service and ensure that these programs are complementary.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, there are various benefits of such involvement: it can reinforce civic participation, social cohesion, and solidarity. In an EU context, it can also increase a common sense of belonging. But it can also have a strong impact on the volunteers themselves by contributing to their self-fulfilment and their professional development. Considering the level of EU youth unemployment, the suitability of volunteer action to respond to many of our time’s challenges, as well as the need to give visibility to EU engagement, I think the Commission’s initiative would be most welcome. A well-coordinated and adequately financed programme could also enable the spillover of positive examples from countries with longstanding volunteering traditions to ones where such involvement is less developed. The new initiative should be set up and financed in a way so as not to have a negative impact on existing successful tools and programmes, such as Erasmus and the European Voluntary Service.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe needs to think of new ways of meeting the ambitions of its young people. The European Solidarity Corps should constitute a bridge between the world of training and that of work, offering training internships and valuable experiences for those who participate, but it must be thought of well, to avoid abuses of the system. The world of work is dotted with exploitation phenomena masked by training courses, phenomena that feed precariousness, the wage gap and further undermine the confidence of young people in the future of Europe. And this happens particularly frequently in places where youth unemployment is highest. The establishment of the European Solidarity Corps is an important opportunity to structure a transparent European program in step with the times, but we must send a clear message: Europe is on the side of its young people and the problem of employment and fair distribution of work is the top priority.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, encouraging solidarity is important for building responsible societies that care for their most vulnerable.Without solidarity there is no social cohesion, no civic and national consciousness, and ultimately no preservation of our Christian civilization of which it is one of the foundations.There is a positive intention behind the establishment of the European Solidarity Force.I have no doubt about that, but it seems to me that in this case the performance will be sloppy.The question is whether we need solidarity forces as a separate program or whether they could fit into one of the already existing programs, such as the European Voluntary Service.We must take care that the new program, if it is really needed, is not an additional burden for taxpayers.The Commission seems to understand this, but it wants to take money from quality programs like Erasmus.That's not good.There are enough ineffective programs that can be abolished, instead of depriving those of added value.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, during this debate I remembered my youth.I remembered the youth work actions we had in Croatia, which were in the whole of Yugoslavia at the time.I threatened that enthusiasm and will, regardless of ideology, and the friendships that exist among young people who are different and who came from different parts of the then state.I see this as an opportunity for young people in the European Union to get to know themselves, get to know their loved ones, get to know the value of solidarity, the value of friendship and therefore support it, despite some contradictions, but I expect synergies with all other programs.that this program will therefore succeed.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, talking about volunteering and the European Solidarity Corps is undoubtedly something positive. Who can say otherwise? However, I cannot fail to note the existence of a great veil of hypocrisy in dealing with these issues, as well as a profound disconnect from reality, especially when I think of the living conditions of millions of European citizens, especially in the south. In the resolution, for example, the principle of solidarity is solemnly sanctioned, which means sharing of advantages and disadvantages, and the aim is to create a sense of community, solidarity and social responsibility. These are beautiful words but denied by what happened in the recent past, and by what continues to happen today, in southern Europe. I have not forgotten what happened to Greece, crushed by the troika's impositions, nor the alarming figures regarding youth unemployment and the at-risk-of-poverty rate, which is 17%. There are an estimated 40 million poor people in Europe. Volunteering is certainly a noble activity, but our task ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Mr President, the idea of ​​creating a European Solidarity Body is positive and seems to satisfy the desire of young people to contribute to society as a whole, but at the same time to have the conditions that will allow them to find a decent job in the future. But for this initiative to be successful, it must be based on a real interest in young people. As you know, throughout Europe and especially in Greece, which is affected by the memoranda, the unemployment of the young unemployed is at a very high level. This creation of the Solidarity Body is a given that will attract the interest of young people. That interest, however, must not be exploited. We must enable young people to acquire qualifications that will help them in their later careers and not fall victim to a requirement to find workers who will work on starvation wages just because they need to work.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President.Commissioner, I think you have seen from the debates so far that no one is criticizing the initiative.I support it too, the initiative is very good, but the question comes at the right time: why do you launch an initiative that you do not explain, do not budget, do not explain where the money comes from, do not evaluate, do not say how you will evaluate this, because it is an investment and, in the end, we have to get something out of any investment.It is excluded to take from other programs, because if you have money for bread in one pocket and you move it in the other pocket, you cannot take meat, you have as much money.Here we must clarify: if we do not budget, it is a dead initiative.And I want to ask you, concretely, what is the budget?What are the allocation criteria?How do you distribute them by country, that you said you supplement the national budgets and how do you do the evaluation?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Mr President, when the idea of ​​setting up a European Solidarity Body was announced, there was a lot of talk, a lot of words: that it would enhance social cohesion, that there would be a sense of belonging with young people, that the concept of European citizenship would be strengthened. , that there will be solidarity in practice, that there will be an offer to society as a whole and that it was essentially an act of volunteerism and altruism. So we see that there are 25,000 volunteers. And suddenly we discover that this is a system with which some people will find work. This now appears in the discussion. After all, it is one thing for the European Solidarity Corps to have a specific direction for young people who want to help and participate, and it is another thing for employment programs. These belong to Erasmus. Bilingualism must stop, please.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Mr President. The European Solidarity Corps is an important initiative for young people in Europe. In fact, young people are the most pro-European citizens of the European Union. That is why it is important, especially in the context of discussions on the future of Europe, to develop such programs that once again show the benefits of a united Europe. But I must say that I know a lot of young people who have applied for this program and their expectations, Commissioner, are very high. We need to provide the young people participating in the program with the necessary support and support for quality experiences. Volunteering and the exchange of experience must not become a source of abuse and limitations of social rights. We need to have adequate and specific funding, and I am in the Committee on Budgets and I have not noticed it, to recognize training through recognized labor market certificates, to coordinate with other European programs, to increase access to the program for young people from all over. environments. It is important to make this program a success. We must not stop at the bureaucracy, but it must be very clear what we propose to young people, so as not to disappoint them. Thanks.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the launch of the Commission’s registration platform for potential young volunteers has spurred a tremendous amount of interest among young Europeans, including in my country, Romania. Yet this initiative could quickly turn into general frustration if the Commission does not present a convincing and sustainable approach soon. In view of the high number of registrations, the Commission needs to make sure that sufficient funding is dedicated to the initiative and that all stakeholders are sufficiently involved in the development and implementation of the European Solidarity Corps. We cannot reallocate funds from priority programmes, such as Erasmus+, often lacking sufficient resources to finance new policy initiatives. We need fresh money, and we cannot create a new initiative which goes against well—established and well—functioning programmes.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I really appreciate this very fruitful exchange of ideas and let me first thank you for the support, the broad support, you have shown for the general objectives of the European Solidarity Corps. If we do it well the European Solidarity Corps can contribute to both European economic growth and the stability of European societies, because the volunteering part of the European Solidarity Corps can give the experience of living in a community for young people and working for the public good at the same time. And I think it is a very important issue from the point of view of stability of society, of the future society. On the other hand the occupational side, the occupation pillar, can contribute to the employability of young people, the employability which is probably the most important virtue, the most important skill, for young people to get a proper job on the labour market in the future. So we really take it seriously, and that is why I appreciate all of your concerns, all of your feedback and all of your opinions because we will put it into the construction of the European Solidarity Corps. But beyond the broad consensus let me address some of your concerns as well. First the funding, because definitely this is the most sensitive issue of the project. During this phase of implementation the European Voluntary Service funding was increased from EUR 62 million to EUR 89 million, out of which we estimate that EUR 58 million will be used for activities which fall within the scope of the European Solidarity Corps. The Commission continues funding Erasmus+ activities as foreseen in its legal base and financial programming, so no change in that. In other words, funding for volunteering has increased while there are no negative effects on Erasmus+ activities. Regarding the second phase covering the period 2018-2020 discussions on the appropriate funding for the new legislative proposal are still ongoing. Let me thank Ms Žitňanská for her concerns on the accessibility of the portal. We are working on a more accessible format of the portal, because it is our personal mission as well to make it accessible for handicapped and fortunate people as well. I agree with Ms Grapini’s remarks. Yes, I think the European Solidarity Corps is really an investment, an investment in the future, and that is why we would like to do it very well. Actually it is happening, the first action of deployment happened last week. So the European Solidarity Corps is already in operation. However, we know that we have to improve in the future to make it more efficient. The second sensitive issue is the difference between the European Solidarity Corps and the European Voluntary Service. The difference at the moment is mostly procedural. The European Solidarity Corps is needs-driven and builds on the synergies of the programmes involved. Most importantly it will offer new opportunities that do not yet exist under the current programmes. It offers a single, easily accessible entry point through the European Solidarity Corps portal and aims at the widest possible outreach to participating organisations and the young people involved. It will also develop an enhanced training, available before a placement, and recognition of learning outcomes after placement. Basically the European Solidarity Corps will not compete with national volunteering schemes. The European Solidarity Corps will enhance what is already on offer at national level, adding opportunities that were not available before. In this sense it complements national schemes and creates new synergies with them. And, last but not least, the application procedure will be easier in the European Solidarity Corps portal and that is why it will be more accessible for young people, hopefully for handicapped people as well. So thank you once again for your feedback, for your support and for your opinions and I am really looking forward to working with you in the future as well on this project.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Solidarity Corps (ESC) is a welcome and timely initiative. It is not only designed to complement and build synergies with other youth engagement and employment programmes. First of all, we have to catch the special nature of this programme as important promoter of European spirit, solidarity and citizenship. The future legal EU framework should prevent ESC becoming a mere substitute to creating jobs, or a sort of auxiliary to the European Voluntary Service. ESC should perform the role of a European civic service, engaged in public, private and NGO sector. Before launching the ESC on the large scale, the Commission has to come forward with a clear legal basis, also taking into account the views of youth organisations, networks and voluntary organisations. We have to ensure that young people who sign up to ESC will know about their rights and obligations, that their certificates would be globally recognised across Europe. The ESC’s goal should be to reach out, as much is possible, to all young people, targeting especially vulnerable young people. In parallel, we must do our utmost to prevent both unnecessary bureaucracy as well as obstacles presented by national boundaries. I encourage the Commission to come forward with solid legislative proposal, including a solution for sustainable funding.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – There is no doubt that the EU and its Member States need more solidarity particularly in the wake of financial and refugee crises that hit Europe. Namely in this context, the setting up of a European Solidarity Corps (ESC) has been seen by many politicians and analysts as the right initiative that will put into practice EU values of solidarity. This is so because the ESC aims to create opportunities for young people to volunteer or work in projects in their own country or abroad that benefit communities and people around Europe. Nevertheless, the ESC should not replace existing, successful initiatives like the European Voluntary Service (EVS) but rather, to reinforce and complement them. Expressed in other words, the ESC should avoid duplication or replacement of existing programmes and tools. In addition, I would like to stress that the ESC should ensure that volunteering, despite the fact that can provide valuable experience, will not replace paid forms of employment. I warmly welcome the intention of the ESC to spread solidarity among young Europeans (particularly young generations) but we should bear in mind that our prime goal is to create sustainable long—term employment opportunities for many unemployed young Europeans, the EU’s lost generation.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - The European Solidarity Corps (ETUC) aims to help young Europeans to develop their skills and to get a job. At first glance, this is a healthy project that would be difficult to oppose! However, this CES project was born in the context of the migration crisis and has very different objectives, such as constituting an opportunity for marginalized communities (understanding migrants), or even developing Juncker's federalist spirit among young people. In addition, the ESC contains several risks to which the Commission has not been able to provide satisfactory answers. On the one hand, (unpaid) volunteers run the risk of eventually replacing trainees and apprentices, thus developing the precariousness of young people. On the other hand, even though there are several programs such as Erasmus + and the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI), the ESC risks complicating this whole rather than rationalizing it. Thus, more than a tool to fight against youth unemployment, it is a tool of Europeanist propaganda, which we cannot support. This project aims to give the CES a legal framework, as well as its own budget. We oppose it.
