name: Daniel Caspary
text: Author. - Madam President, esteemed Commissioner! Every one of us MEPs is familiar with the situation where you put a question to the Commission for a written answer and only get a very questionable or poor answer. There are certainly cases where the Commission cannot answer because it simply does not have information or the Member States do not provide it. But there are answers where the Commission is holding us off because it is examining something and saying: We are still in an examination procedure and we still need something before the answer comes. But then there is usually no answer. There are cases where the Commission does not want to answer. To be honest, I can sometimes understand that because there are a lot of colleagues who make borderline inquiries. We should continue to think about this here in the house. But there are also questions where the Commission does not want to give an answer, for whatever reason - in case of doubt, because it wants to hide something from us. We have already introduced many, many restrictions here in the European Parliament for ourselves as MEPs in order to encourage the Commission to improve its answers in return: We reduced the number, we then reduced the number again, we have the number of words in the Queries reduced, you can only ask three sub-questions. So we in Parliament have certainly made our contribution. And that's why today's debate should only be a small sign. We only have a very short debate, we deliberately do not have a resolution, but we want to remind the Commission that the quality should please improve. We have a countermovement that is growing. The last time we changed the Rules of Procedure here in this House, we introduced a small and a large question to the Commission. That was a matter from the middle of the MPs because we just do it a lot are dissatisfied.So my request is really to change your practice and keep trying to improve the answer.We would be specifically interested in the following - here today 246 MEPs tabled this question together: Firstly: What exact conditions and restrictions has the Commission imposed on itself, and how does it justify the often non-existent substantial content?Second, on what legal basis were these requirements introduced and what level did this decision take?Thirdly, does the Commission want to change the way in which it is answered so that more detailed and better answers can be expected?

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission takes its replies to Parliamentary questions seriously. Today’s oral question was added to the agenda at such short notice, making it difficult to give a complete response to the issues you raised. Nevertheless, I am able to make a few remarks in response. As a sign of the importance that the Commission attaches to these matters, President Juncker wrote recently, on 13 March, to President Tajani on this very subject. In his letter the President said, once again, that the Commission, under his leadership, has been committed from the start to filling with new life the special partnership with the European Parliament as laid down in the framework agreement of 2010. Only together can we change and renew Europe and regain citizens’ trust in the European Project. Replies to written questions are an integral part of our close relations. The Commission sees them as an important democratic scrutiny tool, which must be given due consideration. Over the last two years, measures have been taken by both institutions to improve the system of written questions and answers. The Commission welcomes the European Parliament’s efforts to set a maximum number of written questions to be tabled by Members of the European Parliament. This is appreciated by the Commission in a spirit of cooperation between the two institutions. The Commission makes every effort to reply in good time and to provide high-quality and politically-pertinent replies. The success of these efforts depends also on the quality of the questions. In 2016 the Commission replied to more than 9 500 written questions. An average of 40 replies a day was transmitted to the European Parliament throughout last year. It is important to recall that, according to Article 230 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Parliamentary questions are to be answered by the European Commission and thus by the College, and not by individual Commissioners. This is why each reply is subject to wide internal consultation and agreed by the Commission through a collegial process, in order to enhance the quality and political relevance. It is in this context that the Commission has chosen to set an indicative limit to the length of replies in order to facilitate the smooth operation of the process and to avoid disproportionate costs arising. Derogations from this limit are made where necessary. President Juncker has asked all Members of the College to pay the utmost importance to the replies to written questions of the Members of the European Parliament, to discuss the answers amongst Members to avoid silo approaches, and to give political answers to political questions. The Commission is ready to join forces with you to ensure that the limitation in the number of questions is matched with high-quality replies. The Treaty does not set out any deadlines for replies, but the Commission makes all reasonable efforts to reply to written questions in good time and, wherever possible, within the target dates that Parliament has requested. New efforts have been made in recent months to reduce the numbers of replies delivered after these targets, and these are already bearing fruit. In this context, the Secretariat-General of the Commission is in contact with the Secretariat-General of the European Parliament to work together to further improve the mutual performance of our institutions. In this context I can inform you that a meeting between the responsible Deputy Secretaries-General of the two institutions in planned already for next week.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner. In your native language and in my native language, I will now take advantage of these few seconds. I accept what you said, I have no objection to you reconsidering the situation and trying to give the most correct answers, but you had one sentence, and I would very much like to take that for political answers to political questions. Well, that's exactly what I was missing. We on the part of Parliament have already done so, we really have very few questions, I think that nine thousand seems like a lot to you, perhaps less than the Commission's capacity. But yes, when a Member asks what he is asking, he wants to give a political answer that he can show his constituents, or in any medium, that this is the position of the European Commission. Their answer to the vast majority of questions at the moment is still just that: we’ll see. This is not going to go much.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, Mr Navracsics, the issue we are discussing is very serious. First of all, I have repeatedly protested in this Chamber, because there is a reduction in the number of questions that MEPs can ask. You know, one of the key aspects of the functioning of this Parliament is to ask parliamentary questions, because our role is to vote, but also to control the executive, to control you as a Commission. So the fact that you answer 9,000 questions tells me nothing. You have to answer questions because you act, because you make decisions, because you use a lot of resources. This is the first. The second is that when you give some answers, most of them are vague, they do not answer on the subject, "throw the ball on the podium", as we say. So you have to be much clearer, give answers, tackle the issues and see the questions as an opportunity to improve your own work, to improve the performance of the Commission itself.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Honorable Commissioner, I have managed to ask 519 questions to the Commission so far.I completely agree with you that the system needs to change and it is not the quantity of the question that matters, but the quality of the question, and even more important is the quality of the answer.I asked 518 specific questions.I got mostly general answers to them.I didn’t ask too many political questions because I was less interested in it.I generally know the Commission's political views on the main topics, but I have asked specific questions to which I have received general answers.To one question, about what the Commission is doing to protect the interests of the European Union and the Member States when it comes to space and the moon, I was given a counter-question.Very frivolous!I think we really need to change the way we answer our questions.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the question that brings us here today, that is, the questions that we can ask the European Commission, is one of the few ways that European citizens are able to contact the European Commission through of us, its representatives, MEPs and MEPs. I believe that it is not serious to say that it depends on the quality of the question, because it is often the citizens who are able to identify the problems of non-application of Community legislation, for example on the environment, and we are its spokespeople. What the Commission often does is to say that it has nothing to add, that it is not your responsibility, that it is not your fault. To the only ways it takes the trouble to truly respond, it rarely adds anything to what we already knew. I mean, Commissioner, that this is a question of profound democratic importance, because the democratic deficit that we have between citizens and the Commission is also measured by the quality of the European Commission's responses to its citizens, via MEPs and MEPs and in that sense, Commissioner, it is not a freight, it is a democratic obligation that you must take very, very seriously.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I am going to give you an example of a question about the Contact Center sector in Spain, in which we suggested that this sector abuses temporary hiring and the transmission of activity between different subcontractors, and that these circumstances fail to comply Directives 1999/70 / CE and 2001/23 / CE. We ask the Commission if it will investigate these cases and if it will take measures to force the Spanish State to comply with European legislation. The answer is that the Commission will contact the Spanish authorities. As you can see, an answer that says nothing and is useless. The problem with not taking parliamentary questions seriously is that they reduce to absurdity one of this Parliament's tools for obtaining information and for responding to the citizens we represent. Behind each of these questions there is not only a work of legal and juridical foundation, but there is work with social organizations, with trade unions, with citizen associations that are, in many cases, in a situation of abuse and violation and violation of their rights, and we try to use them to represent them. Not taking them seriously is not taking European citizenship seriously.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Madam President, my apologies for being late in the Chamber. I just wanted to support the question that has been put down this afternoon because when many of us ask questions of the Commission or the Council, I get the impression that they sometimes think we are just doing it out of badness or just to make some political point, whereas often what we are trying to do is genuinely seek information and perhaps forward some useful political process. On a number of occasions I have put down questions and I have either had a delay, or when I have had a reply it has been a thoroughly inadequate response. For example, in December I put down a question about the negotiations going on in Cyprus and asking what sort of helpful role could the Council and Commission be playing in those negotiations, and it was not until February that I got a reply and it told me absolutely nothing at all, so I do think we need to seriously look at this issue.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, written questions are a valuable tool for doing the job of representing our constituents when they want us to represent them in this place on issues which are affecting them, and they are one of the few ways that we can hold the Commission to account and ensure proper democratic scrutiny, and one of the few ways that we can gain information about the huge areas of responsibility of the European Commission. But it seems sometimes that when answers would be embarrassing to the Commission we do not get answers that fully respond to the question, if we get answers at all. Parliament has already limited the number of questions that we can ask. It seems that the movement is all in one direction, but the system here is not working. It goes to the heart, in my view, of the distinction between an elected body and an unelected body and the principles of democratic scrutiny and transparency and that, sadly, in the EU institutions is so often a major failing.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable members, thank you for this short discussion. I have taken note of your concerns and observations. I think that there is a general consensus and nobody would put it into question that it is one of the fundamental rights of the Members of the European Parliament to question the European Commission, and it is one of the obligations of the European Commission and the Members of the European Commission to answer those questions. It is an non-waivable right, no hesitation and no question in that respect. Let me refer to one issue raised in your interventions and that is the vagueness of the replies of the European Commission. I think there are two reasons for that. One is a political reason, and I agree with my fellow countryman Mr Szanyi that the European Commission is a political body – and this is the self-definition of the European Commission, that it is a political Commission – so if it is a political Commission it needs to give political answers. I agree, but let us not mix up political answers with party political answers or partisan answers, because the European Commission is not only a political body, but it is a political body of four political groups, representatives of four political groups and 28 Member States, or Commissioners sent from 28 Member States. We cannot afford to be party political or partisan. We give political answers but they are not party political answers. The second reason for the so-called vagueness might be the limits of the competences of the European Commission. Sometimes our answers go beyond the real competences of the European Commission. So we must be vague because it is not in our competence to answer concretely those questions. If there are other examples of vagueness, I really apologise for that. We would like to improve the quality of the replies and I hope that we can improve the close relations between the two institutions and the meeting of the Deputy Secretaries-General will help in improving this cooperation.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: author. – Madam President, I am very glad that we are having this debate now in plenary with the European Commission on such a vital human rights issue. A lot has already been said about the magnitude of these rights violations and about the relevance of the topic. Trafficking in human beings needs to be addressed with a human rights-based and victim-centred approach. Victims and vulnerable populations need to be put at the centre of all efforts. The prevention of trafficking in human beings and the protection of its victims must be our priority goal. Access to justice, support measures, shelter and education needs to be ensured, independent of the victims’ willingness to cooperate in criminal proceedings. The principle of non-criminalisation in this regard is also vital and needs to be implemented in all Member States. Further, demand needs to be tackled as it can be considered a root cause. Accountability needs to be ensured for both offenders, as well as knowing users. For the new strategy, I think that financial investigations and action against money laundering need to play a bigger part in fighting trafficking in human beings and to ensure that confiscated assets are used to support and compensate victims of trafficking. Does the Commission agree on this, and how does it intend to address this in the new strategy? I am also worried about the trend of trafficking in human beings being mixed up with other legally distinct concepts such as migrant smuggling, increasingly addressing trafficking in human beings through a security lens, for instance in the context of recent migration policies. How will the Commission counter this trend in its new strategy? I also call for greater internal/external coherence in the fight against trafficking in human beings and to further enhance and deepen cooperation and coordination among all relevant actors. Finally, what exactly is the timeline for the adoption of the new strategy?

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα
text: Author. - Madam President, how much is human dignity worth? For the Commission, very cheap! It's too late to take it for granted: to protect fundamental values ​​and rights in practice! "Trafficking" is the most growing crime in the world. It is modern slavery with over 30 million victims, of whom 5.5 million are children. And it has many forms: prostitution, forced labor, forced begging, the trade of babies and organs ... that is where we became today. Yes, we have a pretty good anti-trafficking directive. But why does it have poor results? Because the strategies planned by the Commission are contradictory. How does the Union deal with traffickers? Blocking legal immigration routes? But that's pushing people into the arms of illegal networks. Closed borders are a treasure trove for traffickers and you are all complicit in that. How will the Union prevent gender-based violence? Delayed to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention? That is why I am proposing a viable anti-trafficking strategy. What does sustainable mean? I mean focusing on reducing poverty and high inequality. Because, for the Left, they have always been the sources of human trafficking. Yes to more funds to inform and support victims. Yes to stricter penalties for "customers". First of all, we need to coordinate European policies against inequality and poverty, so that man is not a commodity with an expiration date, colleagues.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: author. – Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union has built a tremendously-respected process of fighting human trafficking and protecting its victims. It is six years since the Anti-Trafficking Directive came into force. It is held up globally as the gold standard for its gender-specific and victim-centred approach. But new challenges are emerging, and the number of trafficked people continues to rise. The nature of this crime makes it hard, but not impossible, for authorities to obtain data and identify victims. It is therefore absolutely essential that we allocate EU funding in an effective, evidence-based system to address sexual exploitation and invest in prevention. Human trafficking is a high-profit crime. We need to know who buys and who profits. It is also vital that trafficked individuals are seen as victims, not criminals, and helped to recover. Europe can and must do more. Human trafficking is still a threat and feeds on poverty. However, only ten Member States have so far established using a victim of trafficking as a criminal offence. Commissioner, this House demands that we continue our efforts to stop impunity and make prosecution of traffickers and their users our biggest priority. Although most victims or are of European origin, the refugee crisis is feeding the supply, especially the thousands of unaccompanied, vulnerable minors. We have made progress in the EU but we need to plan the next stage. Without action and funding we will slip backwards, and that is why we ask the Commission to publish its new strategy now. We – but more importantly, the victims – cannot wait. Human trafficking is happening now in Europe, where we all live, and we must open our eyes and continue the Commission’s work on addressing human trafficking.

name: Anna Hedh
text: Author. - Madam President! The anti-trafficking directive adopted in 2011 was an important step in the fight against human trafficking. Among other things, the directive took a broad approach to human trafficking, with measures for prevention, definition of the crime of human trafficking itself, penalties for perpetrators and combating demand. In addition to the legislation, an EU strategy was also adopted in 2012. But despite all the measures, human trafficking continues. Hundreds of thousands of people in Europe are forced to work under slave-like conditions. About three quarters of the victims of human trafficking are sex slaves. Trafficking in human beings is still one of the most lucrative and least risky crimes one can engage in. I am therefore pleased that today we have the opportunity to ask the Commission questions about the fight against trafficking in human beings. Today there are two things that make me worried and upset. The first is that the Commission has not yet presented a new strategy against trafficking in human beings. The other thing that upsets me is the lack of action by Member States to combat demand. Article 18 (4) of the Directive makes it optional for Member States to criminalize the exploitation of victims of trafficking in human beings. Only ten Member States have chosen to do so, and only two Member States have reported on alternative measures taken to combat demand. This is deplorable and completely contrary to the commitment in the directive. I would therefore like to ask the Commission the following questions. 1: When will a new strategy come? 2: What other measures are planned on the basis of the two implementing reports on the directive against trafficking in human beings? Will the Commission present new legislation, and if not, why?

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt
text: author. – Madam President, trafficking in human beings is a slavery of our time. Figures are shocking and behind every story there is a human tragedy. Most victims are women and girls, exploited for prostitution in Europe and more and more are migrants and more and more are abused online. Trafficking is serious organised crime and should be prosecuted as such. It is a huge business industry with high profit and low risk. It is time to stop impunity and to ensure convictions. There should be no hiding places for traffickers in Europe and neighbouring countries. From the Urals through the Balkans, to the Black Sea, from Niger through the desert and the Mediterranean, actors are cross-border and sophisticated. Concerted action with third countries is necessary. We should step up our European response on all fronts. More police and judicial cooperation, including with Europol and Eurojust, better sharing of information, an operational role for the Asylum Support Office and Frontex, tracking the money, confiscating the assets of both traffickers and agents through the legal chain such as transport and accommodation providers. Member States should also reduce demand and criminalise the users of sex services. I welcome that Member States have finally transposed the directive but, as colleagues have said, much more needs to be done to implement it properly, in particular training of officials, access to health care, and sexual productive rights. Victims should receive unconditional assistance and psychological support. Madam President, many unaccompanied minors that disappear in Europe are exposed to trafficking and abuse. Members have to do more for missing children and ensure that they enter the protection system. I do fully support the anti-trafficking coordinator and in particular her call to focus more on child victims. Commissioner, I urge you to present this year the new strategy on anti-trafficking, taking into account, and I finish on this Madam President, Parliament’s recommendation including a gender perspective and external direction, and the European People’s Party will continue to support you, and be committed to zero tolerance against trafficking.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by expressing my thanks to all of you for this opportunity to discuss with you the very important and sensitive issue of trafficking in human beings. The European Parliament has been a strong and consistent supporter of our efforts to deal with this odious and appalling crime. It is a crime that takes advantage of the vulnerability and exploits the desperation of people in need of protection and support. As you know, trafficking was and remains a priority for us as reflected both in the European Agenda on Migration and in the European Agenda on Security. Europe has globally a leading role in this field. We have developed a coherent and coordinated legal and policy framework to address trafficking in human beings. The Anti-Trafficking Directive and the 2012-2016 EU strategy has been our main instruments to develop, coordinate and implement our policy framework priorities. Having delivered on the vast majority of actions envisaged in this strategy we do not feel that our job is done; quite the opposite. We cannot accept that irrespective of origin there are still and unfortunately more children, women, vulnerable people trafficked, abused and exploited. These are victims of the immoral and inhuman profit-making face of our societies. Now that the 2012-2016 strategy has come to an end the time has come to step up our efforts and continue delivering more intensively and in a more focused way. To this end the support and contribution of this House, of all of you, is of utmost importance. The migration crisis and transnational security threats render people more vulnerable to criminal networks and exploitation. That is why more needs to be done to target the organised criminal networks and follow their money throughout the trafficking chain, to focus more on prevention and on better identification and protection of victims, to further strengthen coordination at EU level and to ensure more coherence in the external and internal dimensions of our anti-trafficking policy. Criminal networks target and exploit the most vulnerable. Recent data indicate that the vast majority of victims are female and children. The most widespread form of exploitation is sexual exploitation, with mainly women and young girls as victims. That is why the Anti-Trafficking Directive has a strong gender-specific dimension, and that is why we have also commissioned a study on the gender dimensions of trafficking in human beings. It is also of major importance to increase our cooperation with third countries and further streamline our anti-trafficking priorities in the external dimension of our policies. The two distinct notions of trafficking and smuggling are often confused. However, it is not only a matter of the correct use of terminology. It is also about ensuring a victim-centred and human rights based approach. Allow me to clarify here that smuggling is a cross-border activity while trafficking can also take place within the borders of a state. In smuggling there is consent of the smuggled person while in trafficking there is not. The exploitation of the vulnerable victim for profit making is an essential element in trafficking. These differences bear significant implications for the rights of the victims of trafficking and the respective obligations of Member States. I would like to assure you that the respective EU legislative frameworks on smuggling and trafficking will remain clear and constant in any future policy initiative. Regarding now the two reports based on the Anti-Trafficking Directive presented by the Commission last December we will continue to proactively monitor the situation in the Member States and examine potential options. To conclude, and as far as our next steps are concerned, we are currently taking stock of the experience and achievements of the current strategy, examining trends and problems and assessing and discussing with stakeholders what future actions from all the different policy areas are needed. Our aim is to address the challenges created by the changing socio-political context. But we also want to maintain a coordinated, coherent and constant approach in the continuation of the efforts to fight this extremely pernicious but highly lucrative form of crime. The reflections and contributions of this House are of great importance for our work and I am looking forward with particular interest to our discussion today.

name: Alessandra Mussolini
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the Commission's commitment to this very serious issue. I heard colleagues say, rightly: "women and minors, who are vulnerable people". No, women are not vulnerable: they are made vulnerable by the men, by the criminal networks that sell them. Among other things, 80% of minors are female and the other 20% male. So it's a huge problem, a problem connected to other factors as well, not just the prostitution factor. I would like to introduce another theme: almost no one talks about it, it is almost a taboo, but as far as minors are concerned, there is really a real danger, even for minors who disappear - we have mentioned unaccompanied foreign minors - of organ trafficking. . We took care of it: when I was chairman of the Senate Committee on Childhood and Adolescence, we spoke to the Minister of the Interior on this issue in Italy. So everything you can and should do is important. Economic commitment: they are often exploited people; they arrive, when they are sold, that they have already suffered unprecedented abuse and violence. They are in economic weakness: still very often women, even in the family, have an economic weakness compared to men. We have to fight on this too. The last thing is linked - it seems unrelated, but it is linked: we also fight for the equal treatment of women with men: this too is enslavement.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, trafficking in human beings is a violation of fundamental human rights. As already mentioned, the European Parliament, together with the Council, has long ago adopted a directive which aims to tackle and solve the problem through a multilateral approach, not only in order to suppress trafficking in human beings, but also to prevent it and to guarantee protection for victims of such abuse. You see, dear Commissioner, we agree with you on the description of the problem; where we are not is on the prescription. As you know, not all Member States have completed the complete transformation of the directive and this terrible abuse continues to persist even within our borders. And therefore the task we have before us is very clear: that of rapidly preparing a new strategy that is much more effective and capable of tackling this dramatic problem, fully safeguarding human rights and the dignity of people.

name: Arne Gericke
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos! Human trafficking is a multi-billion dollar, inhuman and incredibly filthy crime. Anyone who is involved on any level - and there are many - deserves severe punishment and no mercy. I am convinced that as the European Union, as a Union of Values, we must resolutely fight this fight against human trafficking of any kind. This heinous crime affects around 21 million poor women, children and expectant mothers every year. They are all abused for forced labor or sexual exploitation. Let's not turn a blind eye to this, let's fight forced prostitution now and promote the Nordic model. Let us protect our children, especially the children of refugee families, here in Europe. Let's do everything technically possible across borders to find kidnapped children and give them home and security again. We need to have a clear voice here. We also condemn and forbid surrogacy as sexual exploitation, as a new form of slavery, as the European Parliament and the Council of Europe unequivocally demand. Commissioner, do you agree with me on these concerns?

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President! Being reduced to a commodity is among the most abominable things a human being can be exposed to. In the EU, 61 percent of identified traffic victim victims come from an EU country. 96 percent of them are girls and women who are sexually exploited. Over the past year, we have also received information from Europol about thousands of unaccompanied refugee children who have disappeared without a trace. Instead of receiving protection and new opportunities for life, they have ended up in the clutches of unscrupulous human traffickers and are sexually exploited or work under slave-like conditions. In the EU. This is disgusting. Now we need to make sure we come up with a new future strategy that is effective and actually works in reality. Cross-border crime must be fought across borders. And we must adopt this new revised strategy based precisely on the exchange of information between countries. That must be the main point. And remember: man is never a commodity and it is our responsibility to break this.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, I think it is a good time for us to analyze how our instruments to combat trafficking in human beings are working and, above all, how we are covering all the dimensions of this phenomenon that is absolutely disgusting and that it affects our societies. I want to recall an essential point of article 1 of Directive 2011/36 / EU, which establishes that the gender perspective must be taken into account and the prevention of this crime and the protection of victims, and that gender perspective must be reinforced, sir. Commissioner, it must be taken into account in many of its facets when drawing up the new Strategy. In the last Strategy it was already mentioned in some questions, but I would like to reinforce others, taking into account that - as is well known and many of the participants have said - 75% are women and girls, 96% of whom are victims of sexual exploitation. We need a gender dimension in the entire process of identifying the victim of trafficking. That is very, very important, and also that, in all the instruments of support to the victims, there is that gender dimension that can be accompanied. And then there is also another question that is very important. Obviously, we have many instruments in different dimensions and we must guarantee a certain coherence of that gender dimension in how the Europol, Eurojust agencies coordinate or, also, for example, in how other strategies - such as the European Union Security Strategy - they incorporate that issue. Therefore, we urge you to analyze and make a deeper application of the instruments that we have, and that this gender dimension be taken into account in all its characteristics.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, trafficking in human beings is on the rise and criminals are using the EU as a springboard for exacerbating this crime. New evidence from the UK National Crime Agency shows that criminals from former overseas territories of Member States are taking advantage of gaining EU citizenship and creating child-trafficking routes between those territories to the UK or the EU. An example of this is non-EU nationals who become naturalised as Portuguese citizens and are using Portuguese identity documents to set up bank accounts. This allows them to receive payments from former Portuguese territories such as Angola. They are scouting for their victims. The UK’s decision to withdraw from the EU will allow our national government to end the free movement of people, resulting in the return of UK control over UK borders. Criminal background checks and preventive measures will significantly help combat trafficking in human beings and sexual and labour exploitation, ensuring better protection for UK citizens.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, one of the most convincing definitions, also from a legal point of view, of trafficking in human beings is included in the Additional Protocol of the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime, well known as the "Palermo Protocol", which outlines its characterizing elements, that is, the threat or use of force or other forms of coercion to recruit people in order to exploit them. Today, with regard to trafficking from Africa, there is a strong emergency certainly from the west, but also from the Horn of Africa. Everything that has been underlined is evident, namely the risk that these trafficking particularly involve weak people, especially minors. But there is one aspect that seems to me to have been little emphasized, even in the commissioner's response, and which results from the data collected by the International Organization for Migration (IOM), which shows a worrying reality, as more than 70% of migrants in transit from North Africa to Europe are victims of trafficking, organ trafficking and other forms of exploitation. This is a reality that we have denounced several times, but where is Europe at? Did you realize that your immigration policy, of hypocritical open doors, these senseless policies, actually favor these trafficking? And so it is useless for us to debate these things here when nothing is done to close the borders to traffickers and relies on certain NGOs financed by Soros the pro-immigrant and pro-migrant intervention, who knows under what conditions, and then entrusts the Turkey, perhaps, migrants who wanted to reach Europe from other parts. Nice result!

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Madam President, trafficking in human beings is a modern form of slavery. It is a heinous crime which humiliates the personality and dignity of man, because it treats him as an object for profit. Its victims are young women who are forced into prostitution and children who are either used in forced labor under miserable conditions or have their organs removed and trafficked. Particularly easy victims are women and children who enter illegally and uncontrollably as illegal immigrants in the countries of entry, Greece and Italy. Unfortunately, because the profits from this illegal activity can easily be channeled into seemingly legitimate activities, it is not easy for states to tackle this crime. Nevertheless, the states of the European Union must work together and enact strict laws in order to combat this unacceptable phenomenon. A key condition for this effort to be successful is strict border control. I inform you that, when the borders of Greece were guarded by the Greek Armed Forces, the Greek Police and the Greek Coast Guard, the illegal trafficking of people was almost zero. From the moment this serious work was undertaken by failed bureaucratic organizations such as Frontex and the European Coast Guard and Border Guard, we have this chaos, which you all know exists, unfortunately.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, trafficking in human beings, for criminal purposes, affects every country in the world. Sexual exploitation, forced labor, domestic servitude, child begging or organ removal and more. According to Europol, it is a transversal and capital crime; 65% of drug traffickers participate in human trafficking at the same time and, in many cases, use it as a means of payment. Traffickers take advantage of the fragility of the victims and make fraudulent use of travel documents, even abusing legal channels such as tourist, study or work visas. In many cases, victims have to use fraudulent documents to hide their true identity and age. Taking into account that the fight against this scourge is a priority for the Union, as has been collected by SOCTA, and in the new political cycle given the announcement of the revision of the Union's Strategy, I consider it essential that the Commission strengthen the mechanisms for the detection, protection and assistance of potential victims; that minors be granted special protection; that a comprehensive response be given including mechanisms and protocols for cooperation between police, judicial, asylum and labor authorities - labor inspectors -, in turn promoting cooperation between the Union, the Member States, Europol and Eurojust and third parties countries in question, accelerating the interoperability of Eurodac systems. Also intensive monitoring on the internet - the Europol UNCI must be revitalized - and the penal codes being much tougher. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Madam President, Mr President.I am asking you, as the representative of the largest party group in the European Parliament, probably because they can be quite effective.Well, you mentioned, and your party colleagues also, that there are traffickers and innocent victims.On the demand side, therefore, there is very little talk about the users of these terrible services.What do you think can be done to avoid the need for all this horror?

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE)
text: "blue card" response.- Well, you will not pretend that I am here the oracle of Delphi and have the power to give a solution to a problem of such complexity.What seems very important to me is to reinforce the unequivocally established mechanisms for prevention;modify the penal codes, toughening the penalties for this;and, fundamentally, installing instruments of repression and investigation in Europol and Eurojust, with judges and prosecutors.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, of the priorities and objectives in the fight against trafficking in human beings, I would like to see three fundamental questions answered. What instruments are being used to detect victims of trafficking, are there real data on the number of victims, with the flow of migrants in Europe, how has prevention been developed, how have children and women who are the main targets of traffickers protected? Furthermore, how many traffickers have been arrested in the Union? Do we have this data? This lack of information sounds, in fact, little by little. Note that there are about ten thousand migrant children missing on European soil. Many of them are said to have been victims of trafficking, which clearly shows a lack of coordination, cooperation and political inconsistency in the results. What is most tragic is our inability to create effective measures and that, at the moment, among the nearly twenty-one million children trafficked worldwide, many will be working or being victims of sexual exploitation. Most of them still have faith in us.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Madam President!Colleagues!Trafficking in human beings is the third most profitable illegal business, right after arms and drug trafficking.The victims of trafficking are mainly women and girls and they account for 85% of all victims.The scale of this crime is enormous: 30 million victims, including 5 million girls.Of course, we repeat here in this room that the main purpose of human trafficking is sexual exploitation.Pope Francis called human trafficking a shameful scourge, unworthy of a civilized society.Man in this practice becomes a commodity.It is heartless trampling on human dignity.Victims of these crimes are often exploited as organ donors and forced to work illegally.This problem also occurs in the European Union.How is it?We want to set standards, but we are not able to protect girls and women ourselves?Urgent coordination of services, joint action in doing good is needed.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, the strategy to combat trafficking in human beings is, according to the responses we have received from the Commission, the basis on which the actions to develop a Community policy on disappearances of persons are based. In fact, this traffic is identified as responsible for most of the 10,000 disappearances of unaccompanied minors and for a good part also of other enforced disappearances that are registered annually in the Union. In addition to the measures that focus on issues related to the investigation and clarification of this type of event, I would like to ask whether the Commission is aware of the peculiar legal situation in which the victims and relatives of disappeared persons remain in the Union, that causes double victimization, and if there is any provision to review it within the framework of the European policy of care for crime victims. We would like to know specifically when the results of the study that Commissioner Jourová announced to us last November will be available on the transposition of the directive on victims, which has included a specific section on victims of disappearances.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Eurostat figures for the past three years tell us that around 80% of the victims of human trafficking in the European Union are women. The primary motivation is linked to sexual exploitation, but there are various facets on which we do not dwell enough and we end up circumscribing the problem to the different forms of prostitution, when this is not the case. I am talking, for example, of early marriages or fake marriages, the so-called sham marriages, contracted by families on the skin of girls, or the trafficking of pregnant women for the sale and illegal adoption of babies. All of this takes place within the Member States. And it is a trend destined to increase with the growth of migratory flows and asylum requests. The search for legitimate residence within the Union will, according to Europol, lead to an increase in forced marriages. We must protect these girls, preventing them, for example, from being sent to their countries of origin during the school holidays and from finding precocious wives of men much older than them. Attention must be drawn to these situations, which cannot be tolerated by hiding behind respect for the culture of others, because whoever marries a child commits enormous violence, not only sexual, against her, but steals her possibility forever. to love and live as a free woman.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! The phenomenon of human trafficking affects a huge number of European Union citizens, and this fact is less well known to the European public. Not only are the activities of prostitution-related networks and criminal groups a cause for concern, but also very serious cases of labor market exploitation, a phenomenon of a kind of modern-day slavery. Thousands of EU citizens work as guest workers in the more developed countries of the EU under extremely poor conditions, for very low wages, for up to 12 hours a day and often subjected to sexual abuse. It is also a form of human trafficking, as the labor of these exploited people is traded and profited by others, and all existing regulations are overthrown and the victims' need and helplessness is exploited. These phenomena, I think, can be repressed if the authorities take tough action against the perpetrators. I find it impossible that, for example, the situation of thousands of agricultural workers within a well-defined area would be unknown to the official bodies.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, despite the adoption in 2011 of the directive on the prevention and repression of trafficking in human beings and the protection of victims, the phenomenon remains very serious if, as evidenced by a study by the High Commissioner United Nations for refugees, 70% of migrants in transit from North Africa to Europe are victims of trafficking, organ trafficking, prostitution and other forms of exploitation. Of course, the most vulnerable are minors, especially unaccompanied minors, and women. Furthermore, trafficking in human beings is one of the most serious cross-border crimes, but at the same time it represents one of the most profitable for criminal organizations, so much so that it is the third source of income after arms and drug trafficking. So? And so the Commission needs to take stronger measures to ensure that all Member States transpose the directive in full, and a new strategy on trafficking in human beings is needed which, in line with the current migration agenda, can effectively counter this very serious crime.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: - Madam President!Today we are talking about human trafficking - that is, about people who are abducted to become prostitutes or forced laborers.Europol already found in 2009 that the open internal European borders facilitate this trafficking in human beings.In the past, before Schengen, it was difficult to smuggle people from east to west.Today, countries of origin such as Russia or Turkey are only one border control away.In the past, only highly developed criminal gangs and criminal organizations could be successful in people smuggling.Today it is very easy, says Europol, and that is the problem.You remember the result of two weeks of border controls at the G7 summit in Elmau in 2015: 120 successful searches, 80 criminal proceedings.Border controls are important, they are possible and they are effective, and anyone who complains about human trafficking but does not want to protect borders is lying in their own pockets.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, slavery is a crime. Trafficking in human beings is classified as a serious transnational crime in the Treaty on the European Union and is outlawed by international humanitarian law. And yet, slavery is by no means eradicated from Europe, as this debate shows. Thousands of vulnerable people are sold or traded for exploitation; his organs, removed and sold; often vulnerable women trafficked for forced marriages or illegal adoptions. And all this takes place within the framework of a European Union strategy to combat human trafficking. It was launched while I was the chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in 2011 and concluded in 2016. Therefore, this oral question is pertinent to urge the Commission immediately to adopt a strategy that revalidates the commitment of gender and protection of victims that was established in the first Strategy of 2011, culminated in 2016. But, above all, that it says in what way we are going to reinforce, in the light of experience, the European commitment in the fight and prevention against trafficking in human beings.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the mafias trade with people, essentially women and girls who are deceived, tortured, forced into prostitution in many cases. We are talking about slavery in the 21st century, and on this issue, about trafficking in human beings, it is essential that we make a greater effort on the part of the institutions. It is essential to have a legislative instrument. It is important that the Directive on trafficking is put into effect, and also that the European Commission makes a study of the application and transposition into the laws of the different Member States. But only with a law, only with legislative instruments we do not implement policies that really advance in this situation. We need political will, and the Commissioner has not yet told us when he is going to put the European Anti-Trafficking Strategy on the table. Because we are talking about human lives, we are talking about the lives of women, of boys and girls, of vulnerable beings. And we, those of us who have public responsibilities, are required to make every effort to fight against it.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner; This phenomenon has been described by all my colleagues, it is a global phenomenon, and it must be addressed globally. It is very connected, by the way, with the phenomenon of refugees and immigration. But I am going to refer to the local phenomenon, because, indeed, most of the people who are trafficked are women and girls - in the case of the European Union - to be sexually exploited. That is, for prostitution. We traffic the bodies of women and girls for prostitution. But prostitution exists because prostitution is consumed and because there are prostitution entrepreneurs. We are faced with this hypocritical, enormously hypocritical discourse of the European leaders, especially in the Member States, who do not prosecute the sexual exploitation of women and girls locally. All the roads in my country, Commissioner - and surely yours - are full of places, brothels, in which there are girls and women who have been victims of this traffic. You don't have to go very far; It is enough to travel our countries, it is enough to follow the route of those who consume prostitution, because they are consuming direct exploitation of women and girls. So let's not go too far and act directly on our own countries.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I have to apologize about the timing.I think you had a little longer time now, but we had a technical problem.It works again from the next speaker.I have a total of about ten requests to speak for the catch-the-eye procedure that follows.I will let everyone have their say.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, thank you for taking all the speakers. I appreciate it. This is an enormous problem, not just in Europe but right across the world. As we celebrate the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome, the treaty that set up our Union and has led to peace across the entire European Union for 60 years which is good, now we have to look at more details. Not just in terms of stopping war and bringing peace to our Union, but for individuals to be treated properly, with respect and dignity. There is far too much exploitation going on; there are far too many smugglers, human traffickers exploiting women, young children, etc. I think now is the time to reflect on what we can do to ensure that there will be peace both in terms of the continent, but also for individuals, where they can work and live properly and with dignity right across the European Union, and for smugglers and others to be prosecuted and dealt with.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, trafficking in human beings is a terrible form of slavery in modern times. The prevention and repression of this phenomenon must be a top priority for the European Union, and an extraordinary effort by the international community is needed to eliminate these inhuman forms of exploitation. However, the intolerable phenomenon of trafficking in human beings is not only the result of economic and social inequalities, but also of gender inequality. Structural discrimination means that 80% of the victims are female: women, girls and often girls. The migratory phenomenon often overlaps with that of the routes. Smuggling of migrants ... (The President invited the speaker to speak more slowly) Smuggling of migrants and trafficking in human beings, while representing different phenomena, often tend to become complementary. It is a drama within a drama, a problem that is added to the others and that needs the adoption of specific and targeted strategic measures. Therefore, an overall strategy that puts an end to this absurd humanitarian drama is absolutely impossible to postpone.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, Mr Avramopoulos, Commissioner, as you can see, everyone agrees that there must be a decisive confrontation with trafficking in human beings, the slave trade, strict measures, border controls. But Turkey's responsibilities are enormous, because it tolerates and guides the slave trade circuits in the Aegean islands, which it has filled with refugees and, above all, with thousands of illegal immigrants. Recent reports, Mr. Avramopoulos, show that the Turkish Secret Service (MIT) has set up an espionage network in the Aegean islands. They exploit the slave traders, they exploit people who work with the slave traders and that is very dangerous. We even had arrests. The next thing that strikes me is what Mr Tusk said today in Skopje. He praised Skopje for closing the border, and Ban Ki-moon himself said it was illegal. That is, should the borders be closed so that slave traders can do their job and increase the amounts they demand? Mr Tusk's statements are unacceptable today in Skopje.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: - Unicef has said it: 50 percent of the victims of human trafficking are children.And that's what it's all about for me today.That figure is of course only a guess, because human trafficking with children is done clandestinely and children do not dare to admit it.While we fail, Commissioner, to protect them, those children are falling victim.We know what happens to them: they end up in prostitution, they are killed for their organs and all kinds of other atrocities.What about the ten thousand underage asylum seekers who disappeared, Commissioner?I have asked you about it many times and I will continue to do so until we have a real action plan.Hence, of course, Madam Chairman, my question, along with many colleagues here: what are we going to do to protect the children?They are the greatest good of society.Let's bet on that.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, it has been about a year and a half since I asked the European institutions what they intended to do with information from the British daily The Guardian. He wrote that in the United Kingdom, three thousand children from Vietnam are often imprisoned and often forced to work illegally against their will. Yes, in the UK. I wanted to know the reaction of the British Government and the reaction that the European institutions are planning so that the situation can be resolved as soon as possible and can never happen again. In response, I received a list of international agreements that prohibit forced labor and trafficking in human beings, and in particular children. So does this mean that if we sign an international agreement on a problem, the problem will disappear immediately? I confess that the degree of cynicism contained in the answer to this question took my breath away. Signing the agreement is one thing, but the fact is that we are still witnessing human trafficking in the 21st century, and we must ensure that this does not happen again, even in the territory of the European Union, which should set an example and be who will prevent this, always and everywhere.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, throughout last year we received reports of 10 000 and more unaccompanied refugee children entering Europe, being registered and subsequently disappearing. These reports are no longer headline news, but the problem has not been addressed. These unaccompanied minors, especially women and girls, are often trafficked and taken into an underworld of sexual exploitation and abuse. This is a Europe-wide problem and it requires continuous EU-wide work, commitment, investment in resources and prosecution of criminal traffickers. In my own country, the UK, hundreds of unaccompanied refugee children were discovered to be not given any safe haven and it is one of the reasons why the Dubs amendment to welcome refugee children in the UK was so important. Shame on the Conservative Government for going back on its word and ending the scheme when only 350 children had benefited instead of the 3 000 who were promised a safe haven. As a founder of the Children’s Rights Intergroup I will never stop fighting for a compassionate, effective, legal, rights-based response.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, human trafficking is one of the most serious crimes and the worst forms of human rights violations.We must resolutely fight against it with quality policies, better coordination between the competent authorities of the Member States, greater efficiency on the ground and more intensive cooperation with the countries with which we share the external border.But in order to be able to move forward and fight this serious crime in a better way, we must learn from our own mistakes.Our tolerance of the illegal influx of migrants has led to the business of smuggling people literally flourishing.If we continue to send messages to our policies that we are ready to receive all the victims of this world without any criteria, the pressure on our borders will only grow, and smugglers will have even more clients.Without a decisive blow to human smugglers and a clear departure from the headless policy of open borders, this great problem, even with the best of intentions, will not be solved!

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, we are essentially talking about a crime against humanity. And I think all my colleagues have expressed very strongly their dissatisfaction with this evil. But at the same time, I feel that we are talking from this secured space about an issue so far away, as if we were looking at it from afar with binoculars. We can not approach the terrible evil that is happening to these hundreds of thousands of people if we do not really manage to approach this picture. And there is no other way but to get out of this room and go to the places where these tragic events take place. And I will close with the well-known position that is often heard loudly from the Left: we must confront the causes that cause this evil and the causes are wars and famine. There are no other ways!

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I remember the great commitment with which in 2011 in Parliament we approved the directive on trafficking in human beings as a violation of fundamental human rights, enslavement of persons, both sexual and working, which involves, as has been said, an absolute majority of women and an increasing number of minors, especially unaccompanied. It was asked to approximate the sanctions between the various countries, as well as information and protection actions for victims also with humanitarian residence permits. I would like to recall that the opportunity was envisaged for Member States to take measures against those who knowingly make use of the sexual or labor services of trafficked persons. But it is urgent that the Commission, as the Commissioner said earlier, strongly recalls the Member States that have not yet done so - and they are the majority - to transpose the directive, also because otherwise it is useless to have put in place European coordination and national coordinators, if there are free zones for the exploiters. The 2016 report shows that the number of uncertified victims is still high, thus remaining in a situation of invisibility, also because they are confused with illegal immigration and this is causing attention to fall on the status of victims.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues for this very constructive and interesting debate. I would also like to thank you for your support in keeping the fight against trafficking in human beings high on the political agenda. The questions you raised today – the economic and financial aspects, the gender dimension and the coherence between the internal and external dimension – will fuel the development of a new, comprehensive EU anti—trafficking policy. It will certainly take due account of the actual and worrisome trends in Europe. Mrs Wikström, trafficking existed prior to the migration crisis. It is not something new. But there is evidence that the current challenges have exacerbated vulnerabilities and I agree about the attention that has to be given to children. They represent 15% of the victims. Mr Panzeri, in order to ensure policy coherence, it is important to take into account the latest deliverables. The first progress report on the fight against trafficking in human beings and the two reports of the Anti-Trafficking Directive delivered last September will also take into account the targeted consultation with all relevant stakeholders. The internal Commission processes are ongoing to ensure the best possible outcome for a future policy.  Mr Urtasun, the latest data for the European Union does indeed indicate that sexual exploitation is the most prevalent form of exploitation. It concerns 67% of victims with 95% being women and girls. The external dimension has been an integral part of EU policy to address trafficking in human beings. It constitutes one of its pillars and will continue to do so. Let me assure you once again that the Commission is monitoring the process in Member States towards the full transposition of the Directive on anti—trafficking. We will take all necessary steps to ensure full compliance with it. Let me conclude by saying that the fight against trafficking in human beings is an imperative for the European Union to continue its struggle against unscrupulous criminals. You can be sure that we will do our best in order to take all the necessary action and all the necessary initiatives in the future, engaging all Member States in order to fulfil this commitment.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - Trafficking in human beings, especially women and children, is one of the most worrying phenomena in the world and, unfortunately, one of the fastest growing criminal industries. It is impossible for many of us to imagine, but even today, millions of people are forced to work in factories, farms and homes in conditions similar to slavery. The Global Slavery Index estimates that 35.8 million people live in slavery today. In its latest progress report on the fight against trafficking in human beings, the European Commission estimates the number of victims of this heinous crime in the EU at 16,000 a year. This situation is intolerable and unsustainable! It is unacceptable for even a person to live as a slave in the 21st century. century in Europe, but anywhere else in the world. Closely linked to human trafficking, human trafficking is also flourishing today on our continent and in the world. According to Europol, there are currently more than 5,000 international organized crime groups in the EU, which is not only a decrease but also a significant increase compared to 2013 figures. And these international criminal groups are increasingly intertwined with migrant smuggling, which not only smuggles migrants into Europe but also encourages them to embark on a life-threatening journey. That is why we must take all possible steps to eradicate human trafficking networks.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Kateřina Konečná, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on 'Palm oil and the clearing of rainforests' (2016/2222 (INI)) (A8-0066 / 2017).

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, in debates, people often ask me why I am interested in the issue of palm oil. Why don't I prefer soy, avocado or other vegetable oils. I believe that this is a legitimate question, which is why I want to answer it for you. The topic of palm oil opened to me sometime at the end of 2015, when I first learned about the fires in Indonesia. I admit that I was completely amazed. The rainforests were on fire and with them everything living in them. The environmental damage was dizzying, but no one seemed to know about it. It was as if we were all looking the other way and letting the rainforests burn. No one informed about it, few people talked about it and no one seemed to be dealing with it. So I started working on the topic, and I had no idea that I was opening Pandora's box. The fires were linked to many of the problems associated with palm oil production in general - corruption, blindness, child labor, environmental devastation, violations of human and indigenous communities, activities of multinational corporations, post-colonial development and migration, and I could go on. This innocent-looking ingredient, often added to confectionery, cosmetics, baby food, potato chips and other food and drug products, is responsible for the fact that the rainforest has burned on more than two million hectares in Indonesia for more than two million hectares. This fire emitted more CO2 into the atmosphere in three weeks than Germany can handle in a whole year. Orangutans, gibbon, Sumatran elephants and tigers, along with thousands and possibly millions of other species, have lost the last remnants of their natural habitat and are in danger of being destroyed. Sixty-nine million people in Indonesia and Borneo breathed polluted air, and thousands of people paid with their lives for these fires. The reason was the effort to create palm plantations at the expense of the forest. The negatives of such palm oil production are clear, but the low price is able to overcome everything. We are thus witnessing another race to the bottom, in which we prefer to follow a short-term race economic benefits rather than the long-term interests of the sustainability of our lives on Earth. As indicated, the problem is not only in the release of harmful substances into our air, which of course helps global warming, but especially in the fact that we do so in the rainforests, which we rightly call the lungs of the planet. I believe that the European Union, as an organization that strongly supports the Paris Climate Agreement and the UN Sustainable Development Goals, must act on this. I am very glad that I have found important allies in the shadow newsletters and let me thank them very much. And not only to them, but also to all their co-workers. They took the subject with the seriousness it deserved, and they were a great support and a great help. We may have taken a different path sometimes, but the direction remained the same. For European consumers, but also for citizens of countries that produce palm oil, we wanted to prevent deforestation associated with palm oil production. Ensure that palm oil imported into the European Union is grown and processed in sustainable ways. Push for the most ambitious certification schemes possible. Fight human rights abuses on plantations and trampling on the human rights of indigenous communities. To also comment on the illogicality that we have palm oil in first-generation biofuels, which causes fires that flood our air with significant amounts of CO2. Ladies and gentlemen, I am now looking forward to a constructive debate on my report and on this issue. Palm oil is certainly not the greatest evil we have under the sun. However, the current method of cultivation and processing poses a risk to our planet, and for that reason I believe that we must not only talk about this issue, but also act.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to welcome this own-initiative report and particularly congratulate Ms Konečná and her colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI). I would also like to congratulate and thank the other three associated committees as well for their good work, and I am referring to the Committee on Development (DEVE), the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI).  Addressing the environmental and social challenges of deforestation and forest degradation has been, and will continue to be, a priority for the European Union, and in particular for the Commission. That is the case now more than ever as part of the implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development as well as for the Paris Agreement. Deforestation is a complex problem with many drivers such as infrastructure and agricultural expansion and with different dynamics in various countries, so there is no single solution. Tackling it requires action at many levels – at the international, national and local levels – and through joint efforts by different actors, acting together – governments, industry and business and civil society. It means working in partnership with countries which are most affected by deforestation and it means adopting a comprehensive and broad approach by identifying all the relevant policies, processes and tools we can work with. The European Union has consistently been at the forefront of action in this area through both international and domestic initiatives. At the international level the European Union has proactively engaged in the UN Forum on Forests, in the Convention on Biological Diversity, in the implementation of the REDD+ framework, and under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. Domestically, since 2003, the European Union has an ambitious forest law enforcement governance and trade action plan which has delivered key results such as the conclusion of VPAs (voluntary partnership agreements) to help partner countries combat illegal logging. But being a frontrunner does not mean that no further engagement is needed. The evaluation of our FLEGT Action Plan demonstrated that the work we have carried out so far to combat illegal logging is achieving significant results, but also that we need to work more and we need to work better, both internationally and domestically.  Addressing illegal logging is not sufficient on its own. The main drivers of deforestation are related to a broad range of societal factors. In that context we also have to look, for example, at our own consumption and agricultural commodities that are often associated with deforestation, such as soybean and palm oil here in the EU. We are of course aware of the degree of public concern at the environmental impacts of palm oil production, such as deforestation and biodiversity loss, greenhouse gas emissions and indigenous rights issues, but we are also aware of the opportunities that it presents, for instance contributing to lifting thousands of people out of poverty in producing countries.  The Commission believes that we need to address the issue of deforestation by looking at a much broader range of issues and drivers. As a follow-up to the 7th EAP, the Commission launched this last year in 2016 a study to consider the feasibility of options to step up EU action to combat deforestation and forest degradation. The results of this report should be available by mid-2017. The Commission believes also that it is essential to cooperate and to support the efforts of producer countries to minimise deforestation and other negative impacts that palm oil cultivation can have in order to achieve sustainable production of this commodity.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, palm oil is a dangerous product that causes enormous damage. Europe is the second largest importer in the world, but precisely for this reason it is also able to dictate the rules on the international market for this product and demand respect for human rights and the environment much more than any convention or agreement. Strengthened by this consideration, in the INTE commission we have formulated precise recommendations: differentiated customs duties to reward those who produce in a sustainable way; complete traceability of palm oil along the entire supply chain to understand who really produces respecting the rules; and finally we called for the use of free trade treaties to promote clear and binding rules on sustainable development, the environment and human rights in producing countries. This means putting trade at the service of the weakest. I thank the rapporteur and the whole Committee on the Environment, who have decided to make our main recommendations their own and to reflect them in the final text which will certainly see our support.

name: Florent Marcellesi
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - Madam President, the monoculture of palm oil is a disaster for ecosystems and a danger to our health. Look, he's responsible in Indonesia for deforesting forests the size of Germany. Furthermore, in Europe, we consume harmful amounts of palm oil: an average of 60 liters per year per person, that is, more bad cholesterol and more heart problems. And, as if that weren't enough, almost half of the palm oil imported into Europe is used for agrofuel. With these thousands of hectares of crops, we want to feed people or feed cars. Therefore, the European Commission must act to exclude the use of palm oil as an agrofuel from public funds, launch a binding action plan against deforestation, label products that contain palm oil and guarantee that in producing countries the rights of local populations.

name: Alberto Cirio
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I too would like to thank the rapporteur for the work she has done and which we have done in recent months to deal with a topic that is certainly important, which has to do with the environment, which health of people, but which had to be treated with due seriousness and also with due insights. In fact, the question of palm oil, and the need for it to be grown in a sustainable way, has made us open our eyes to realities such as the Indonesian one, in which respect for the environment is not always guaranteed, but it also made us understand that instead there are other countries of Southeast Asia - in particular we refer to other realities, to other States - in which we have found and have found a greater respect for the environment, greater education, greater maturity, greater sensitivity , greater awareness regarding the need to ensure production that is sustainable and that is done respecting the environment. This is fundamental, if we think of countries like Malaysia, which have made significant investments to differentiate themselves from those that have been elements of exploitation, of lack of respect for the environment of these productions. And if on the one hand we have found that some countries differed positively, on the other hand we must not forget - because here we are in the seat of the European Parliament - that the largest European industries that have used palm oil in Europe over the years they have always done so in the autonomous and voluntary respect of this sustainable balance. We will now provide for traceability, we will plan to make interventions on the label, we will plan to guarantee the path of palm oil from where it is produced to where it is consumed.
