We know, and we must know, that large Italian and European companies have already done it up to now, they have done it voluntarily for their commitment, because sensitivity is a sensitivity to use a product that is not harmful in itself, because it is a vegetable oil that exists in nature, but which must naturally be used and marketed with respect for the environment.

name: Paul Brannen
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the S&D Group are pleased with this own-initiative report. We have had good cross-group cooperation and agreement on the important issue of palm oil and deforestation. At the eleventh hour a letter was received by some of us from ambassadors representing some of the palm oil producing countries outside of the European Union. The letter makes four criticisms of Parliament’s own-initiative report on palm oil and deforestation. However, all of these can be countered. The first criticism made in the letter is that palm oil is not the main deliverer of deforestation. In reply, it may not be the single biggest cause of deforestation but it is responsible for some 29% which is a significant amount of deforestation. The European Union has signed up to ending deforestation and as the third largest market for palm oil the EU cannot turn a blind eye. Consumers have responsibilities too. The second criticism is that the report attacks the reputation of palm oil producing countries. No, it does not! Nor does it call for the phasing out of palm oil.  The third criticism, that the aim of a single certification scheme is redundant, is not true. Too many schemes are now confusing the customer. We need one certification scheme. The fourth criticism is that the report is partial and not inclusive. In reply, this again is not true. The process involved a sustainable palm oil round table which involved growers, cooperatives, processers, traders, development NGOs, environment NGOs and social NGOs. It was inclusive. It is an inclusive report. To conclude, the European Union signed up to the UN Paris Agreement on climate change and this report helps deliver the EU’s obligations and should be supported by Members of Parliament.

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Konečná, and her team for their work on this file. The text we will vote on is a true compromise text, and I appreciate the efforts made to accommodate all of our positions. I am just going to concentrate on one thing here today, my personal priority in these discussions and something I am very pleased that has been included. It is the call for one single certification scheme at EU level. This is a scheme which businesses and consumers can easily recognise. I believe the existence of multiple certification schemes confuses consumers. You do not know which logo or scheme to trust when seeking to make a sustainable consumption choice. I understand that there are difficulties. The main growers, most particularly in South-East Asia, the Indonesian and Malaysian growers, have not reached an agreement on what level of sustainability there should be and how it should be certificated. I am delighted that in our report we have laid that out really very carefully. A huge amount of work went on from the rapporteur to get that right, so that it is sensible, it is annotated, it lays out what we think could be done, what we think should be done. I believe that this is a huge step forward. Rather than continue to demonise palm oil – some of the language even this evening I cannot possibly agree with, although I do recognise that deforestation is a bad thing – we should move ahead firmly with the certification schemes as laid out in this report and really get ourselves behind it here in the EU.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President, I too would like to thank the rapporteur, my colleague Konečná, for the work she has done on this report. The destruction of rainforests due to the cultivation of palm oil is currently one of the biggest environmental problems on the planet. The speed and pace of rainforest eradication is particularly alarming. Primeval forests that act as the lungs of our planet. We are thus endangering our future generations, the future of people living in mining areas, we are endangering many of the rarest animal species. I am therefore very pleased that the European Parliament has also taken a clear position on this matter, that it is aware of the urgency of the problem and the need to address it. Even the unprecedented consensus across political factions is proof that there is a will and an effort to address the issue. I welcome the fact that the result of the negotiations is a material containing a number of concrete steps. Whether it is the introduction of minimum standards for palm oil imported into the European Union, the provability of its origin, ensuring greater transparency of information for us consumers. The European Union is the third largest consumer of palm oil in the world. As in many other areas, we should act responsibly and set standards that can inspire the rest of the world.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL).
text: - The European Union is a huge buyer and investor in palm oil, and Europe is therefore playing a major role in the destruction of our planet. At the expense of future generations and at the expense of habitats for humans and animals, Europe is burning down primeval forests in Indonesia and Malaysia. The sustainable palm oil certification system has failed. Sustainable palm oil does not exist! Sustainable palm oil is a myth to soothe the conscience of consumers, producers and politicians. Let's stop using conflict materials like palm oil. Because not only coal and copper are disastrous for our planet, but palm oil certainly is. Now let's invest in cultivation in our own soil. Now is the time to invest in organic cultivation of flax, sunflowers and rapeseed. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question under Rule 162 (8).)

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you Ms. Hazekamp.You are from the Netherlands as far as I know.I think you have a very special responsibility for Indonesia because, as far as I know, West Papua has been completely depopulated.Not even 50% of the original population live there, and palm oil is grown there too.Couldn't one begin to label either the palm oil from West Papua or, if that's not enough, if they don't stop depopulating the country there, threatening sanctions there too?

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" answer.Thank you for this question.Of course, the Netherlands has a considerable past in Indonesia and that is not a past of which we should be proud.If we now look at Europe's role in deforestation of jungles in Indonesia and Malaysia, we need to make sure that we don't have to be ashamed again in 50 years.And we must now stop importing palm oil and using it.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to say thank you to Kateřina for her outstanding work with the file. Palm oil is clearly one of the major drivers of tropical deforestation and it not only has climate-related problems but also has a disastrous effect on biodiversity, and it also has some human rights issues including land grabbing and forced eviction of indigenous people. So that makes it clear that for the EU there are some things to do. The EU is the world’s largest importer of embedded deforestation and also one of the biggest markets for palm oil globally. We Greens, in line with the report, believe that there is a clear need for a fully sustainable palm oil supply chain by 2020. Also we call on the Commission to come up with an action plan on palm oil. There is a need for comprehensive sustainability criteria for palm oil products, also with independent auditing and monitoring of the certification schemes. In the long term we also need a mandatory certification scheme for palm oil in the EU, and also binding commitments, in particular an anti-deforestation guarantee in trade and development cooperation agreements with producing countries. Altogether I think that we also have to go beyond palm oil, as there are other issues of deforestation as well, and we call on the Commission to come up with not only a palm oil action plan but also with a deforestation action plan as soon as possible.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the disastrous effects of the uncontrolled cultivation of oil palm are there for all to see. In producing countries, despite numerous proclamations, there is still no change of course to put an end to the destruction of rainforests, which provide invaluable ecosystem services for us and for future generations. Of course, palm oil is not the only one responsible for global deforestation, we know that well. The relationship we are discussing here, however, marks a precise path that we must follow for this and other products, which still correspond to a standardized and unsustainable model of production and consumption, which is antithetical to the use and promotion of ingredients and organic, quality products and preferably even at zero kilometer. I would like this report to be approved tomorrow also because it incorporates many of the demands that the 5 Star Movement has made in the work of the Committee on the Environment. Above all I want to mention two. The first: the need to support a mapping of the territory in producing countries, in order to control the expansion of plantations and create ecological corridors dedicated to the conservation of critically endangered species. Secondly: the request to freeze the areas planted with oil palm and to introduce a moratorium on new concessions as part of the dialogue that the Union and the Member States have with producing countries to safeguard what remains of the rainforests . I thank my colleague Kateřina Konečná and all the shadow rapporteurs for their work.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the rapporteur proposes firm commitments on labor as well as on social and environmental criteria in trade agreements. However, we cannot reduce our dependence on palm oil without considering a sustainable replacement solution. Vegetable oils which could replace them require more cultivable land. Increased use of these crops would not remedy deforestation, to which agriculture contributes 73%. The rapporteur has therefore rightly qualified the 2020 date for the use of palm oil in biofuels, which represent an increasing share of total palm oil consumption. It is therefore urgent to develop second and third generation biofuels. This energy transition must be accompanied by a social transition. Small producers provide about 40% of world production. We need to guarantee them fair treatment when it comes to qualifications. I take note that this text deals with all these questions. However, all of our policies must establish a coherent framework for our future energy supply.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: - Madam President, esteemed Commissioner! The consumption of palm oil has increased by around 700% in the last 30 years, and the result is now really blatant overexploitation and also exploitation in the producing countries. Palm oil can now be found as an additive in almost all products - regardless of whether they are in food, cosmetics, detergents or anything else. In all of these everyday products, cheap, industrially produced palm oil also partially replaces really sustainable and, above all, domestic alternatives. I am also astonished that political groups in particular fall for the campaigns of the palm oil lobby here again and again and sometimes also demonize animal products and animal fats, which, however, especially in Europe, are produced to much, much better and more sustainable standards. I would like to expressly support the demands for transparent labeling of palm oil in refined products and, above all, appeal to consumers to always pay attention to where products are being made when making purchasing decisions. I would also like to underline my request for a butter fat support. We could simply and really very efficiently use measures to bring butterfat back into food production and thus replace palm oils. And it should also become more attractive again to produce oils in Europe - vegetable oils. In this way, we could reduce the CO2 footprint and also ensure more regionality. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Madam President, honorable Member.I hope I understood what you said, but if so, I miss it a little bit, because it seemed as if you were putting the weight of solving the problem on the producer countries, while the developed countries are the ones demanding these products.Don’t you think we should live by shrinking demand rather than pointing outwards?

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- One thing definitely depends on the other, but what I really want is that we have a lot of opportunities in Europe to produce and thus ultimately to reduce this dependence on imports.What we keep forgetting here: For example, ice cream production and much more was replaced years ago by cheap products, in some cases palm oil products as well, and what was displaced was milk products, and that could also be reversed and thusOf course, the demand in Europe will also be reduced.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to start by saying thank you to Kateřina Konečná as rapporteur for her work on this report and also to our S&D shadow, Paul Brannen, because whilst progress has been registered in international, European and national policies and in the regulatory framework, and whilst various commitments have been made from political, financial and industry leaders, we still need to work harder to make sure that the business of clearing out forests for palm oil and timber plantation, of robbing indigenous people and invading the land and resources, will no longer be considered business as usual.  Sustainable policies addressing deforestation can stimulate economic growth and development. They can encourage agricultural productivity and reduce social conflict. They can be a win for our climate, for inclusive development, for economic growth, and for small-scale farmers and indigenous people alike.  But we need to act together. Only if we all do our part can we achieve these benefits. This is an appeal to promote forest protection as a new way of doing business and not as a threat to business. We require measures that are environmentally sustainable, measures that are socially responsible. Ultimately, it is our responsibility to support sustainable production and provide EU consumers with a choice based on informed decisions. Accepting palm oil from sustainable sourcing is our obligation if we want to address deforestation and prevent extinction of threatened species.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, we have no choice but to admit to ourselves that we simply did not react in time and that we now need "fire measures".I symbolically mention “firefighting measures” because we know what it means when a fire ravages forests.We are now harassing them in another way, because of the desire for profit, extra profits, because of corruption.We are not at all interested in environmental protection or the core values we promote, above all, in our own backyard.As if this little planet will live only from the fact that we protect it in the area of our continent.Our trade, our companies that so hastily want their development and access to capital in an incorrect way, without fair trade, will not help this planet.That is why I am both for traceability and certification and for many things that are very well presented in this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the cause of 80% of global deforestation is agriculture. We lose nine million hectares in forests - this is the same as the area of ​​Portugal or three times that of Belgium - every year. We Europeans are part of this problem, and palm oil is one of its most damaging faces. It is not worth keeping looking the other way; We cannot shirk our responsibility as one of the largest importers and consumers of palm oil. We cannot escape our responsibility. According to a study by the Commission itself, the Union's forest footprint continues not to grow year after year. As long as we continue to function as if there were no limits to the exploitation of the earth, we will continue to be complicit in an unprecedented environmental and human disaster. How can we avoid it? To begin with, a binding regulation must be established. This is what we want with this report: that palm oil imports guarantee the sustainability and traceability of the supply chain. It is possible, necessary and, furthermore, it is in our hands. In closing, I wanted to congratulate my colleague Kateřina on this important report.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank rapporteur for this report on palm oil. I think at the core what we are seeing here is that we, as the European Union, should start using our bargaining power as a big market. We are the second importer of palm oil in the world. Twelve percent of the global production is imported into the EU. The standards that we are setting will be a global example. We are doing it, for example, for conflict minerals. Now it is time for us to take the next step: looking at palm oil production, knowing that there are cases of human rights violations, that there are cases of environmental destruction. If we set our standards and make sure that according to these sustainability criteria only the good stuff is used for import into the EU, we will set a global standard. And that is exactly what we should be doing, for the environment but certainly also for the people earning their money from these products, and that is what we are doing here and it is time we used that power.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the rapid deforestation on the islands of Sumatra and Borneo in Indonesia are of great concern, in particular the threat of extinction to the species that live there. In fact Borneo and Sumatra are the only places on earth where tigers, rhinos, orang-utans and elephants coexist. Such deforestation, caused by the increased demand for palm oil over the past 20 years, is driven in part by the demand for their use in biofuels and biomass, and has led to the decimation of parts of both the Indonesian and Amazonian rainforests. To add insult to injury, these wildernesses, teeming with wildlife, are being replaced by huge palm oil plantations, a sterile monoculture that supports very few living creatures. Coupled with illegal logging, we are witnessing an ecological disaster, as these wildernesses are being sacrificed on the altar of anthropogenic global warming climate change. However, my party UKIP, are unable to support this report as we believe that legislation such as this is too important to be decided by the European Union, and should be left to nation states collaborating at international, rather than at European, level.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is our duty to do our utmost to combat deforestation. Indeed, forests play a key role in adapting to climate change and mitigating its effects. However, the very rapid development, in recent years, of the oil palm monoculture is at the origin of part of the global deforestation. The European Union, as a consumer of palm oil, therefore has a major role to play. Several avenues have been launched in this report and some seem particularly important to me, in particular the support of a sustainable palm oil production, guarantor of the forest, which ensures a great transparency in the production and a good traceability while allowing the maintenance of local agriculture and its jobs. In this context, I support the proposals for simpler and more understandable information for consumers on sustainable palm oil, as well as the establishment of a single certification. I would like to dwell for a moment on the issue of biofuels. The issue of palm oil should not be confused with that, more global, of vegetable oils, such as rapeseed, which can be co-products necessary for our self-sufficiency in terms of proteins while responding to a logic of economy. circular. In my opinion, however, this subject falls within the scope of the revision of the “Energy” directive and I regret that some people wanted to use this report to preempt the discussions.

name: Susanne Melior (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Vella! We have a very important topic on the agenda here today with palm oil. I would also like to thank the rapporteur very much for the good work we have done together in advance. We worked very well together at various technical meetings, but also in the shadow meeting, and also worked out a good recommendation. After all, 40% of global deforestation is caused by the creation of large-scale palm oil monocultures. This problem has also been addressed several times by our colleagues here: Deforestation means that we also release 1.5 gigatons of carbon dioxide. That corresponds to around a quarter of the annual emissions from fossil fuels here in the EU. It affects nearly 70 million people in unhealthy air and results in thousands of premature deaths. But valuable plants and animals are also lost. It is therefore the most urgent problem that we oppose deforestation and bring a uniform certification system on the way, which includes this.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Palm oil production is extremely harmful to biodiversity, and huge areas of rainforest have been and are being destroyed as a result. Numerous animal species are losing their habitat and are dying out. Palm oil is also harmful to the people, as land grabbing by large corporations is driving the indigenous population to ruin. So people, animals and nature pay the price for cheap palm oil. Palm oil ranks third among the most environmentally harmful agricultural products after global meat and soy production. The Konečná report deserves our approval because it contains good proposals for solutions. He called on the EU to consider the urgently needed measures to minimize the negative environmental and social impact of palm oil production. But we have to come to terms with one fact: there is no such thing as ecologically sustainable and socially produced palm oil, and it will not exist in the future either. So let us, Commissioner, take up the fight together with this report on the unregulated palm oil production.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner Vella, I am disappointed with the answer you have given. Unfortunately, this is very unambitious and you rely on voluntary partnerships. That will not solve the problem. We have to do something about consumption, as many colleagues have said. Palm oil is a cheap maker in food and can be substituted. But what is a real scandal is that 45% of palm oil - a million hectares after all - actually goes into agrofuels. We have to end that immediately and not until 2020. That's dirty fuel and you can't put an environmental label on it. But we must also ensure that European companies and European banks still help finance the business. We have to put a stop to this. But we are all clear: a large part of the deforestation is due to palm oil, a large part of the emissions is also due to palm oil, and then there are still some who are then awarded sustainability certificates such as the round table for palm oil come. There is currently no sustainable certification that really deserves its name. We have to apply criteria that are really sustainable and not go along with this fraudulent labeling.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we all agree on one thing today: we must use palm oil that is produced sustainably and there must no longer be this wild deforestation, especially in Indonesia. But many other things are not understandable, and there we divide. Meanwhile, I would like to remind you that palm oil is cultivated not only in Malaysia and Indonesia but also in 17 other countries in the equatorial belt, and thus provides economic subsistence to millions of people. Then we must remember - as has already been mentioned - that if we replace palm oil with other vegetable oils we go to consume even more land, because palm oil has a higher yield between five and eleven times compared to many other oils. And then there is no need to talk to industries, just talk to technicians and nutritionists to understand that palm oil has many characteristics that are also useful, for example for health, because palm oil, being practically solid at temperature environment, does not need hydrogenation and is therefore more suitable for limiting, for example, the risks of cardiovascular diseases compared to trans fatty acids deriving from the hydrogenation process. There are many qualities that this oil has, and it cannot be replaced, for example, even by butter - and below I also see a trade war - because butter contains slightly more saturated fatty acids, it goes rancid more quickly and would therefore shorten the life of the products. So, in conclusion, our message is this: the solution is not to boycott palm oil but to buy it sustainable, ensuring its traceability.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D).
text: - Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate and thank my colleague, Kateřina Konečná, for bringing this topic to the agenda of the European Parliament's plenary. Europeans are interested in whether and how their consumer preferences are helping to destroy the environment, biodiversity and local communities, in this case the rainforest ecosystem and agriculture and local communities in South-West Asia. Now, finally, the European Parliament is clearly speaking in this sense. I hope that the European Commission and the Member States will now really do their utmost to ensure that, from 2020, only palm oil from sustainable production is used in the European Union, according to a single certification. In the compromise text, the European Parliament also calls for the phasing out of the use of palm oil and other vegetable oils as a component of biofuels, with a preference from 2020. I would welcome a tougher result in this regard, but this is a start and I am happy for it.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! First of all, let me thank everyone for their work, because it seems that there is a kind of consensus between the parties here as well. Now, as the People's Party leader in the opinion of the Committee on Development, I would first of all like to highlight the aspects of those living and working in the palm oil-producing countryside. It would, of course, be very tempting to talk about environmental aspects as well. Palm oil production can be largely linked to large international companies with huge markets, although these companies provide a kind of work and livelihood for the residents, it also makes the people living there infinitely vulnerable. Not to mention that local smallholders don’t even have a chance to compete with giants. The local people are suffering from the environmental effects of palm oil extraction, above all the consequences of deforestation, which has already been mentioned a lot here. I would like to say that I see that we have two tasks: we will certainly accompany it with due weight and attention, and we will do so here today, in the interests of those who live there. We are working together to represent environmental and sustainability considerations in our development policy, and I am sure that I am convinced that Europe cannot benefit from deforestation and inhumane working conditions in the current order of palm oil production.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, palm oil is widely used in the food industry and also in the cosmetics and biofuels sector and the truth is that, in the last 20 years, its production has become unsustainable and has resulted in massive deforestation, in loss of natural habitats, the near extinction of many species and the consequent increase in greenhouse gas emissions. Many cases of child labor and expropriation of indigenous lands for the production of palm oil are also reported. In this context, the European Union - which is the third largest world market for this raw material - has a great responsibility. It must assume a leading role in combating wasteful and abusive practices in the consumption of palm oil and adopt minimum sustainability criteria in its imports of this matter - which must be certified - and the use of these vegetable oils should also be phased out gradually. production of biofuels, increased traceability and labeling and also information to consumers. This report is a step in the right direction and I therefore want to congratulate your rapporteurs.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: - Mrs Kateřina, thank you for the wonderful report. Preserving the rainforest and global biodiversity are vital to the future of humanity, and that's what we're talking about. But palm oil isn't the only cause of global deforestation. Growing world food demand, population pressure and illegal logging are also causes. Let us therefore support and follow up on the sustainability efforts of member states and companies, such as in the Netherlands. Europe, our European Commission and all: sign the Europe and Amsterdam declaration! Before the year 2020, we will then only use certified sustainable palm oil. Sustainable palm oil is indispensable for our food sector, which provides both employment and, of course, a very good source for a great deal of food production. In addition, research and support our European oils and fats, such as rapeseed, butterfat, and alternatives, thus achieving synergy with existing European policy. New animal feed and second and third generation circular biofuels are part of the solution! Finally, European farmers feed the world's population. Give them space, but let our European fields be optimally used for flax, sunflowers and rapeseed, among other things.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would also like to thank my colleague Kateřina Konečná for the report she has been able to present in cooperation with other Members. It is, in fact, the European Parliament's contribution to environmental protection. It is also our responsibility, because the European Union is the second largest importer of palm oil. We have a chance to change the behavior of oil producers and thus improve this situation. A concrete benefit would be the creation of a single binding certificate, which would give consumers clear information about the origin of palm oil, and here I expect action from the European Commission. Of course, the creation of a more transparent land register in producer countries would also help, but here its establishment is in the hands of producer countries such as Indonesia and Malaysia. The European Union should take the initiative in international negotiations on this matter. I am just afraid that the speed of these steps will be faster than the irreparable destruction of natural resources.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: - Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs - especially Paul Brannen, my colleague - for this own-initiative report, which includes, in particular, the environmental impacts of the palm oil industry. , while promoting a more sustainable production of this product. In the last two decades, intensive cultivation of palm oil has led to the massive deforestation of some of the most precious ecosystems - and that is an unquestionable fact that we all must recognize here today - which has pushed some species to the brink. of extinction. The European Union is the third largest consumer of palm oil; therefore, we have a great responsibility. Some measures have already been taken, but they are still not enough to end the growing demand for this palm oil. Stronger measures must be taken at European level and information campaigns aimed at consumers so that they can better make their decisions; a single certification scheme is a good way to do this as well.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, last week, in the city of Mocoa, in the south of Colombia, 250 people lost their lives due to intense rains and landslides that devastated seventeen neighborhoods in that village. In the Indonesian capital, also last week, a similar incident occurred that claimed the lives of several people and left many others missing. All over the world, this type of calamity happens, which normally affects those who are the most vulnerable in society: the poor and the destitute. The cause is recurrent: the intensive destruction of forest habitats through constant deforestation for agricultural exploitation and for the construction of infrastructure, such as dikes and dams. I believe that this is the right time for the European Union to promote an action plan against deforestation and forest degradation, as well as the production of palm oil. There are many vast problems that today affect tropical ecosystems, which only occupy 7% of the Earth's surface. Palm oil is being increasingly used as biofuel and a substantial part of its production does not respect human rights, using child labor. This report highlights that respect for fundamental human rights, the protection of the forest and the sustainable production of palm oil are reconcilable objectives. The European Union now has to make efforts to ensure that, by 2020, all palm oil consumed in Europe is sustainable. I hope that tomorrow's vote will reflect the urgency of action.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - Palm oil is not just a threat to rainforests.Palm oil has long been used in the food industry as a "vegetable fat".Cheap palm oil is displacing natural butter from more and more foods, replacing milk fat.In some infant formulas, it accounts for up to a quarter of the total weight of the product.This has a direct impact on all European agriculture: by using imported palm oil, we are not only promoting the deforestation of the tropics, but also depriving our farmers, dairy farmers and processors, of their livelihood.Do we Europeans, who already have a surplus of milk and milk products, need it?I therefore support all initiatives to reduce the use and import of palm oil.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the revision of the Energy Directive will soon be presented to Parliament, so I am starting to work on the issues of anaerobic digestion. I discovered with great concern that anaerobic digestion systems used both grains and edible oils, including palm oil. For my part, I refuse to see edible productions being massively used in the production of fuel. In the case of palm oil, this issue is coupled with the problems of deforestation of humid forests essential for climatic balances, drifts in working conditions as well as extremely dangerous pollution for local populations, all to the benefit of of a few. Without condemning palm oil, steps must now be taken to ensure that this product is used in Europe only for essential needs. It would be inconsistent to use it as a fuel source, for example, but also as a frying element, especially in collective restorations. In fact, sustainable, balanced and supervised management between producers and consumers must be put in place.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Madam President, palm oil is increasingly used because of the cheaper price as a raw material compared to similar products, but this saved cost of this raw material will be reflected in much higher public health costs and government budgets and price. which consumers will have to pay. I find it shocking that palm oil is used in the production of baby and baby food. According to experts, 50% of all foods in the European Union contain palm oil. The European Food Safety Authority recently published information that the product is carcinogenic and genotoxic. The vicious practices are clearly being undertaken by unscrupulous producers, but the European Commission must intervene and ban the use of the raw material in the food industry. Last year alone, 12,000 tons were used in my country, Bulgaria, in the food industry.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner!Ten million liters of palm oil flow into the fuel canisters in the European Union every day.In the period 2010 to 2014 alone, the admixture of palm oil in so-called biofuels increased sixfold.The examples we have heard about today show that the idea of doing business sustainably is being taken ad absurdum.Just one example: In Malaysia and Indonesia alone, forests have been cut down in the last 25 years that correspond to the entire forest stock of the Republic of Austria.A further 30% of the Austrian area corresponds to the area that was originally peatland in Malaysia and Indonesia.We see that it is not only humans that are being harmed here, that nature is being damaged here, that biodiversity is being damaged here.We have to say the end of palm oil.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I agree with Susanne Melior, who said that this is a very important discussion. I would like to thank you all for sharing your views on this important matter. As you have confirmed, deforestation is a very complex issue and I think we can agree on a number of points. But we need to take a broader look at deforestation because it is not caused only by the palm oil industry. On the other hand, not all the palm oil industry produces deforestation. So we cannot take a black and white approach. Here I would like to draw a parallel with agriculture. As in all activities, agricultural activity has both good and bad practices. I agree totally that we need to have a more sustainable agriculture, but we cannot say that we have to scrap all agriculture.  A number of colleagues mentioned traceability. I think that traceability and informing consumers about the sustainable production of products also helps a great deal as consumers can take on – and I think consumers should take on – their environmental responsibilities as well. I agree with Bas Eickhout who said that the power of consumers cannot be underestimated. We all agree that we should stop irregular and unsustainable production, not just of palm oil, but any unsustainable production of any product. But do we all agree that all production of palm oil is irregular, illegal or unsustainable? Julie Girling also mentioned palm oil certification. The Commission is also specifically looking at the issue of palm oil certification schemes through a dedicated study which will inform its ongoing work on deforestation. Some Members also mentioned palm oil as a biofuel. We need to work on sustainable production, but we also need to work on sustainable consumption, including biofuels. The Commission has already proposed revising the Renewal Energy Directive to gradually reduce the share of food-based biofuels after 2020. Already this directive does not allow biofuels to count towards renewable energy targets if they come from land that has been deforested since 2008.  I think the final speaker or the speaker before last also mentioned that palm oil in baby food is toxic and harmful. Here our information is that the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) is working on this, but there is no proof that these products are toxic or harmful. I will conclude by saying that this report by Parliament is a very useful contribution to the debate. I have already mentioned that the Commission launched a study last year which will give us a better insight into this industry. In addition, the Commission will also be organising a conference on illegal logging and deforestation in the coming months in Brussels, bringing together producer and consumer countries, as well as private sector and civil society organisations. Here I would like to mention that Kateřina and all her colleagues could – and should – also participate in this conference. I trust that this conference will provide a very useful opportunity to strengthen our dialogue with third countries and trigger further contributions to the Commission’s work on deforestation. Finally, once again, I would like to thank Kateřina Konečná and her colleagues for their good work.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: rapporteur. - Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to thank you very much for the debate that has taken place here, and I have faith in tomorrow's vote and in the fact that perhaps now, although it should not be said in advance, I can say that we have succeeded. a huge piece of work. I would just like to point out that the issue of palm oil is definitely relevant, and that was also the reason why the report has spread from three sides to twenty, it is not just about deforestation, it concerns child trafficking, human labor, it concerns social aspects, it concerns biodiversity, covers an incredible number of topics. And as one of my colleagues here said - perhaps at the moment, we are not only fighting a fire in Indonesia, but we are fighting a fire that we have long overlooked precisely as we have allowed palm oil production to grow and our consumption to grow incredibly. I just want to add that I am very pleased that we here in the European Parliament have handled this debate as a comprehensive debate. A debate that may not have been as heated and emotional as some had initially imagined, but which was factual, apolitical, balanced, and I firmly believe that you will find everything about palm oil in that report. After all, this was stated not only by the NGOs, to whom I thank very much for their support, but also by the industry with which we openly communicated about the matter, and all those who were interested in the subject, except some lobby organizations from some countries that did not even contact us. now they communicate differently via Twitter and Facebook and write you emails about how bad everything is. I guarantee you that if they wanted to meet, they had the opportunity and never did. The Commission has a number of recommendations, and I thank them for them. Thanks for the study we are waiting for and according to my original information it should have been in February. But it cannot be about studies, recommendations, conferences, Commissioner, please, this must be about concrete things and concrete actions, not just the European Commission, but all of us. We are perhaps showing you the way in that report. Thank you that we may pursue this common goal in different ways ways, but we will reach that common goal and we will reach it in time.This will be the most important thing we can do for the future of our planet and our children.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, April 4, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: written. - Europe is one of the most important markets for palm oil, allocating almost 50% to the manufacture of biodiesel. Although we are working hard to limit CO2 emissions, we have no qualms about importing oil of this type, 300% more polluting than fossil diesel combustion, according to the Globiom report, carried out for the Commission. Our extreme hypocrisy causes us to shirk environmental, social and ecological responsibilities just because it is the cheapest of vegetable oils. The Commission must address the end of the use of palm oil as a biofuel feedstock. Europe has the strength of the world's third largest consumer to stop the largest and fastest deforestation in human history, especially in the forests of Borneo and Sumatra. Is there really a sustainable palm crop? I firmly believe that it is not and only the lack of perspective on the problem of global warming makes us think that this could be so. While we are considering establishing border adjustment rates for the import of construction materials and cement, I denounce that no one is proposing to establish these rates to mitigate the disaster that palm oil monoculture entails for global warming.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EU renewable energy policy is driving demand for biofuels within and beyond Europe’s borders. This has led to massive land-use change in various parts of the world and can have serious consequences. The competition for arable land has affected food security at local level as well as global food prices. Some biofuels can even emit more greenhouse gases than the fossil fuels they were supposed to replace. Given these concerns, I welcome the measures proposed in this report. A phasing out of palm oil will reduce the risk of associated deforestation and damaging land-use change. And certification based on sustainability criteria will reduce demand for the most damaging biofuels. Bio-based fuels are not infinite natural resources which can be exploited without consequences. Over-exploitation requires huge amounts of land, water, fertilisers and pesticides, causing pollution, soil degradation, and damage to ecosystem services. A bio-based economy must be developed in the right way, because using the wrong sources of bio-energy can do far more harm than good.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The 2030 Agenda commits the European Union to promoting sustainable forest management, by stopping deforestation, restoring degraded forests and substantially increasing afforestation and reforestation. This goal is made possible by providing sustainable production and consumption patterns and sustainable practices to both companies and consumers, in line with national policies and priorities. At the same time, the consumption of palm oil, expected to double in 2050, calls for deforestation of tropical forests, which means the destruction of natural habitats, ecosystems and biodiversity, as well as the promotion of climate change. Moreover, the production of palm oil infringes the fundamental rights and freedoms of those involved in the process. Also, palm oil (Dende), the most used in the food industry, according to the European Food Safety Authority of the European Union (EFSA), is carcinogenic. As such, there is a need to step up research and information campaigns on the impact of the use and consumption of palm oil on human health and safety and on the environment, as well as research on the social dimension of palm oil production, use and consumption.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on fraudulent practices in the meat sector in Brazil by Czeslaw Adam Sierkierski, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O-000025 /2017 - B8-0213 / 2017) (2017/2635 (RSP)).

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski
text: author. - Ladies and gentlemen! We take up an important topic for the functioning of the world market, in this case primarily for our trade relations with Mercosur countries. The most important here is the issue of standards and compliance with certain rules, but also the issue of mutual trust between partners. It is in this context that the recent incidents in Brazil should be considered, which are hopefully only incidents and not a constant practice related, first, to the dispatch of substandard meat on the EU market, and second, to breach of the principles of cooperation that underpin commercial relations . We have high standards in the European Union. Our consumers and we all expect the same requirements for imported goods. And here we are talking about food, which has a significant impact on human health. Let me now turn to a question raised by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and prepared with the active participation of many members of our committee, but also of other Members. Operation Carne Fraca - a two-year investigation by the Brazilian federal police into two of Brazil's largest meat processing plants (JBS and BRF) in seven major Brazilian beef-producing states - has raised great concern. The investigation revealed serious fraud and corruption in a sector that introduces potentially dangerous and fraudulent products that pose a risk to European consumers in the food chain. According to investigators, federal inspectors received money in exchange for ignoring counterfeits or expiring processed foods. Sanitary permits and export certificates were also forged. In addition, the investigation showed that chemicals were used to improve the appearance and smell of expired meat, and cheaper products were added to the meat. European consumers are seriously concerned about reports that salmonella-contaminated meat has been exported to Europe and that, to improve in appearance of rotten meat, ascorbic acid was used. Brazil is the world's largest beef and poultry exporter. It is also the largest meat supplier in the EU, which introduces hundreds of thousands of tons of beef and poultry to our market every year. European producers and consumers expect all meat imported into the Union to meet high European food quality standards. 1. Can the Commission provide details of the imports of these contaminated products into the Union, detailing the volume of the suspect products and the European markets to which they have been sold? 2. Why did the European inspection services fail to detect this systemic fraud of placing counterfeit meat on the EU market? What advice will the Commission give to Member States so that they can strengthen controls following these reports? 3. As this scandal raises concerns over food safety, how will these reports affect ongoing trade negotiations with Mercosur? Is it time to review the negotiations and withdraw meat from the trade negotiation agenda? End of question. I presented the question on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and now my short comment. We must use this situation to review our relationship with the rules and control system on the Brazilian side and clearly demand that the errors and shortcomings that occur there be removed. It is important for the Brazilian side to discover these irregularities, and according to information from Brazil, its services have been dealing with this matter for some time. It is a pity, however, that there was no cooperation with the EU in this respect. I believe that the review that I have mentioned may open up a new lease that needs to be included in the negotiations with Mercosur. In the Union, too, we must learn lessons and evaluate our control system. This situation should contribute to better relations in the future and respect by the Brazilian side of EU requirements.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thanks largely to the solid set of legislation, which aims to ensure that food is safe for consumers, the European Union has probably the world’s highest food safety standards. Our European Union system imposes strict hygiene and safety controls on food imports, and in particular on animal products for which systematic documentary, identity and physical checks are compulsory. Immediately after the information became known about the deficiencies in food licensing in Brazil, on 17 March, and following the Commission’s advice, Member States – in addition to the existing documentary and identity controls – introduced reinforced physical controls to ensure the safety of imports from Brazil, focusing on food hygiene requirements. As soon as news came to light about the fraudulent practices in the Brazilian meat sector, the Commission asked the Brazilian authorities to ensure that there were no exports to the EU from any establishments in Brazil that could bear a risk of non-compliance with European Union requirements. We immediately introduced a request to ban the imports from establishments implicated in the scandal; we requested the reinforcement of control checks at EU borders and we made clear to the Brazilian authorities our dissatisfaction, including learning of this crisis in the media rather than through official channels. We continue to ensure that Member States authorities are continuously informed about the evolution of the situation; we are preparing urgent audits of Brazil. In addition, let me stress that all consignments currently en route to the EU from the establishments implicated in the fraud will be rejected and returned to Brazil. The importance of the controls on imports at the point of entry to the EU – at border inspection posts – is crucial. The Commission is in close contact with the Member States to ensure a harmonised approach as regards these reinforced checks. A full consensus was reached on these reinforced checks and on the way they should be selected. In particular, it was confirmed that there should be 100% physical checks on all consignments presented for import to the EU and 20% microbiological checks. It was also confirmed that importers would be liable for the cost of these reinforced checks. In the light of the outcome of these reinforced checks, the evolution of the situation and the response of the Brazilian authorities to the demands for corrective measures, the Commission and the Member States will decide whether further measures are necessary. In this regard, the protection of European consumers will be the determining factor. The Commission will also undertake audits of Brazil as soon as possible and not later than mid-May. I would like to use this opportunity to thank Members of the European Parliament for their recent vote in favour of the new official control legislation which will enable the Commission to ensure even more vigorous controls of imported food products. Let me also reassure you of my personal commitment to ensure the safety of European consumers. With this objective firmly in mind, I met with the Brazilian Minister of Agriculture, Mr Maggi, last Tuesday in Brazil. I had an open, long and frank discussion with the minister. I asked him to provide more information on the state of play and the next steps that he planned to take. I also stressed the need for Brazil to restore the trust, reliability, predictability and independence of the Brazilian official control system. In addition, I made a point of passing on to the Minister the positions and concerns of the Member States, as well as the requests coming from honourable Members of this Parliament. My services also had a meeting with Brazilian officials on 30 March to further discuss this matter. It was agreed that the minister would send more details about the findings of the investigation and the possible food safety impact. Important progress was also made on two other requests from the EU. First, the Brazilian authorities agreed on concrete steps to solve long-standing applications for export from the EU to Brazil, and to make the approval process more predictable. We also discussed how to improve our cooperation using the bilateral sanitary and phytosanitary mechanism. Second, in relation to avian influenza, Brazil also promised to accept the principle of regionalisation based on region of outbreak. Speaking about possible recognition of the EU as a single entity, the Brazilian counterparts showed some openings. However, more discussions will be needed. In addition, we discussed cooperation on antimicrobial resistance and animal welfare. Just today we received a letter from Minister Maggi informing us, and I quote: ‘the issues investigated by the federal police in the four establishments are authorised to export to the EU are related to conduct misbehaviour and economic fraud not representing any risk to food safety.’ The Minister also informed me of the modification of Brazilian legislation for the inspection of products of animal origin, among other things.   Turning to the negotiations with Mercosur, trade relations between the EU and Brazil currently take place within the framework of the World Trade Organisation. However, the proposed future agreement with Mercosur would not undermine our high safety requirements. Current as well as future imports from Mercosur countries will have to respect these requirements. This will not change. A future EU-Mercosur agreement will not lower our high regulatory standards for food safety. It will not authorise imports of agri-food products if they do not meet our high food safety requirements. The agreement will, however, reinforce cooperation with the authorities of Brazil and other Mercosur countries by means of updated provisions to establish solid information and notification systems in the sanitary and phytosanitary field. This would strengthen our reaction capacity via a privileged channel with the four countries concerned.   To conclude, let me emphasise that current and future imports into the EU will always have to meet the high quality and food standards established by our EU legislation and implemented through a credible certification and control system. Once again, a future EU-Mercosur agreement would not lower our high regulatory requirements and food safety standards for agricultural imports from Mercosur countries, including Brazil.

name: Mairead McGuinness
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his detailed response. However, I have just some comments to make. On our first question we did look for some details and I am not sure that you have provided us with the details we would like. This investigation, which is a criminal investigation, was going on for two years and in that time products that were unfit for purpose were placed on the market and we need more clarity about the extent of it, and where they were sent to.  The second point I would make is in relation to the return of products on the high seas. I have to say, if I were a Brazilian consumer and I heard that this product was being returned to Brazil I would be very frightened. I would want this product destroyed somewhere and to have a guarantee of that if there is any doubt about its quality, because insofar as I worry about European consumers I clearly would have a worry too about Brazilian consumers.  In relation to how this was discovered, probably the only good part of this story is that there was an investigation and the system was found wanting. It reveals an all too close relationship between the industry and those who are inspecting it, and it reveals that where an industry is very large, then it is very powerful. While I like what you are saying, that there would be no lowering of EU standards, these are very fine words but the problem is that if you have this type of activity in an industry that is supplying the European Union today, how can you guarantee that it will not continue tomorrow? So we still have some questions.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President, Commissioner, following the rotten meat scandal and its possible consequences, both for consumers and for European producers, the Commission has chosen not to suspend its imports of meat from Brazil . You have simply removed from the list the four offending companies which had licenses to export to the Union and you have adopted additional hygiene controls for imported meats. These measures are both insufficient and inconsistent. As a new round of trade negotiations has just opened between the European Union and Mercosur, it appears essential to suspend meat imports, at least those from regions where the deficiencies have been noted. The "carne fraca" case involves thirty-three inspectors from the Ministry of Agriculture in this vast network of fraud, so it is indeed the entire system of control of meat certification in Brazil that is put back into action. cause. Under these conditions, Commissioner, what concrete measures do you intend to take to finally protect both consumers and European farmers?

name: James Nicholson
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I thank the Commissioner for what he has said tonight. This scandal, when I raised it in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development – with the full support of the committee – certainly brought home to us how dangerous this situation can be. But I say to the Commissioner: this is not the first time Brazil has pulled the wool over Europe’s eyes. They did it back in 2007 and 2008, and it took a delegation from this Parliament to go out there to prove that your Commission was not telling us everything. So Commissioner, I have to say to you tonight – and the previous speakers and Ms McGuinness have referred to this – you have not answered all the questions that we asked. We need more answers. This is simply not good enough. And if they have pulled the wool over our eyes once again then we have got to ask the question: how long are we going to allow them to do similar actions as they have done in the past? I sincerely hope you are not telling us here tonight that nothing will change, because if that is the case that is unacceptable, certainly from my point of view and from the point of view of consumers throughout the European Union. And you are quite right: you told us here tonight that we in Europe are the best, we have the highest possible standards that anyone can hope for. But that is something that has got to be kept right; and it is not right if we allow other countries to break that. And it is even more wrong that you say talks with Mercosur will go on and the negotiations there will go on. They must be ended as well.

name: Ulrike Müller
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President! The current meat scandal surrounding Brazilian meat is a very sensitive issue for us too. The citizens of the European Union rightly demand that the high and globally recognized standards within the EU also apply to imported goods. This means that these standards for the entire production chain must also be emphatically demanded by our non-European trading partners. In order to be able to draw the right conclusions and take the necessary measures, all facts and backgrounds must be on the table immediately. It is essential to ensure consumer protection. The population expects a clear line here. We must be concerned about this with a view to the future of our trade relations. People want transparency and safe, reliable control and protection systems. Only on this basis can we strengthen confidence in the urgently needed trade agreements. That is why it is also in our interest that we put thoroughness over speed and put a stop to the criminal machinations with a functioning, effective control system.

name: Matt Carthy
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the truth is that if this Commission was prioritising the livelihoods of European farmers and the well-being of European consumers then the recent scandal relating to Brazilian meat imports would have immediately led to withdrawal from the Mercosur trade agreement talks.  Instead, last week, the Commission released a joint statement with the Mercosur trading bloc committing us to concluding a deal as soon as possible. Not a single mention whatsoever in that statement of the complete breakdown in trust following the emergence of the meat scandal just ten days previously. It appears that revelations that rotten meat, meat treated with carcinogenic chemicals, meat mixed with cardboard, that had made its way into the EU under your watch, could not dampen the enthusiasm of this Commission to try to conclude dangerous and regressive trade deals. This time last year Commissioner Hogan told us that beef was temporarily off the table of these negotiations. But where is the follow-up timeline or detail of the conditions under which it will be brought back to the table? Where are the assurances for poultry, the sector which is actually the single largest category of meat consumed in Ireland, for example, and which faces far bigger Brazilian import quotas than even beef? What about the other sectors that stand to be impacted by cheaper, improperly treated agricultural products? Where are the assurances for consumers who should be confident that what they buy in the shops or order in the restaurants is properly treated? At what cost is this Commission actually prepared to continue pushing with these deals? It is time to protect our consumers and to protect our farmers. It is time for you, Commissioner, to ensure that we withdraw from the Mercosur trade talks.

name: Martin Häusling
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Commissioner, you have acted relatively quickly on the case, but the question still arises: what did you do before? Were the controls effective? And you didn't answer the question: Has meat really made it onto the European market? You couldn't definitely answer that. This scandal is not just any trivial matter. Chemicals were added to rotten meat, the meat was contaminated with salmonella - an effective health hazard. That means that the highest level of alert is really announced. And the Commission is now doing a bit of business as usual and says: “No problem, we have it under control.” But the matter is more serious, especially because this scandal has shown that there is a system error in at least 21 production sites . Massive corruption, fraud, even in the highest government agencies - that's not even a small scandal, it's a scandal, so to speak, of the entire Brazilian sector. And that is why the question is: what conclusions do you draw? The subject of the Mercosur negotiations has already been raised several times today. There can be no business as usual here either, you have to draw conclusions. Because what will come of this is likely that consumer standards and safety standards will not rise, but rather that this area will be liberalized again and that consumer protection and the rights of small farmers are of secondary importance at Mercosur. I have to honestly say that I have no confidence in the Brazilian government either. We have seen the Agriculture Minister in the Agriculture Committee, he is himself part of the agribusiness with 200,000 hectares. I have no confidence that if someone like that tries to solve the scandal, the consequences will actually be drawn. We have to as Europeans be consistent.Hence the question: will a delegation, a commission be sent to Brazil on the spot to inspect the production facilities on site and really to take action, Commissioner?

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, this is the second time that the British beef consumers have been let down by the EU. In the first instance our consumers were conned into eating horsemeat when they thought they were eating beef. They were obliged to rely on the EU hack-up process of traceability which is only as good as the least honest person in the food chain. Now we discover that relying on the Commission to monitor the conduct of the Brazilian meat industry is a very naive aspiration. The Commission did not have a clue what was going on as grossly substandard meat arrived on EU shores from Brazil. This is particularly worrying as the Commission had ambitions for yet more Brazilian beef imports in its Mercosur negotiations.  British beef producers are subject to RPA inspections, assurance scheme inspections and the scrutiny of animal rights organisations, whilst the cost of meat processing is higher than it need be due to the EU’s insistence on expensive veterinary surgeons to attend abattoirs when the experienced reliable British meat inspector had done an excellent job. Brexit gives us the opportunity to address these problems.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, what worries us about this scandal is the inability of the Commission to give us the real figures and answer our questions. Is this a debate for nothing? In any case, for the moment, we are not moving forward on this subject. How long have our fellow citizens been exposed to this risk? What quantities are they really involved? What we are seeing is that Chile and China immediately closed their market while the European Commission instead asked Brazil to vaguely review its standards. How is it possible today to ask our European breeders, especially French breeders, to observe maximum health protection standards when we let in rotten meat? Brazil, Ukraine and Turkey are countries riddled with corruption and can nevertheless export. Commissioner, I think it is time to review our standards and ensure that we in Europe can carry out checks paid for by the countries of origin.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, it is vitally important to take food quality and food security seriously and the Brazilian meat scandal has reinforced this message. There can be no place for corruption at the heart of any food supply chain and we must congratulate the Brazilian police for tackling the problem. In Northern Ireland we make enormous efforts to ensure the safety and traceability of our food. However, many of the farmers and processors that I represent are questioning the ability of the Commission to guarantee that product entering the EU is of a comparably high standard. Why did the inspections not uncover this problem and leave it to the Brazilian press to break the story? Why is it that only now additional measures to ensure food safety are being adopted? As the Commission races ahead with the Mercosur trade deal, what measures will be put in place to ensure food standards and consumer safety?  Many farmers in Northern Ireland believe that the Commission has a laissez-faire attitude to imports which is quite contrary to the stringent and over-burdensome requirements placed on them. What we need is a full investigation. All affected plants must be delisted from exporting to the EU and any product from these plants removed from the food chain. If we do not get a satisfactory response from Brazil, then we should be prepared to consider a ban on imports until such times as we have a proper reassurance.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: - Dear Commissioner, this is about food safety, this is about transparency and, above all, it is about fair competition. The Brazilian meat scandal is a mockery of the European production and animal welfare standards, and I believe that the loss of trust is really enormous here and that we were shown massive weaknesses in the EU checks on food imports. But I also ask myself where our consumer advocates are, who normally, especially when it comes to European production standards, cannot be strict enough when it comes to controls. Anyone who wants to have access to the European market has to adhere to the same European standards as the European producers, and I really think it's very important to say that too. It is high time that we finally slowed down the Mercosur negotiations and the agreements on the agricultural chapter and instead really gave gas to the development of quality external protection. Consumers and farmers must be able to rely on the fact that imports are subject to the highest levels of control and quality.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, this oral question concerns an issue of undeniable importance, since such important issues as food security and the safeguarding of public health are at stake. The entry into the European space of spoiled meat cannot be tolerated, regardless of where it comes from. It is the responsibility of the Community authorities to continue the necessary steps to determine what happened and to immediately overcome it. What we cannot do is use this unique case as a pretext to call into question the success of the ongoing negotiations aimed at establishing a trade association agreement between the European Union and Mercosur. In fact, it is worth remembering that this case was detected and reported by the Brazilian authorities themselves and that it affects a very small part of the vast universe of meat production in that country. It refers to 22 companies, of which only 4 exported to the European Union. The European Commission has already come, and rightly so, to affirm that the current situation of Brazilian meat does not represent, in any way, an obstacle for the negotiations of the EU-Mercosur agreement. Let us jointly resolve this phytosanitary problem with the Brazilian authorities. We do not fall into the temptation to turn it into a serious commercial relationship problem between two regional blocs that have every interest in guaranteeing their approximation on the political, economic, cultural and also commercial levels.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Taking the floor in the debate on Brazil's import into the EU - beef meat that is potentially dangerous for consumers - I would like to point out that the EU veterinary and sanitary services did not detect this, and we found out about the matter from the media. However, such a practice took place and lasted for months, which is confirmed by the investigation of the Brazilian police, which was carried out, among others, against the largest beef processing plants. In 2016 alone, over 145,000 were imported from Brazil. tonnes of beef, which accounts for as much as 42% of all imports of this meat to the countries of the Community, and there is no doubt that meat that is dangerous for consumers has found its way to European tables, which proves the enormous scale of threat to public health. Against this background, the increased controls proposed by the Commission on imported Brazilian meat are rather half-measures. In my opinion, until this scandal is resolved, the import of beef from this country should be banned.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: - Dear colleagues, Commissioner, from veal to steak and from piglet to shoulder ham, European farmers and our meat processing industry meet the highest food safety standards.Outright fraud in Brazil with meat is therefore hard.Food safety must be guaranteed.It is therefore very important that we get all the facts on the table as quickly as possible.When did it become clear that food safety was at stake?Where did the meat end up?We must prevent these kinds of scandals in the future and we can expect crystal-clear guarantees.In addition, it cannot be explained that despite our very strict requirements, Europe is not allowed to export beef and veal to Brazil.Conversely, Brazil can still export its meat to the EU.I think we should defend our interests better, because this is the world upside down.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Commissioner, but I must say that your words worry us because from what you have said to us it appears that we know nothing about the past. You spoke of the future, of what we will do, but not of what it has been. We became aware of this scandal thanks to the Brazilian investigative authorities. So I ask myself: and how did European customs behave? It has already happened in the past that something has arrived in Europe via European ports that should not have arrived - I am referring for example to the case of Xylella. So I wonder if this is a carelessness or a desire to place products on the European market and then generate pockets of unfair competition. This approach cannot be good for us. We have no assurance from the Brazilian health authorities that they are part of the process that caused this rotten meat scandal. Plus, we don't know where we've come. We don't know where this meat got, we don't know who ate it, we don't know if it hurts, we don't know anything. So, beyond the resolutions for the future, I hope that we will also have information to know if today we have attacked the health of European citizens.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the food security of the citizens of the European Union cannot and should not be taken lightly. I would like to congratulate the Commission for the diligence in its reaction, for the visit to Brasilia and the meeting with the Minister of Agriculture, and also the Brazilian authorities for having uncovered this case. It is a case that is coming, as Mr. Assis recalled, limited to a small number of cases. In any case, one thing is the food security of our citizens and another thing is to take advantage of to pull by elevation against the European Union-Mercosur Association Agreement. I would like to recall that the Heads of State and Government, meeting in Rome, have called for a more active European Union on the international scene. And I wish to recall that the last European Council unanimously decided to support these negotiations. And you decided to support them, Madam President, not because of anything special, but because the European Union and its citizens and its companies pay more than € 4.5 billion a year in tariffs, which naturally redound to the benefit of our citizens and our companies. That is why, obviously, I insist that the European Union can conclude an agreement that respects the security demands of our citizens, a balanced and ambitious agreement in the best possible timeframe between the European Union and Mercosur.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Ms. President!I think of this whole situation that it would be a great pity to hit the Brazilian side in, say, the Mercosur negotiations, given that all benevolence can be assumed from both sides.But the fact that some fraudulent companies, fraudsters, criminals have taken advantage of the weaknesses of the European system is a fact.In English, we have the right answer, if we strengthen our own border controls, food controls and our whole system at all, in such a way that it is so strong, it is so visible that no one can think of going here, to this area., spoiled or poisoned consignments to that continent.I think we should sweep a little in front of our own doorstep and not necessarily shout for an immediate ban, but for much stronger control.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: - While European producers must meet the highest food safety standards, the Brazilian meat sector has instantly damaged that confidence.This is a very serious matter.I therefore have a number of questions for the Commission.To begin with, the most important one, and colleague Huitema already spoke about it: how is it possible that Europe time and again gives opportunities to the Brazilian meat sector, while Brazil has for years refused to use European meat, including veal for which it has no competition whatsoever,to be allowed on the Brazilian meat market?This is a very unfair situation and I therefore ask the Commission to address this problem appropriately.Brazilian government officials are involved in the scandal.Does it also concern officials at the top of the ministry?Finally, has the FVO visited the affected companies in the past?To what extent do the audits look at the traceability of meat after the moment of packaging?
