name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I thank my colleague for his oral question. We must relay the concerns raised by this health scandal both among consumers and beef farmers. It is legitimate to wonder about the place of beef in the negotiations of the agreement with Mercosur. If it is excessive to want to end this agreement, this matter should not be underestimated. This scandal gives concrete expression to the concerns denounced for several years by cattle farmers and must be taken very seriously by the Commission. Within the framework of negotiations with Mercosur, two risks must be taken into account: the health risk for consumers and the economic risk for the livestock sectors. In the absence of firm measures to guarantee the protection of consumers and beef farmers, the message sent by the Commission will be such as to reinforce citizens 'Euroscepticism and farmers' rejection of European institutions. Remember that the spirit of the CAP is to protect European agriculture. I reaffirm that agriculture cannot be an adjustment variable in trade negotiations.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in the face of the scandal that has hit the meat sector in Brazil in recent weeks, we strongly urge the Commission to ensure timely measures to protect the health of European consumers, and we ask the Brazilian authorities tomaximum collaboration in ascertaining responsibilities and safeguarding one's credibility.Let me stress, however, that what we are debating today is serious commercial fraud, which must not be used as an excuse for a possible halt to negotiations with Mercosur.Conversely, an agreement will be able to provide a more solid legal framework for the protection of European citizens.Negotiations are at a crucial stage today, and while others are proposing trade wars and protectionism, we should not miss the opportunity to strengthen existing links with this strategic area for the European Union.

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I am saddened to hear so many colleagues using this crisis is an opportunity to trot out their dogmatic anti-global views. Our reaction to the Brazilian meat scandal should not be a purely protectionist attitude. Suggestions that the scandal could undermine the negotiation of the EU-Mercosur Agreement are not only unhelpful, they are also disproportionately excessive in my view.  Four plants eligible to export to the EU were implicated in the scandal. This is very manageable in terms of an investigation. Moreover, given the increasingly interdependent nature of the global environment such a closed-minded approach would be counter-productive and damaging at a much broader level. The focus should be on finding ways better to uphold Europe’s high standards. This applies both to the delivery of consumers’ expectations for quality as well as ensuring that the EU producers are not penalised for adapting to ensure these standards are maintained.  I would like to see a full report identifying lessons that we can learn and measures to be enforced. I know that Mr Siekierski summed up our questions at the beginning and we would like to hear full answers.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: - A few words as President of the Delegation for Relations with Brazil. Firstly, to emphasize that the words to be conveyed to our fellow citizens must be enlightening, calm and trustworthy. In fact, the authorities on both sides of the Atlantic acted quickly and, as far as we know, also effectively. However, we have a market under pressure and if today we talk about Brazilian meat, in the past we have already talked about mad cow disease, poorly labeled equine meat, bird flu, in short, even the warnings of the World Health Organization. in fact, when meat is on the plate few consumers know its origin or nationality. We are facing a problem that affects everyone, not just meat producers in a particular country. Therefore, companies in this value chain with sales in Europe are required to strictly comply with the legislation, but the competent authorities are also required to ensure this compliance. Secondly, to reaffirm that we are facing a judicial case. Therefore, I underline the merit of the investigation by the Brazilian authorities, who identified these irregular practices, as well as the speed, transparency and effectiveness of subsequent actions. In conclusion, I recall that the Trade Agreement between Mercosur and the European Union is welcome, because, in addition to the obvious economic benefits, it will reinforce the proximity and cooperation between our peoples.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, we are undoubtedly facing a major fraud because it affects such substantive elements as food safety and public health. Therefore, a great concern is generated among citizens and it should be clarified; Let these discussions serve to clarify it. Apparently, the detection is made by the Brazilian authorities. I am concerned about the European part. What about inspections? How are they made? It is being said that the inspections that are made are basically documentary, and that the percentage of physical inspection is not carried out. Therefore, we are calling into question import controls on products like this meat that comes from Brazil. Furthermore, I do not know if it is the fault of the controls of the Member States or the inspection of the European Union. It is convenient to clarify all these aspects, because without a doubt there is a big problem: that the citizenship has a distrust towards these productions. It is good to clarify it and not to confuse it with other debates.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: - The call from the Brazilian authorities to maintain confidence in their meat sector has surprised us, especially as inspectors from the Ministry of Agriculture were involved in the fraud scandal. This government has also been blocking the import of European meat, veal, for years because it says it has no confidence in us. That is crazy for words, especially when you know that our European meat industry in particular is one of the most important in the world, the world top. This does not apply to Brazilian producers who, among other things - and I am not just saying that - use large quantities of chlorinated water for disinfection. That should not happen to our producers, there should be nothing to it. This is prohibited in the Netherlands and Europe. Nevertheless, Brazilians earn up to 12 billion annually from meat exports to Europe. Mr President, Commissioner, our farmers simply have the right to a level playing field and if they want to maintain confidence in Europe - everyone is working hard on it - then we must do something now.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Dear Commissioner, The first thing that comes to mind is: We also need the mandatory indication of origin for processed meat, and we also need it in the catering industry, because only then does the consumer have the chance to make an informed decision where the meat he has on his plate comes from. In the European Union we will soon have a new system of official controls that has been tightened in many areas. There we want to control from farm to fork. It will be stricter, we will have more transparency, we will have more independence, we will try to avoid conflicts of interest. We have built in the whistleblower so that there is a possibility that information may also go out here in order to access these unlawful processes, e.g. B. in production companies. It won't help us if the strict import controls take place on imports, but if we are in areas such as B. animal welfare cannot rely on our partners. We also need provisions in the trade agreements that urge that our very strict laws that apply in Europe also apply to our importers along the entire production and distribution chain.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: - Madam President, European farmers have made great efforts over the years to produce better, with high standards in the world, the highest standards in terms of animal welfare, food safety and, in the case of beef production, with individual traceability, as required by European legislation. It is, of course, important that Europe, when importing animals from third countries, requires, at least, exporting countries the same requirements that it makes to European farmers so as not to destroy the confidence that consumers have in the meat sold in Europe, which so much effort has cost European farmers and so much economic resources to the European Union. In this case we must recognize that it was the Brazilian authorities themselves who reported the case, which means that the inspection in Brazil worked, but at the same time, it means that in the European Union the inspection was not effective, because if the meat was adulterated it was not detected as such in the European Union space and it is about this internal inspection, in the European Union, Madam President, that we must also question ourselves.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: - Commissioner, I have listened very carefully to what you have to say at the beginning of the debate, and I must say that I was disappointed. The failure of the Brazilian control authorities is one thing, but we have a huge hole in the control system in our country in the European Union. How could a lot of spoiled meat be distributed within the EU if the control worked? These days, 21 tons of meat, which contained salmonella and was in salt for 2 years, was withdrawn from distribution in Slovakia. If we had not done so, perhaps children in schools, patients in hospitals, social facilities and regular clients in restaurants would be eating such meat today. There would be 210,000 consumers; 210,000 people would be at risk. Commissioner, please tell us what to say to our people, who are losing confidence in the EU through such cases and are already expanding the advice of Eurosceptics. What guarantees can you give European citizens that unfair commercial practices in the food supply chain will not be repeated? Tell me when you will identify the culprit and when and how he will be punished?

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: - In trade agreements, I have been defending a regulated market that guarantees food safety for products entering the European Union, as well as conditions of fairness regarding their production method. We must protect European farmers from unfair competition by not allowing products to enter without the same production criteria as those we demand in the European Union, guaranteeing fair costs. We cannot accept two criteria, one more permissive for the external and the other more demanding for our farmers. The situation in question is criminal and punctual, but it showed serious flaws in terms of control, which are systemic. Adulterated and additive meat is introduced into the Union, to the detriment of our farmers due to lack of equity. I am in favor of Mercosur, but I am in favor of a “regulated” Mercosur and, at this moment, that is why I defend the review of Mercosur negotiations regarding meat, for the sake of consumer protection and protection of European farmers.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I think there is a credibility issue here. Not so much for Brazil but for the European Commission. The credibility of Brazil has been questioned for a long time, as my colleague Mr Nicholson pointed out. They, Members here, the Irish Farmers Journal, the IFA, exposed the fraudulent activity 10 years ago and here we are with another scandal now. What does the Commission do? Nothing! They are letting down European consumers. We are supposed to have the highest standards in the world within Europe, but we do not for food coming into Europe. The first thing we should do is ban Brazilian beef. Look what happened when BSE struck in Ireland and in Europe. It was banned, and it still has not yet been lifted in some cases. Seventeen years! That is how you act to defend your citizens and your consumers. Tolerating and asking for guarantees is no good. We must ensure that guarantees satisfy us so that our consumers can know that they are getting the highest standard of food within Europe at all times.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, first of all thank you for being here tonight after your meeting with the Council earlier today. I do not think I need to repeat here that your approach will be decisive for the recovery of consumer confidence. I expect the European audit of Brazil scheduled for this spring to be carried out very seriously. It is a necessary condition to restore consumer confidence. In Europe, the emphasis must be on harmonization between Member States, at all levels. Fraudulent operators target the weakest links, where there is the least control and / or the lowest costs. More thorough inspection and adequate testing, throughout the Union, are indispensable. Commissioner, I am Belgian. With us, there is no steak without fries. And I am also concerned about our European fries. Not about quality, nor about safety, but because Brazilian anti-dumping measures have been in force against European frozen chips since February. By the way, I already asked you a written question about this on 7 February. And although I realize that it is not a phytosanitary problem, I still dare to ask you to explain the Commission's approach on this.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: - Commissioner, 145 000 tonnes of meat have been imported from Brazil.Infected meat which is implanted with salmonella, which has been treated with carcinogens and which is distributed in the European Union.Only 21 tons of meat have been distributed to our small Slovakia alone and they were simply already in food establishments, schools and hospitals.I ask you, Commissioner, how it is possible that the European inspectors, our hygienists, the central authorities, the microbiologists, the food chambers did not find out that damaged meat came to us from Brazil.Did we have to find out until Brazil itself discovered this terrible scandal when Brazilian inspectors were bribed by cartels and turned a blind eye to the quality of meat?I ask you, Commissioner, what will you do to ensure that this does not happen again?

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the Brazilian judicial authorities have identified various frauds in some batches of meat exported by Brazil to Europe and other regions of the globe. This is unfortunate! But it must be underlined the effectiveness of the operation that detected the fraud and the quick reaction of the authorities that suspended companies, launched audits and sued the State employees involved. Another dimension of the scandal is the impact it may have on food security in Brazil, or outside it. We must protect consumers. This investigation must go through. However, in this context, it is not acceptable to use this case as a throwing weapon to call into question the trade agreement between the European Union and Mercosur. In the current world economic and political order, letting out a strategic rapprochement between Europe and an important part of Latin America through sectoral calculations, if it were to happen, it would also be a big scandal, a weak view on an operation that is called “weak meat”.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I have a question for the Commissioner. Commissioner, you spoke of the highest safety standards in the EU, but my question is: who is taking responsibility for ensuring the safety of meat imports into the EU? As my colleague Seán Kelly said, this is not the first time. Ten years ago in this Parliament we were discussing the absence of traceability of Brazilian beef, and tonight we are discussing an even bigger scandal which shows systematic failures in controls at all levels in Brazil. European consumers rely on the Commission to ensure safe food. European farmers rely on the Commission to ensure verifiable equivalence in the food products we import. The Commission has failed in this duty. Several countries moved swiftly to ban Brazilian beef. Some have relaxed that ban, but we sat on our hands and failed our citizens and farmers again. It cannot be business as usual in the Mercosur negotiations. The mutual trust that should be there has been shattered.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Andriukaitis talks about current and future safety. I notice he did not talk about our past safety because we have been let down and it is too late on that. Then he goes on to talk about continuing these trade talks, but surely the best way to guarantee the safety of European citizens is to give them access only to meat that comes from the safest system – in other words, from the European Union. Surely it makes sense to have a short supply chain and interestingly enough, I have not heard many people talk here about the fact that we have signed up to doing something about climate change. How on earth, pardon the pun, does it makes sense to bring meat from that far away across the planet and potentially send it the other way – although we are not allowed to do that yet, though potentially with trade talks.  Who is mandating you to do this? Because apparently we are not going to do this. As for safety checks, how can you increase physical checks? What are you going to do – have X-ray vision?  You are already physically checking it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the detected situation of fraud in the meat sector is worrying about the failure of official controls that knew that the meat did not comply with quality standards, but nevertheless did not prevent it from being exported to the European market. In international trade, the trust of partners is crucial, and in this case it is significantly undermined - both in the supervisory services and in the control of products. Such behavior is extremely irresponsible because it calls into question the existing international trade agreements between Brazil and the European Union. This undermines Brazil's credibility in complying with WTO rules in that agreement. This situation calls into question further trade negotiations with the Mercosur countries and forces the Member States of the European Union to raise the level of trust and verification of imported food products in order to protect their citizens. If we cannot trust the declarations and certificates of third countries, then domestic checks are necessary. If there is no mutual trust, there can be no free trade agreement. After all, I always advocate buying homemade, because homemade is best.

name: Paolo De Castro (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the scandal we are discussing requires serious reflection on two distinct but closely related aspects. On the one hand, the protection of our consumers, for which a harmonized approach between the Member States with greater controls, not only on incoming meat, but also on consignments already imported from Brazil, is very necessary; on the other hand, the standards that our operators must respect and which make European products the healthiest and safest in the world. Compliance with these standards, which we as Europeans should be proud of, nevertheless entails heavy costs and sacrifices for EU producers, often placing them at a competitive disadvantage vis-à-vis our global competitors. Therefore, Commissioner, we ask that a more transparent market be guaranteed, also through the trade agreements currently being negotiated and in the future, oriented towards the pursuit of the principle of reciprocity, at international level, of the quality standards applied by the Union. Only in this way will the approach to growth that can be given by an expansion of commercial exchanges be truly enhanced, without reducing the protections enjoyed by our consumers.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to start with this very simple question: who is responsible? Me! I am responsible. I am required to do my best and to be responsible in this situation. I would like to continue my work in this style.  Of course it is not about a trade war, it is not about protectionism, I fully agree with all of you. It is about food safety, about trust, about reliability, predictability and effectiveness of official controls in Brazil and here. Of course the fraud was in Brazil, and we all know very well how it is difficult to detect fraud because we have our own experience when we are speaking about the horsemeat scandal. Now it is very difficult to detect fraud on the ground and the Brazilian police authorities did it. Of course we will ask the Minister once again to provide us with very informative, very detailed information. We will look at such a response from the Brazilian side. As you know, in Brazil they have only three states which have the right to use the European certificate. Twenty-one establishments were involved in this situation. Only four establishments were involved in that scandal.  Of course we will see how to monitor the situation. This is why we have asked to check, to reinforce controls here in the EU – because we are speaking about the past and not only about the future – but we will ask Member States to follow all situations and once again to provide very reliable information after official and enforced controls here in our Union.  Then we will ask also to see how to introduce stricter rules today. We organised two immediate meetings with senior officials, with senior veterinary officials and they all agreed about such a harmonised approach at the moment. As you know, we do not rule out the adoption too of further measures should the situation so require, be it through the outcome of the import controls, the Commission’s audit in Brazil or the information provided by Brazil, and I am ready to inform you after a few months about the situation because it is about food safety, about consumer protection, about our trust and reliability.  Of course, there is no doubt we will do our best in this way, but it is not about war between the EU and Brazil, about war between the EU and Mercosur. This is not the situation when we are speaking about a rule-based trade agreement. A rule-based trade agreement! You need to understand that the EU-Mercosur agreement must be based on rules and of course we will guarantee all possibilities to provide clear instruments to defend food safety standards.  Of course you ask me about statistics. Such statistics are available. I can send you this information additionally. Just to illustrate: in 2016 imports from Brazil of bovine animals meat was EUR 449 million and of poultry EUR 163 million. As I mentioned, of course, you also know that we have a rapid alert system and in this rapid alert system they have all the figures. I do not know about some figures which were mentioned here, they are not in line with our figures which we have in our rapid alert system.  I would like to respond to all of your questions in more detail, but I will be more than happy to continue our discussions and then to provide you addition information after the audit, after the response from the Brazilian side and also after collection of additional new information in the EU.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: in writing.- The Brazilian spoiled meat scandal is worldwide, so much so that China and South Korea have adopted import blocking measures.The EU has only threatened to take the same measures at the moment.It is necessary for European intervention to be urgent, blocking all imports of Brazilian meat, not just that produced and processed by the companies involved in the scandal.Does the Commission intend to take action in this regard?And again: is the Commission monitoring that infected meat has not already arrived in supermarkets and / or on the tables of European citizens, who have the right to public protection of their health?

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - After two years of investigation, the Brazilian federal police have brought to light very serious fraud and episodes of systematic corruption in some meat processing companies. The Brazilian control bodies have maliciously ignored violations of the most basic defense and food safety regulations. We are talking about the falsification of export certificates and health authorizations, to which is added the use of chemical substances to improve the appearance and smell of expired meat. It even appears that salmonella-contaminated meat has been imported into Europe, treated with ascorbic acid to hide its appearance. These are blatant violations of European standards. It is a huge flaw in the correct management of the food supply chain, even more serious because it comes after the reassurances on the effectiveness of controls, also given to this assembly during the discussion on CETA. The credibility of Europe is heavily undermined by these episodes, unacceptable criminal acts that must be countered with rigorous and timely measures to safeguard the health of consumers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. - As the report shows, the fraudulent practices of the Brazilian authorities, and in particular the peripheral states, in relation to the export of unsuitable and dangerous meat to the EU are on the agenda, as they have been a common practice for many years. This is also a result of the uncontrollable tactics prevailing at EU level, which in the context of globalization has opened its gates to mass imports of agricultural and livestock products of dubious quality. In addition, the EU leadership with its policies in the field of the Common Agricultural Policy has literally dismantled agriculture and livestock, leaving the Union essentially dependent on imports to meet the nutritional needs of the European population. For all the above reasons, the principle of Community preference must now be reinstated in order for the EU to protect agriculture and livestock and to pursue a policy that will give it self-sufficiency and adequacy, especially in meat production. In addition, strict controls on meat imports from Brazil and other third countries should be imposed here and now, while strict measures should be imposed to restrict meat imports from third countries.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: In written form. - The scandal with imported beef from Brazil is just the tip of the iceberg. With each regulation in the field of agriculture, we are creating more and more conditions for European producers. At the same time, however, we are increasingly opening up imports from third countries of a number of products. Europe must be a guarantor of the income stability of European cattle breeders, not a destination for products of dubious quality and standards from other parts of the world. I believe that the European Commission's flirtation with third countries, through so-called free trade agreements, must stop. European agriculture is losing its competitiveness, rural areas are losing their livelihoods precisely because of such agreements as the one prepared with Mercosur, of which Brazil is a member. In 2016, the EU imported 66,000 tonnes of fresh and frozen beef from Brazil alone. Cattle breeding is a sector that engages local labor and raw materials, creating a livelihood for several sectors. More protection for European producers means stronger European agriculture, more local production and better quality.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. - According to Health Commissioner Vytenis Andriukaitis at the plenary debate on 3 April 2017, the EU has the highest food safety standards in the world. Nevertheless, as a result of unfair trade practices, meat has entered the European market, putting consumers at risk. While I welcome the strengthening of controls on imported meat from Brazil, there is a need to ensure that such a thing does not happen again, whatever the country. It is important to note that the investigation of the Brazilian authorities has been going on for two years, and during that time the Commission has not sent a single signal that something is wrong. Controls on meat imports from third countries in general need to be strengthened. Brazil is the world's largest exporter of beef and poultry, exporting 400,000 tonnes of meat to the EU each year. European consumers and producers expect all meat imports to meet demanding European norms and standards. I support Mrs Smolková's initiative, which calls for an appropriate response from the European Commission, and therefore I also support the initiatives of my Member State, the Czech Republic, which calls for a ban on meat imports from Brazil following the scandal. I also welcome the rapid response of the State Veterinary Administration, which has analyzed the presence of pathogenic micro-organisms, inhibitory substances (antibiotics) and water-retaining substances in meat on the basis of laboratory samples and found serious errors.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Commissioner, high standards and European controls have completely failed. The European Union has not been able to discover the fraud. I wonder, as well as anyone with common sense, how many more frauds are happening to food imports without being discovered by the European Commission and the States? But this explains how fraudulent methods are used to put food products at low prices in markets around the world, putting people's health at risk and ruining local producers and producers. And it also clearly shows why the big meat companies do not want the labeling of the country of origin, because the business is also in the use of cheap meats in processed from recognized brands. In my country it is said that “nobody sells pesos for four pesetas”, that is, nobody would sell a euro for eighty cents. The solution to all this is to end the export vocation of agrarian and food policies, end the mass circulation of food across the planet, give priority to local production for local and local markets, regulate production and markets and define minimum prices that cover costs and remunerate labor.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - A new food scandal ravages the EU: imports of rotten and unhealthy meat from Brazil. Twenty-one Brazilian companies are under suspicion. Four of them exported meat to the EU. This scandal is the top of a huge iceberg. Between 2000 and now, the Fast Food and Feed Alert System reported 258 notifications about Brazilian meat products and 553 notifications about poultry. Between November 17, 2016 and now, there have been 24 serious reports of Salmonella and 3 of E.coli in frozen meat and chicken. This scandal is linked to intensive agricultural techniques that are causing massive deforestation of the Cerrado, a savannah-like area where deforestation is 2 to 3 times faster than in the Amazon. This also has a direct impact on human rights: 207 environmental activists were murdered between 2010 and 2015. The former FVO organized 3 audits in 2016 and found that the export of meat did not meet European export standards. Yet that had no effect on trade. The FVO is doing an incredible job, but there is insufficient political control over the follow-up to their conclusions and recommendations. That is why I am calling for an annual political debate on the recommendations of the FVO.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Brazilian federal police recently revealed a gigantic scheme of fraud and sale of adulterated meats involving the main brands in the country. There were 29 companies investigated, including the two giant JBS, of the brands Friboi, Seara and Big Frango, and BRF, owner of Sadia and Perdigão. Among the list of irregularities investigated, the repackaging of products at the end of their validity stands out, water injection to increase the weight of the goods and the use of ascorbic acid and sorbic acid to make up signs of meat degradation. Both acids are carcinogenic when used in high doses. These crimes are associated with a network of corruption involving officials from the official inspection and control services. It is essential that the European Commission assess this scandal coming from what is today the world's largest meat exporter and the largest supplier of beef to the European Union and that it takes measures to protect consumers and avoid any doubts about the quality of meat sold in space. European. It is also imperative that this issue has consequences for the current negotiations with Mercosur.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Werner Kuhn on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council defining the characteristics of fishing vessels (recast) (COM (2016) 0273 -C8-0187 / 2016 - 2016/0145 (COD)).

name: Werner Kuhn
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner! Now there is another brief change, the individual areas of expertise being redistributed, Commissioner Vella. I also greet the representatives of the Maltese Presidency. I would like to thank everyone who has contributed to this report. That is certainly a very technical report, but it is also a very comprehensive and important report. And it is necessary that the regulation defining the information on fishing vessels be made very clear. Technical and physical information must be consistent. The current status of this information from the fishing vessels is summarized in this regulation. Every Member State has to submit a fleet report almost every year on its small, medium-sized and deep-sea fishing vessels, and for this they naturally also need precise information on how ships are measured, what propulsion power they have and similar things. Up until now, the information on fishing vessels was regulated in the 1986 regulation - at that time still EEC. But against the background of simplifying Union law, i.e. making it clearer and easier to understand, this legal act has of course now been codified in a new version, so to speak. That means a systematic summary of the law applicable to a certain area in a coherent body of law, so that one does not always have to merge it into different paragraphs. The material content of this codified legal act was retained in full, and it is only a necessary adjustment to the current status of the International Organization for Standardization, to which all member states belong. The regulation regulates the legal content, the definition of this information: length over all, width, the tonnage - that is, the gross tonnage - the displacement according to Archimedes, the engine power - that is, which bollard pull, which fishing device can be carried there with a corresponding towing power - and of course the ship register and the date when the ship was put into service. The same characteristics must be used for all member states in the European Union. Because these are of course things that are important, even when it comes to restrictions on very specific fishing areas, then fishing vessels up to eight meters - small artisanal fishing - of course have different options than those that are twelve meters and larger. Those over 15 meters must have an electronic log, they must have a vessel monitoring system and also the AIS, the automatic ship identification system. That is why it is necessary for us to come to an agreement on the conventions on which, so to speak, the Member States are also based: the 1969 International Ship Surveying Convention of London and also the International Convention on the Safety of Fishing Vessels and their Crew - that is the Convention from Torremolinos - both under the auspices of the International Maritime Organization. Alignment with the Treaty of Lisbon - I have already mentioned this - is necessary and entails a delegation of powers in the form of delegated acts. But here you especially have the engine power, the towing power in mind. The Commission originally requested that the delegated acts should not be time-limited. But we did that together in Parliament, for five years. It is a legal exercise, so to speak, and it is necessary that we address these characteristics of fishing vessels together. One more word on the amendment proposed by the GUE and my colleague Ní Riada. We discussed whether it is possible to include such an amendment. But unfortunately the big problem is that we're here fail to find a coherent adaptation.We see it as very difficult to define exactly what small fishing vessels are, which medium-scale and which deep-sea fishing vessels are, given the characteristics of the ships, where lengths and propulsion power are involved.I think we should look at the subject again in a different situation.Thank you all again, I look forward to the debate.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would also like to thank my colleague, Werner Kuhn, the rapporteur on this file, for the very clear explanation that he has just given.  The Commission welcomes the agreement reached between the two co—legislators on our proposal concerning the recast of the regulation on characteristics for fishing vessels. As Werner explained, this is essentially a technical exercise consisting in codifying a rather old legal text dating back to 1986 and updating an empowerment to the Commission in accordance with the provisions of the Lisbon Treaty. The Commission attaches great importance to simplifying and clarifying the law of the Union so as to make it clearer and more accessible and understandable to citizens. For this reason the codification of rules that have frequently been amended is essential to make the law clearer and more transparent. The agreement reached in February is a step forward in this direction. I would like to thank the rapporteur once again.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I think it is true to say that many sectors are very concerned about the fallout that may occur in relation to Brexit. In Ireland, the fishing industry is definitely a sector that is really concerned about what the terms of Brexit will be and what will transpire in relation to territorial waters, quotas and maximum sustainable yield, etc. For that reason the concerns, especially, of our coastal communities and their mainly small vessels fishing within quota, have to be taken into consideration, and the proposal by my colleague Liadh Ní Riada is one that tries to make that distinction. One size does not fit all and while we have to continually reform the common fisheries policy we have to be cognisant of the fact that there are big and small countries, big and small fishing vessels, and that each of them must be considered and given their due regard, especially where we, the coastal communities of Ireland, are concerned.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, I would like, first of all, to thank the rapporteur, Mr Kuhn, for the debate we have had on this dossier, which is very technical, but he is a great connoisseur of this matter and has helped all the others, we were not as expert as Mr. Kuhn. So I want to thank you for the work we have been able to do - myself as shadow rapporteur for my group. Fisheries policy manages and sets the maximum limit of the total capacity of the fishing fleets of the Member States in terms of engine power and vessel tonnage, taking into account the available fishing resources. A significant number of European Union regulations, especially in the framework of the latest reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, also refer and apply to fishing vessels based on their power, tonnage and other technical characteristics such as length. , the width and the date of entry into service. All these aspects are very important - they have always had it - but with the latest reform of the common fisheries policy they have a unique value and required, in addition to seniority - to which the commissioner has referred; the antiquity of some rules that we had in 1986—, also an adaptation to reality after the new reform of the common fisheries policy. And that is what we are going to do. The Commission has also been given more power in those delegated acts for their subsequent application and, therefore, here is a great agreement of all the groups that will be ratified tomorrow with the vote. And finally, I do want to say to Mr Kuhn, when he has referred to the amendment in which he says that a distinction must be made between deep-sea fishing boats and small-scale fishing, that I agree with that background. Probably, the procedure is not technically adequate, but basically I agree and we will vote favorably, Mr. Kuhn.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Madam President, I congratulate Rapporteur Kuhn and the shadow rapporteurs on a quality report that addresses certain legislative problems that have been an administrative obstacle to citizens in exercising their rights for many years. Unfortunately, both in this House and in national and regional parliaments there is a clear trend of complicating regulations written by expert experts and the common man in this forest of various rules and norms often fails. This report is the complete opposite and therefore the path in the right direction. Regulation must be as simple as possible and as applicable as possible in order to achieve the desired effects. It must be clear to those concerned, not just to experts. It is good that an initiative has been launched to codify the 1986 Regulation on the characterization of fishing vessels, as the harmonious implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy implies equal rules and definitions. However, as I have repeatedly pointed out in this House, the Common Fisheries Policy must take into account regional and local specificities and the socio-economic and cultural significance of fishing in individual regions. Therefore, I am particularly pleased that in the codification process, in addition to the technical characteristics of the vessels themselves, their social role in coastal communities as well as their environmental performance and fishing capacity will be taken into account. I consider this proposal to be a big step in the right direction and that is why I will support it in the vote.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner; The regulation that we are presenting today - and I would also like to thank Mr Kuhn, the rapporteur, for the effort he has made to ensure that we have reached such a broad agreement - is of vital importance for two reasons. In the first place, because it will be fundamental to be able to determine the conditions of all the Member States to see their fishing capacity and because it offers guarantees so that the degree of respect of the capacity limits established in the basic Regulation of the PPC. For this reason, it provides legal certainty and clarity to all types of operations that are related in the Union to the exercise of the fishing profession. In order to achieve this, this Regulation has proceeded to establish a definition of all the parameters that serve to define and describe fishing boats, such as length, tonnage beam, date of entry into service and engine power, which it will allow these definitions to apply to all European Union fisheries rules. To make these definitions we have looked at the initiatives of specialized international organizations and, of course, for specific aspects such as engine power, at the standards of the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) that are usually applied to the measures that they are adopted in other sectors of activity. Finally, they are definitions consistent with the common fisheries policy, and this will allow us to give coherence to all the policies and all the regulations of this Chamber.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, Táim tar éis leasuithe mar a luaigh an tUasal Coonan san áit chéanna a mholadh ar reachtaíocht iascaigh maidir le tréithriú agus sonrú árthaí iascaireachta. Agus cé gur ghlac an Coiste leis seo níor cheadaigh an Chomhairle é, agus tá lochtanna an-mhór sa reachtaíocht mar nach sonraíonn sí idir iascaireacht mhionscála nó thraidisiúnta agus iascaireacht thionsclaíoch. Is cúis náire é gur chuaigh siad i gcoinne mo leasuithe maidir le tréithriú árthaí a thabharfadh aird ar ról sóisialta na n-árthaí, ar a dtionchar timpeallachta, cumas iascaireachta, éifeachtúlacht bhreosla, aschur agus scála. Tá dualgas ar an reachtaíocht tacú mar ba léir le rialáil na monarchana mara seo a dhéanann damáiste don timpeallacht, dár bpobail, agus dár n-iascairí mionscála. Cuireann an Comhbheartas Iascach, cobhsaíocht choibhneasta, agus córas ITQ rialtais anois ar a gcumas éisc a bhronnadh ar na creachadóirí idirnáisiúnta agus ag an am céanna gnáthiascaireacht a chuir ar mhíbhuntáiste. Tá gá le tréithriú agus sonrú teicniúil ceart a dhéanfaidh idirdhealú idir na hárthaí móra agus na cinn bheaga. Agus glaoim ar an bParlaimint vótáil ar son mo ráiteas a bheith curtha leis an iarscríbhinn. Agus tá súil agam go gcomhlíonfaidh an tUasal Coonan a gheallúint chun forbairt a dhéanamh ar an reachtaíocht seo agus plé a dhéanamh liom mar gheall air sa todhchaí.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I also want to congratulate the rapporteurs for their work. This Regulation is important, but it does not respond to one of the main ambitions in Europe's small fishing world in terms of definitions. It does not define what artisanal fishing is. It seems to me that the role of the European Union, in this case, will be to establish general rules so that this definition can be established regionally. In fact, artisanal fishing depends on the region where it is practiced. I know that giving up the power of standardization is a difficult step for the European Commission, also for the Council and, to a certain extent, for Parliament, which dream of harmonizing legal procedures across an entire continent. But, in the same way that Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union enshrines regional specificities, I suggest that the Commission propose legislation that gives Europe's regions the ability to define their artisanal and traditional fishing.

name: Czesław Hoc (ECR).
text: - Madam President!First of all, thanks and congratulations to Mr Werner Kuhn for a very good report.However, I have an important point to raise regarding the scope of the definition of fishing vessels.Well, it should be extended and it should distinguish vessels intended for commercial fishing, the so-calledfeeders, from small-scale fishing vessels, the so-calledboaters.This is very important, especially for the Baltic Sea, which is a fragile ecosystem where industrial fishing destroys fish stocks, mainly cod stocks.It also leads to the bankruptcy of coastal fishing.It is therefore necessary to establish a legal definition of industrial-scale fishing and a definition of small-scale coastal fishing.We must protect the cod stocks in the Baltic Sea, we must protect traditional small-scale fisheries.This is our sacred duty - to present and future generations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, I had asked in the previous catch-the-eye debate early enough to speak, but unfortunately you did not have me on the list. The Commissioner said that we are codifying legislation in 1986. But, Commissioner, have you ever wondered what has happened to fisheries thirty years ago? If European fisheries have developed, what social problems and what levels of unemployment does it face? Therefore, this is an issue that should concern us particularly in relation to the Greek fishermen, who are currently mourning, as they face the enormous anti-popular measures imposed by the troika. I agree that a distinction must be made between small and large fishing vessels. Legislation must also cease to be complicated, there must be no administrative burden, no costs and excessive costs. These are issues that we must take into account, as well as the social specificities of coastal communities.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: - I support the unification and codification of this issue and, in fact, the simplification of legal rules as much as possible, especially since the existing ones date back thirty years or more.Of course, it must be said that fisheries policy is a very complex process, where it is necessary to take into account local specifics, where it is necessary to take into account environmental aspects and also what colleagues before me said: the distinction between t.i.small-scale fisheries, artisanal fisheries, on the one hand, and industrial fishing, on the one hand, because they have a completely different impact on many sectors.Of course, unification requires, even very much, clarity of texts, even though it is a technical document.Above all, there must be very clear and concrete and coherent definitions of terms in order to avoid things being interpreted differently and then the Member States not taking them into account as they should.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their constructive attitude towards this file. As already mentioned, rightly, the purpose of this proposal was to undertake a codification of Council Regulation No 2930/86 of 22 September 1986 defining the characteristics for fishing vessels. The new regulation will supersede the various acts incorporated in it and this proposal fully preserves the content of the acts being codified and, hence, does no more than bring them together with only such formal amendments as are required by the codification exercise itself. Further to codifying the above-mentioned regulation, the Commission proposal also includes a substantive amendment with a view to delegating powers to the Commission to this end. As a result, the proposal is being presented in the form of a recast. With regard to the two amendments refused, they were refused on formal procedural grounds as they would change the law. So this is a recast, but we still take note of all the concerns and all the comments. I would like again to thank Mr Kuhn, the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs, and all the MEPs who contributed to this debate.

name: Werner Kuhn
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! Many thanks to my colleagues as shadow rapporteurs. I was also very pleased to incorporate constructive suggestions from you into this dossier. With the basic regulation, we repeatedly came to the point: How can we promote small-scale and artisanal fishing in a special way? And the definition, as Ricardo Serrão Santos said earlier, is highly complicated and very different from region to region. And Mrs Ní Riada, it is difficult to include in this very formal file - it is a regulation - now a definition of small-scale and artisanal fishing, fishing vessels centimeters in length over everything, displacement and engine power - that can be done in another country to be completely different than in Ireland - or to define large factory ships exactly what propulsion power they may have, what size, how much frost, catch and processing capacity, how much tonnage, how much fuel they are allowed to carry and, and, and. That is why I would make the proposal - because that is the only dissent we have on this dossier, on this regulation - that the coordinators meet at the next meeting or the next but one, perhaps with the support of the Commissioner, that an own-initiative report be drawn up on this and tries to define the definition - especially with regard to small-scale and small-scale fisheries and of course also medium-scale fishery vessels and of course deep-sea fishing vessels - in such a way that the individual Member States have the opportunity to make a clear regional distinction For small-scale and coastal fishing or deep-sea fishing vessels and also normal tugs that are over 15 meters where the vessel monitoring system is and the AIS, automatic information system, and maybe we'll get a solution there and take a step further.Many thanks again to everyone, the Commissioner, my rapporteurs, but also the Maltese Presidency, which as an island already has a lot of experience in fishing, but also in shipbuilding, and that made a particular impression on me as a shipbuilding engineer.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, April 4, 2017.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next order of the day is the report by Marijana Petir and Maria Lidia Senra Rodriguez, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on womenand their roles in rural areas (2016/2204 (INI)) (A8-0058 / 2017).

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their contributions and also the teams that made this report possible. In rural areas, different types of women live with different professions and, like all women, they suffer the consequences of a patriarchal system that oppresses, discriminates and makes them unfeasible. Despite the progress of the laws on equality, we see that there is a long way to go. Existing laws do not fully apply or are often implemented on a macho basis. This impeded the advancement of our rights. I hope that this report on women in rural areas will help to strengthen the fight and to move forward in terms of full recognition of the rights of rural women. The challenges are important: in the professional sphere, in that of conciliation, in the scope of public services and in the fight against macho violence. The wage gap between men and women persists and unemployment affects women to a greater extent. I am going to refer, above all, to the situation of women farmers. The policies of deregulation of production and markets, driven by the CAP, have caused the precariousness and loss of many jobs on farms and in rural areas. Failure to recognize shared ownership on family farms implies that only 30% of female farmers in the European Union own farms. All other women in this type of farm are deprived of the rights that derive from being the holder of the same. We are referring, for example, to economic income and CAP rights. These women also face difficulties in receiving aid under positive action measures to support working women, as has already been the case in many Member States. The way in which the CAP distributes aid, favoring large farms, it also harms women, who normally own smaller farms. For example, in 2013, on average, a farm managed by a woman is 8 hectares, compared to 20 hectares on farms managed by men, or 8 livestock units compared to 26 of men. But there is also the fact that many women farmers are not considered as such because they do not contribute to agricultural social security. Others, on the other hand, have a few years of contribution when they reach retirement age and this deepens the pension gap and brings higher levels of poverty to women. It is essential, therefore, to tackle this situation of discrimination and insecurity for women at the root if we really want to keep the farms that are the fundamental economic base for the development of a living rural environment. It is proposed in this report the need for Member States and the Commission to bet on shared ownership in family farms, namely through the drafting of laws aiming at their establishment and their effective application where it already exists. The participation of women in all areas of decision-making, such as institutions, unions, cooperatives and also in the negotiation processes must be guaranteed. Public and quality services should target the countryside, education, health, social services, transport or postal services. To conclude, I would like to say that it is essential to provide the rural environment with instruments for the implementation of measures aimed at preventing and eradicating sexist violence and that support and counseling services be guaranteed for women affected by this violence.

name: Marijana Petir
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, women living in rural areas deserve our full attention and our full commitment. Their problems are real and in order to understand them, we need to understand the diverse role of women in rural areas. They take care of the family, preserve tradition and the environment, work in agriculture, which is one of the most important economic branches of every country, participate in the process of food production. Women in rural areas are invaluable for their family farms, they are also important for the development of entrepreneurship, sustainable development, as well as overall economic development. But they are not a homogeneous group, so I advocate a specific approach to their diverse roles. Women in rural areas do not have good access to education, computer literacy is weak, and the availability of the Internet is still very low. Also, due to the distance of specialist doctors and unavailable diagnostics, in most cases women come to the doctor only in the advanced stage of the disease, which is unfortunately sometimes too late for them. In the countryside, there is usually no adequate social, communal and communal infrastructure that is necessary for a dignified life. Women make up less than 50% of the total working age population in rural areas of the European Union and manage only 30% of family farms. During 2014, women accounted for about 35% of total working time in agriculture, which is a significant contribution to agricultural production, and in addition, farms take care of the family and household, which is often characterized as "invisible" work. Women in the countryside are often economically dependent on their husbands. There are no working hours for them, and they also struggle with the lack of basic social and pension rights, such as significantly lower pensions or unpaid maternity leave. Almost half of them never go on holiday, and participate to a very small extent in decision-making processes at the local and regional level. No member state The European Union has not yet established a thematic sub-program for women in rural areas, such as the one for young farmers, although this is provided for by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, which is a clear indication that women in rural areas are simply not valued enough. This Report recognizes the invaluable contribution that women make to the rural economy and encourages Member States to make more and more synergistic use of the instruments available under the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development, Leader + and the European Social Fund. Women need easier access to land and all social rights they do not currently have because their work on the family farm is not recognized and valued, so the professional status of rural women needs to be regulated. I hope that this Report will help raise awareness of the problems faced by women in rural areas and that in this sense it will be a step towards solving them. Women in the countryside are real heroines and that is why I dedicate this Report to them.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I myself come from a rural region and I know that life in the countryside is really more complicated. There are fewer job opportunities, especially for highly skilled professions, poorer access to services, trade, schools and medical care. This is what affects women, who mostly take care of children and need these services. I know many small and small municipalities that manage to support these services, to create a better environment, precisely with the support of European Union funds or government programs. I think this is a good example of how the better position of women can be addressed. I consider the special view from the point of view of women on this issue to be rather artificial, but I respect it. Rural development is important for society as a whole, for food security, for maintaining and creating the landscape, it is important for maintaining our traditions and cultural roots. I would like to thank my colleague Petirová for supporting rural development for fighting for it and for sensitiveing ​​the needs of women.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank my colleague, Marc Tarabella, for his work on this report, which recognises the role of women as entrepreneurs in rural areas. It is indeed important for the Commission and Member States to invest in the empowerment of women in entrepreneurship in rural areas. It is also important to invest in access to technology and connectivity to the internet and in promoting education and training for women and girls in business, science, technology, engineering and green jobs, especially in places where such facilities are lacking. We should also emphasise the role of cooperatives, social enterprise and alternative business models in providing a powerful platform for women’s economic empowerment and independence. The EU can make a significant positive impact with more funding in that field, as has happened with the ESF and ERDF programmes, such as Leader funding for rural areas like Cumbria, and the Daphne programme for women.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, Commissioner, the main problem at the moment in the Common Agricultural Policy is that there is huge unemployment and poverty and that is what you have to see. The report itself says that between 2005 and 2010, 2.4 million farms disappeared, which means that things are very difficult. So in relation to women, who suffer the most in the agricultural economy - the work they do is not recognized, they have no pay, no pensions - we need to take action, and I think the report addresses the issues. There must be arrangements for women's entrepreneurship, for the reinforcement of new technologies, for training, for the integration of women in a modern way in agricultural production. Also, small women's cooperatives must be strengthened, the position of women in the management of cooperatives must be upgraded and there must be social protection of women in the countryside.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, I want to congratulate and thank colleagues Petir and Lidia Senra for this report, which wants to give women who work in rural areas visibility, but also policies so that their contribution to development, sustainability and innovation in this sector is recognized and supported. To begin with, for justice but also for efficiency. For this reason, we have opted - and this has been reflected in the report - that this is the first step towards the drafting of a European Statute for women farmers, such as the one that is already applied in some historical European nationalities such as the Basque Country, and from whose contents most of the amendments that we have tabled come. We need more women owners or co-owners of farms, in positions of responsibility in cooperatives and companies, and a CAP that seriously measures and allows the female contribution to emerge, that puts it in value in terms of income and talent, and that supports it accordingly.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, this report on women and their role in rural areas is very important because we demand that the European Commission and the Member States take measures in favor of development in rural areas, where women play an essential role, but not only economically, but also socially. Many of our demands through amendments, and also thanks to the work of my colleague Lidia and Mrs. Petir, are reflected in this report. For example, a high level of public services can be ensured in rural areas, because if not, it will be impossible to fix population. We ask to guarantee the right of access to ownership of agricultural holdings for women and we also encourage budgets with a gender perspective and, finally, we recall the need to strengthen the means to combat sexist violence in rural areas. In short, if we want gender equality and cohesion to be not only principles written in the Treaties, specific public policies must be developed so that the rural environment subsists.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, women produce more than half of the world's food, but only a minority own their land: invisible work, difficult access to finance, underrepresentation of women in decision-making positions are constant in the rural world. The Greens consider that the current model of agriculture, which is industrial, globalized and intensive, in addition to being unsustainable for the planet, also contributes to perpetuating this inequality between men and women. On the other hand, the agricultural model of the future and also for the CAP, for example, is ecological and egalitarian. There, women are agents of change and play a key role in the creation of new rural jobs, such as crafts or quality tourism. To do this, the European Union has to lead this ecological and gender transition. We need the European and national institutions to support us, support them. It is an opportunity for society as a whole.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Ms. President! Again the usual situation, there is a problem with the title, the situation of women in the countryside, but in which countryside, please nicely, in which Member State? In Austria, where there is a strong rural citizenship, the land, the small farm, the mixed farm, possibly a small inn, are handed over from mother to daughter, from father to son, etc., or in Hungary, a hundred kilometers away, where there was a communist type of cooperative system. which was over, the good people got the land in good times, it is very difficult for women to get land, the previous colleague spoke correctly about the difficulties of getting land, just did not talk about the situation in countries where oligarchs acquire land, and there are very few women in these oligarchic groups. On the other hand, you, our dear Western friends, who have achieved the inclusion of arable land in the chapter on the free movement of capital, this disgrace, please, if you want to help rural women, perhaps also in Central and Eastern European countries, please eliminate the inclusion of arable land in the free movement of capital chapter.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: –  A Uachtaráin, aontaím go hiomlán leis an mbeirt rapóirtéirí nuair a deir siad gur laochra iad na mná go háirithe atá ag feidhmiú i saol na tuaithe. I ndáiríre tá siad ag coimeád shaol na tuaithe le chéile mar dheirfiúracha, mar mháithreacha, seanmháithreacha, oibrithe ar fheirmeacha agus gach uile rud. Freisin, tá siad ag cabhrú go mór leis na gluaiseachtaí deonacha a choimeád le chéile mar oibrithe deonacha, rúnaithe agus mar sin de agus ba chóir gach aitheantas agus cabhair a thabhairt dóibh. Aontaím go hiomlán gur cheart dúinn tuarastáil féaráilte a thabhairt dóibh, aitheantas a thabhairt dóibh, saol sóisialta níos fearr a thabhairt dóibh agus freisin seans a thabhairt dóibh chun breisoideachas a fháil má tá sin ag teastáil uathu. An tseachtain seo caite bhí grúpa ban agamsa sa Pharlaimint mar chuairteoirí agus bhí sé go hiontach iad a bheith linn agus tá súil agam go mbeidh mé in ann iad a thabhairt ar ais arís. Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the progress made in recent years, women in rural areas continue to have difficulties in accessing the labor market and in decision-making fora. In order for women to benefit from aid schemes in the agricultural sector, their role in the business must first be recognized. Guaranteeing social protection for women active in agriculture is an indispensable element in contributing to the modern and sustainable development of the countryside. The professional development, training and specialization of women in agriculture are other essential elements to ensure the development of farms. Equality between women and men is a fundamental objective of the European Union and its Member States. To achieve it in agriculture and rural areas, it is essential to integrate the gender dimension into the CAP and cohesion policies in rural areas, as well as new actions aimed at encouraging the participation of women in the labor market in rural areas. within the EAFRD.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, my thanks to Ms Senra Rodríguez and Ms Petir for this joint report of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM). The strength of support for your joint report reflects the fact that you have accurately identified the challenges faced by women in rural areas.  The Commission welcomes the report in terms of its recognition of the contribution that women make to the rural economy, and also of the opportunities for women both on- and off-farm. Gender equality is a fundamental EU value. As policymakers, we have a responsibility to ensure that the rights of women are fully protected and to enable women to realise their potential. This needs both legislative and non-legislative action. We are committed to mainstreaming the gender perspective into all policy areas and to promote gender equality in the preparation and implementation of EU programmes. This includes the CAP, the rural development policy, which is an essential element of the wider policies supporting both on-farm and off-farm investment to ensure the vitality and viability of our rural communities. The report emphasises the importance of the family farm model, which frequently involves the participation of all family members and often as many as three generations. The modernised and simplified CAP will continue to foster and support European family farms. We need to provide opportunities to young men and women who wish to live and work in rural communities, so that they can make the most of their potential. Attractive rural communities will help generate balanced territorial development.  We also recognised the need to do more in relation to the roll-out of rural broadband, which is essential if we are going to encourage those who wish to live and those who wish to work in rural communities. Women have always played a huge role on family farms, even if not always adequately rewarded financially. Today, the numbers of women wishing to enter farming in Europe has probably never been higher, yet there are persistent barriers to entry that prevent many young men and women from taking up farming, and women face particular problems. The Cork 2.0 Declaration on a better life for rural areas includes strong messages that rural areas must be attractive places for people in which to live and to work throughout the different stages of life.  Your report addresses itself to the Commission and to the Member States. We must all take our respective responsibilities in formulating a comprehensive and considered response, and I trust that the Member States will take careful note of the report’s observations and recommendations. Honourable Members, this report reminds us all of the essential role that women play in rural areas and throughout society. It also reminds us that there are challenges facing women, but there are also opportunities. It reminds us that adopting legislation is not enough to remedy inequality. We must also make certain it is properly implemented.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday, April 4, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The gender dimension is also an instrument applicable to EU structural and investment funds, including the EAFRD, and the inclusion of women in education and in the STEM sector favors the achievement of gender equality in different sectors. Furthermore, maintaining an active population is of considerable importance for the conservation of the environment and ecosystems, and rural tourism is a source of employment and incentives for the population to stay on site. If we consider that between 2005 and 2010 in the EU more than 2 million family farms disappeared, we understand how important the issue is and the report presented aims to highlight the multifunctional and active role of women in rural areas as promoters of sustainable and environmentally friendly agriculture. EU and Member States are called upon to support and encourage access to the labor market for women in rural areas, and to include policies focused on the contribution made by women themselves in their rural development programs, in order to increase their participation in PAC as of beneficiaries.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. - Women in rural areas need and deserve our full attention and full support, as they play an extremely important role in their family farms and contribute to the development of entrepreneurship, sustainable development and the development of the economy in general. The challenges facing women in rural areas are many and we call on the Member States and regional and local authorities to continue to support these women and encourage them to take additional action.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. – Equality between women and men is one of the basic values of the European Union and it should not be different in rural areas. Women in rural areas are under-represented in the executive bodies, and face, among other things, significant pension gaps, violence and difficulties to access childcare. We must safeguard the effective implementation of the Barcelona objectives concerning childcare facilities and urge Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention to fight those challenges. In order to secure the possibilities for women, and not only for them, to develop their entrepreneurial potential, it is necessary to guarantee the connection of rural areas with economic centres. Therefore, I encourage Member States to use wisely the sources from the Cohesion and Structural Funds to expand the infrastructure and to provide full coverage by internet network. I would like to point out Finland as an example to follow regarding providing access to the internet for isolated areas. Furthermore, I call on the Commission to include the question of rural areas in the Digital Agenda, since digital development can influence the quality of life and boost competitiveness and employment.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: in writing. - In my opinion, this is a very important report as it highlights the importance of the role of women whose hard work does not seem to be sufficiently recognized or appreciated in rural areas so far. I had the pleasure of working on this report as a shadow rapporteur and was also able to make some positive changes to it, including increasing the financing of aid projects for women (now funds for their financing will come from both the 1st and 2nd pillar). However, while I strongly support the broadly understood improvement of working conditions for women in rural areas, unfortunately I cannot agree with the term 'gender mainstreaming' proposed in the report, as the concept is vague and undefined in international law. I am also concerned about the call for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, which, firstly, also changes the definition of gender and, secondly, allows excessive interference by the European Commission in the areas of social and employment policy, which are the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen! Within the EU, family farms dominate, where nearly 80% of work is performed by family members. Taking into account that in rural areas only 60% of women have official employment, this means that a large part of them perform the so-called invisible work. This is a serious problem because very often they are not covered by the social security system and do not have their own financial resources. This in turn makes them dependent on their husbands and partners throughout their lives. Therefore, within the EU, we should consider how to solve this problem. Competences in this area generally belong to the Member States, but it would be worth thinking about introducing a system of incentives to institutionalize the work of women and other family members, as well as creating a mechanism for the exchange of good practices between Member States, within the framework of the common agricultural policy. Some European countries have already noticed the problem of "invisible" work by women and there are various solutions in them, including, for example, differentiating legal statuses of spouses working on family farms. A good example is France, where family members can have the status of manager, associate or employee. Giving official professional status is one of the possibilities to strengthen the financial independence of women and guarantee them higher pensions. It is important because without taking these measures it will not be possible to stop the depopulation of rural areas.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I want to congratulate the rapporteurs, Marijana Petir and Lidia Senra, for their good joint work on a text that includes many of the requests that Parliament has already expressed in its report on the future of the CAP.A gender perspective is necessary to combat the enormous inequalities in access to land and agricultural property between men and women, as well as in the recognition of their status and rights as farm workers.The Commission must take note of the serious decline in the situation of women in rural areas and integrate this gender perspective into the development of the CAP.For this, as the report points out, it will also be necessary to improve the implementation of policies in rural areas, facilitating the participation of women in decision-making.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for one-minute interventions on important political issues (Rule 163).

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Venezuela was without a National Assembly for three days after the Supreme Court decided to usurp its powers and deprive Members of their immunity. This coup d'état was aborted by the Supreme Court judges who, due to the strong opposition in the streets, realized the seriousness of their act. It was, however, just one more episode that illustrates the anti-democratic and totalitarian nature of the Venezuelan Government, which started by disrespecting the 2015 electoral result, went through the delaying maneuvers of the National Electoral Council to make the revocation referendum unfeasible, by the interference of President Maduro in the judicial system and even for the irrational decision to expropriate bakeries, most of which are owned by Portuguese emigrants. The situation in Venezuela is very serious. In Venezuela you die of hunger, you die of diseases that are deadly nowhere else in the world. In Venezuela, citizens are treated like animals at the mercy of the whims of the Maduro regime.
