The humanitarian crisis in Venezuela has reached such serious proportions that we Europeans did not imagine that it could happen in the 21st century and in a country that was a world reference for progress and democracy. Dear Colleagues, assistance to the martyred people of Venezuela is urgently needed. Venezuelans expect us, Europeans and Democrats, to act to help them. I call on this House to make every political and diplomatic effort so that the opening of real humanitarian corridors to Venezuela is possible.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Madam President, according to estimates by the European Environment Agency, about 15 thousand cases of premature death in Bulgaria in 2013 were due to the concentration of air pollutants. For years we have been hearing from the representatives of GERB how well and successfully Bulgaria has been governed and how well the European funds are being absorbed. Success cannot be based on self-esteem. The facts speak louder than the words. Cases of premature death clearly give a realistic assessment of the "successes" of the GERB government over the years. In addition to the thousands of health-related deaths, the financial cost of air pollution in Bulgaria is over 3 billion euros per year, which includes direct costs to the economy. Over the years, GERB has spent thousands of euros in litigation to challenge the Commission's decisions instead of making the air better for its own citizens. This luxury will now have to be paid for by Bulgarian citizens, however, after the ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union is confirmed in two days. The Bulgarians also suffered and suffered, thanks to GERB. Think about the citizens, colleagues from GERB - not about how to present the glassware for "supposedly" successful management.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Dear President, for a long time the citizens of Croatia have been protesting against the Enforcement Act, which, in its current form, is a legalized robbery of an ordinary person.In the elections, they mostly chose parties that promised to change the law, but nothing came of it because of the obvious link between politics and powerful interest groups that stand behind such a law and are rich in its application.The Court of Justice of the European Union has determined that Croatian notaries, when acting in enforcement proceedings on the basis of the so-called"Authentic instruments" cannot be considered a "court" in the application of the Regulation on the European Enforcement Order and the Regulation on the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters.This means that such actions of Croatian notaries cannot be enforced by anyone in the European Union, except Croats.This is blatant discrimination and I therefore ask the Commission to state whether such a law is in line with the acquis.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Mr Vučić on his election as the new Serbian President. At the same time, I would like to point out that the electoral campaign has now ended and it is time to leave nationalism aside. The EU hopes to have a partner in President Vučić. We expect Serbia to remain a stable and trustworthy partner in enlargement talks and contribute to regional stability with an EU—oriented government. The EU expects the implementation of reforms, improvement of the socioeconomic status of the country and the establishment of an honest dialogue with Kosovo. Serbia should stay on the EU path and not fall back into the trap of nationalism and interference in the internal matters of neighbouring countries. I wish President Vučić every good luck with the hope that we will see the best of Serbia in years to come.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, I am bringing the struggle of the workers of the Rota base to this plenary session. It is a matter of international scope, because the multinational Louis Berger has laid off twelve workers, threatens further layoffs and intends to reduce wages by up to 35%. And all this in the course of negotiating the collective agreement, also violating the right to strike. Likewise, the bilateral agreement signed with the Government of Spain is breached, by which 370 Spanish workers should be hired at the base. The Government of Spain allows the European regulations on the transfer of companies, information and consultation, and collective dismissals to be breached, tolerating the blackmail of this multinational. If the Government of Spain is not going to act against the United States, it is the Commission's mission to remind it and make it comply with its international obligations, because no worker who fights for their rights deserves the lack of institutional support to which they are submitting. Rota workers.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, I want to report two things. One, the daring interference of Spain in the future of Gibraltar, which has decided, almost unanimously, to remain in the European Union. To meddle in Gibraltar now, for your own benefit, is to hamper any negotiation with Great Britain rather than to help find solutions. Second: the use that Spain makes of European money for the Mediterranean Corridor is scandalous. Saying that the Mediterranean Corridor goes from Algeciras to Madrid is like saying that the Berlin-Munich or Paris-Lyon lines have to do with the English Channel. The Government of Spain twists everything, including geography, to the benefit of its expensive, useless and outdated centralist project. But is it possible that Parliament and the Commission do not know geography and that they give money for a transfer that causes laughter and pain in primary school children? I am shocked. Wherever you look, Madrid is not in the Mediterranean and it seems that it will not be in the next millennium.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Madam President, the people of French Guiana have revolted to protest against their abandonment. Nothing works any more in Guyana: hospitals, schools and public services are in ruins; security is no longer guaranteed and borders are sieves, incapable of stopping the migratory flood. The French state is primarily responsible for this situation because of its leaders who have let everything go wrong for 40 years, like Ms. Taubira, who is nevertheless Guyanese. But the European Union is also responsible, because Guyana is an outermost region which benefits from grants from the ERDF and the European Social Fund. However, these subsidies were used to finance networks of no interest such as "an animation network intended to create a dynamic of territory and a strategic watch of structuring projects". The European Union thus proves once again that it is far removed from the real concerns of citizens. It is not animation that the Guyanese need, but respect and solidarity.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Madam President!As all decent socialists, communists, and other leftists know, a capitalist is a terrible man.The capitalist only dreams of exploiting his worker.This is his favorite dream, and his favorite game is to throw a worker who earns more from his job, to replace him with another worker who earns less.Well, if women got sixteen percent less for the same work, surely the capitalists would have kicked out all men and replaced them with women.Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to draw attention to the case of two young Czech citizens who were arrested in Turkey in November 2016. Miroslav Farkas and Markéta Všelichová visited the Rodžava region in Syria, where they helped manage the humanitarian crisis in an area inhabited mainly by Kurds and helped build a hospital. As part of this activity, they also met with members of the IPG, groups that are recognized in many European countries as part of a coalition fighting the so-called Islamic State. Both young people are currently in Turkish prisons awaiting trial. The reason is precisely their contacts with IPG, which is considered a terrorist organization in Turkey. I continue to believe in a fair trial. I know their parents, I know their story and I believe they are innocent. My colleagues and I are working to release them. We have written a letter to the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Mogherini, asking her to support their release. Markéta and Mirek wanted to help in good faith and are now facing unjust consequences. Nevertheless, we believe that there will be a fair trial that will set them free.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Ms. President!In the last few days, nearly forty thousand scientists, academics and university professors around the world, including fifteen Nobel Prize-winning economists, have raised their voices because Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán wants to close the region's best international university in Budapest, the Central European University.I called this move an orbital lice in the Hungarian media, and yesterday ten thousand young people protested against this diabolical plan with a similar opinion.The phlegmatic response of power today is to fabricate a law in twenty-four hours to legalize its evil.Viktor Orbán, as well as Putin and Erdogan's most enthusiastic followers of the European Union, destroys not only education, but also the entire Hungarian civil sector with another shameful law.The Hungarian people are now crying out for European solidarity.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - A month ago, in this chamber, I spoke of a woman who, without her consent, despite desperate attempts to defend herself, was killed in one of the Dutch levenseindekliniek.At that time, I called for a reaction from the Vice-President of the Commission, officially responsible for human rights, Frans Timmermans.Two weeks ago, during his first visit to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs in two years, I tried to obtain his position directly.The vice-chairman declined, explaining that this was not the topic of his visit to the committee.This attitude shows the actual position of the management of the European Commission, which is in office today, towards the rule of law, towards parliamentary control, and above all towards human rights and the most tragic human misfortunes.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, France wants to take another bold step to disrupt the European Union's internal market. The French regions are quietly introducing the so-called Molière clause, according to which companies applying for a public works contract must ensure that all workers speak French. It is clear that this measure is intended to discriminate against foreigners again and make it more difficult for them to access the French labor market. This condition is completely at odds with European legislation, as the Commission itself has already confirmed. The main reason for introducing this measure is to increase safety on construction sites. The real reason, in my opinion, is just another effort to protect the French market. Or is France trying to tell us that it is being treated differently in other Member States than in France? The principle of free movement of persons and services requires that the requirement of knowledge of the language of that State be ensured only for professions where it is necessary for communication reasons. At present, the introduction of various discriminatory and protectionist measures has directly torn the bag. Similar measures can only trigger further countermeasures by the remaining Member States. Is this really the path we want to take?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, now that Article 50 has been triggered everybody is focused on what will transpire in relation to negotiations. We in Ireland are well aware that we will probably be the most affected country in the European Union – economically, definitely, especially in relation to agriculture, but more importantly in relation to the border that hardly exists right now thanks to the good work of the European Union over many years, the USA and the two governments. You could walk across the border now just as easily as you could walk from one of these rooms to the other. That is the way it has to stay, because if you unravel that you could set things back 20 years. It would upset trade, it would upset jobs but, above all, would upset peace. We cannot risk that in Ireland or the European Union, too much has been invested in it. This is not a bargaining chip. The border, which is invisible at this stage, must continue into the future.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D).
text: - Thank you, Madam President. Dear colleagues, last year, on July 7, here in Strasbourg, we launch to you the proposal that, in post-Brexit conditions, we take together a first step towards consolidating a homogeneous Europe, of the 27, by rethinking the distribution in the territory of institutions of the Union. At that time, I made known to you my intention to initiate and support the relocation of the European Medicines Agency from London to Bucharest, and I am glad that you are with me in this endeavor. I also thank the Prime Minister of Romania, Sorin Grindeanu, for responding more than positively to my idea, organizing an inter-institutional working group to prepare Romania's candidacy for the relocation of the European Medicines Agency to Bucharest. For those who still have doubts and ask if Romania is ready to host an institution of this magnitude, I announce that as soon as possible I will make available a study prepared on my initiative and with the support of the European Parliament, where you will find all the arguments necessary to support the proposal to relocate the European Medicines Agency to Romania. Thank you.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, autism affects as many as 5 million people in Europe, and the data shows a growing trend. Autism involves significant disabilities for those affected and upsets entire families. Talking about autism is less scary today than in the past. Many barriers have fallen, there is a widespread sensitivity, there is greater knowledge thanks to initiatives such as the world day of awareness of autism, celebrated yesterday. However, much remains to be done in terms of research, in terms of care and quality of life for these people and their families. A strategic response from the European institutions is necessary and can no longer be postponed, also in light of the written declaration on autism adopted by this Parliament in 2015. The European Union must be able to respond adequately to the challenge of autism and ensure adequate assistance for people with autism and their families. We cannot turn away from those who suffer.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Union has always been a project of peace, democracy and human rights, keeping the peace on this continent for decades, yet now, within days of triggering the UK’s exit process, senior Tories are already threatening to go to war with Spain. How utterly foolish. It is imperative that we continue to speak out to the British people about the EU’s role in promoting peace and human rights. One year ago today, British Iranian citizen Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, was imprisoned in Iran on unknown charges but, together with many fellow MEPs, I have sent a letter to key Iranian leaders urging her release, as well as that of EU Iranian prisoners Dr Jalali and Nazak Afshar. The EU must continue to be a pillar for human rights in the world, to take a stand when children are imprisoned in Bahrain, for example, or when LGBTI people are rounded up and killed in Chechnya, as is being reported. It is true that working together we can achieve more than alone and we must continue to speak that truth.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the latest data from the European Commission on the index of the digital economy and society place Romania in a surprising and disappointing position. The quality and very high speed of the internet are clearly disconnected, for the time being, from the full, economic and social capitalization of digitalization. Romania can and must take advantage of the digital revolution. This must be implemented at both national and local level. In this context and in the conditions in which I presented this proposal two years ago, I want to make an appeal from the plenary of the European Parliament to the local authorities in my hometown, Oradea. I believe that local authorities need to work with the private sector, young people and beyond, the education community and the social partners so that the whole community can take full advantage of technological progress. Oradea has the vocation and the potential to become, among others, a new IT hub of Romania, in the conditions in which it manages to support an ecosystem conducive to innovation. As a programming engineer, but also as an MEP, I will do everything I can to help. Thank you.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I issue a strong warning to the European Commission. Romania and the countries of Eastern Europe must not be forced to pay the Brexit bill. I received with concern the recent message from the Vice-President of the European Commission, Mr Oettinger, who spoke of the need to make consistent savings in the future multiannual budget following Brexit. This explicitly suggests that the aim is to reduce the budget for cohesion policy, in addition to the possible increase in contributions for Member States. What we understand is that Eastern states, such as Romania, would be double-taxed following the exit of Great Britain. Therefore, not only a multi-speed Europe is being prepared, but also a Brexit at an extra price for those in the east. A reform of cohesion policy would dramatically accentuate all the inequalities we are trying to correct in the European Union. These cuts would be tantamount to sacrificing the interests of these new states, which have very acute development gaps. The European Commission must do everything possible to avoid such unfair treatment applied to states such as Romania, because the result would be the de facto split of the European Union.
